  3-1-17 et seq. of this Title.
ARTICLE B. CARNIVALS AND AMUSEMENT RIDES
SECTION:
3-4B-1: Carnivals
3-4B-1-1: Definition
3-4B-1-2: Permit Required; Restrictions on Issuance
3-4B-1-3: Investigation of Applicant; Insurance; Powers of Police
3-4B-1-4: Permit Issued in Duplicate; Availability for Inspection
3-4B-1-5: Violations
3-4B-2: Amusement Rides
3-4B-2-1: Compliance with State Law
3-4B-2-2: Permit Required
3-4B-2-3: Insurance or Bond
3-4B-1: CARNIVALS:
3-4B-1-1: DEFINITION:
"Carnival" means and includes an aggregation of attractions, whether shows,
acts, games, vending devices or amusement devices, whether conducted under one
or more managements or independently, which are temporarily set up or conducted
in a public place or upon any private premises accessible to the public, with
or without admission fee, 1  and which, from the nature of the aggregation,
attracts attendance and causes promiscuous intermingling of persons in the
spirit of merrymaking and revelry. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-2-6 of this Title for amusements tax.
3-4B-1-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE: 1
No carnival shall be set up, run, operated or conducted within the limits of
the City unless a written permit from the City Council has been issued, setting
forth the conditions under which such carnival shall be operated. The permit
shall be granted upon the condition that there shall not be set up or operated
any gambling device, lottery, number or paddle wheel, number board, punchboard
or other game of chance, except as permitted pursuant to Illinois Revised
Statutes, chapter 38, paragraph 28-1(b), or any lewd, lascivious or indecent
show or attraction making an indecent exposure of the person or suggesting
lewdness or immorality.
Carnivals may be held and conducted by not-for-profit organizations; provided,
however, that all of such not-for-profit organizations shall operate and
supervise a carnival in the City not more than once in each calendar year, and
provided further, however, that such not-for-profit organizations shall be
jointly and severally accountable for the maintenance, operation and
supervision of such carnival, and further provided, that such carnival shall
receive authority and permission from the City Council and shall conform to all
of the ordinances in effect at that time. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
 
Notes
1 2. See Section 3-1A-1 of this Title for permit fee.
3-4B-1-3: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; INSURANCE; POWERS OF POLICE:
No permit shall be granted by the City Council until it shall have investigated
the carnival and is satisfied that, if permitted, it will be operated in
accordance with the permit and the provisions of this Section
3-4B-1 and the carnival has filed with the City Clerk proof of insurance naming
the City as an additional insured in such limits as shall be determined by the
City Council. The City Council may issue the permit and collect fees necessary
to pay the expenses of the investigation and to aid in policing the grounds and
otherwise to compensate the City in such amount as the City Council may
determine. The permit shall contain the proviso that police officers shall have
free access to the grounds and all booths, shows and concessions on such
grounds at all times, and it shall be the duty of all officers present at such
carnival to enforce all the provisions of this Section. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
3-4B-1-4: PERMIT ISSUED IN DUPLICATE; AVAILABILITY FOR INSPECTION:
The permit as provided for in this Section
3-4B-1 shall be made in duplicate, one copy thereof being retained by the City
Clerk. The other copy shall be kept in the possession of the manager of the
carnival and shall be produced and shown to any sheriff, police officer or
citizen upon request. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
3-4B-1-5: VIOLATIONS:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this Section
3-4B-1 is guilty of a petty offense pursuant to Illinois Revised Statutes,
chapter 24, division 54.1. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
3-4B-2: AMUSEMENT RIDES:
3-4B-2-1: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
No amusement ride or amusement attraction shall be licensed by the City at any
carnival in the City unless the operator of the amusement ride or amusement
attraction has first complied with the Carnival and Amusement Rides Safety Act,
Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 1111/2, paragraphs 4051-4069. (Ord. 0-27-90,
6-4-90)
3-4B-2-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate any amusement ride or amusement attraction at a
carnival or fair in this City without the owner or operator of such equipment
first having obtained from the Director of Health and Inspectional Services,
upon the approval of the City Council, a permit for the operation of such
equipment. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
3-4B-2-3: INSURANCE OR BOND:
No person shall be issued a permit under this Section
3-4B-2 unless at the time of application there is in force:
   A.   Insurance: A liability insurance policy or policies in an aggregate
amount of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily
injury to or death of one person in any one accident and, subject to the limit
for one person, in an amount of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury to or death of two (2) or more persons in any
one accident and in an amount of not less than fifty thousand dollars
($50,000.00) for injury to or destruction of property of others in any one
accident, insuring the operator against liability for injury or death suffered
by a person attending a carnival; or
   B.   Bond: A bond in like amount, the aggregate liability of the surety of
which shall not exceed the face amount thereof. (Ord. 0-27-90, 6-4-90)
ARTICLE C. RAFFLES
SECTION:
3-4C-1: Definitions
3-4C-2: Classification Of Licenses
3-4C-3: License Required
3-4C-4: Application For License
3-4C-5: Issuance Of License; Restrictions
3-4C-6: License Fee; Term; Revocation
3-4C-7: Conduct Of Raffles
3-4C-8: Raffles Manager; Bond
3-4C-9: Raffle Tickets And Prizes
3-4C-10: Records And Reports
3-4C-11: Rules And Regulations
3-4C-12: Penalty
3-4C-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who
have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial and civic
interests of a community.
CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an
indefinite number of the public. The services rendered to those eligible for
benefits must also confer some benefits on the public.
EDUCATION: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide
systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to
schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and
intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools.
FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary
interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide
assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of
government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by the
government.
LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of
betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the
development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective operations.
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable
sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating
expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not-for-
profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the
operation.
ORGANIZATION: Includes an auxiliary or affiliate of a licensee.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery, as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-2
(b) conducted by an organization licensed under this article, in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance;
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery; except, that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the
purpose of religious worship.
VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which
substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows or
widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to
confer a public benefit. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990; amd. Ord. O-03-2018, 2-12-
2018; Ord. O-08-2018, 4-16-2018)
3-4C-2: CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES:
   A.   Class A; General Raffle License: A general raffle license shall permit
an organization the ability to conduct a raffle that may include multiple
drawings to award prizes, but all drawings must occur on the same day and at
the same location and within the confines of the same raffle event.
   B.   Class B; Financial Hardship Raffle License: A financial hardship raffle
license allows a not-for-profit fund-raising organization or group, organized
for the sole purpose of providing financial hardship assistance to an
identified individual or group of individuals suffering severe financial
hardship as a result of an injury, disability, accident or disaster, to conduct
one raffle event for that purpose.
   C.   Class C; Annual Raffle License: An annual raffle license permits an
organization to regularly conduct raffles as defined herein within twelve (12)
consecutive calendar months. Such license shall permit no more than fifty two
(52) raffle events per year. (Ord. O-08-2018, 4-16-2018)
3-4C-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a raffle without first having obtained a license
pursuant to this article. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license shall be made, in writing, at the Office of the City
Clerk, no fewer than thirty (30) days before the intended sale of raffle
chances, on forms provided by the City Clerk's Office.
Each license and application for license shall contain the following
information:
   A.   The name and address of the applicant;
   B.   The area within the City in which the raffle chances will be sold or
issued;
   C.   The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued;
   D.   The date, time and location(s) of determining the winning chances;
   E.   A sworn statement attesting to the nonprofit character of the
prospective licensee organization, signed by its presiding officer and the
secretary of that organization;
   F.   A copy of the applicant's articles of incorporation and/or charter; and
   G.   Such other information as the City Council requires. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-
4-1990)
3-4C-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   The City Council shall have the authority to issue licenses for raffles
subject to the following limitations:
Licenses for raffles shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable,
labor, fraternal, educational or veterans' organizations that operate without
profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a
period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license
and have had, during that entire five (5) year period, bona fide membership
engaged in carrying out their objectives or to a nonprofit fund-raising
organization that the licensing authority determines is organized for the sole
purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual or group
of individuals suffering extreme hardship as the result of an illness,
disability, accident or disaster.
A license issued by the City shall authorize the sale of raffle chances only
within the borders of the City.
   B.   No raffle license shall be issued to:
      1.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character;
      4.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection B1,
B2 or B3 of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in
which such person is active or employed;
Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or B3 of this
section is an officer, director or employee, whether compensated or not;
Any organization in which a person defined in subsection B1, B2 or B3 of this
section is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined
in this article.
   C.   The City Council shall act on a license application within thirty (30)
days from the date of application. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-6: LICENSE FEE; TERM; REVOCATION:
No fee shall be required for issuance of a license under this article.
Licenses issued under this article shall be valid for one raffle or for a
specified number of raffles to be conducted during a specified period not to
exceed one year and may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this Code.
(Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-7: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
The conducting of raffles in the City is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle.
   D.   The maximum fee which may be charged for each raffle chance sold or
issued shall not exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). All such fees shall be
paid in currency or by check.
   E.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance
or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under
this article.
   F.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license, and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license.
   G.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-8: RAFFLES MANAGER; BOND:
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a
single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a
fidelity bond in the sum of an amount determined by the City in favor of the
organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties.
Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the
City not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation. The City Council
may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license;
provided, that a request for such waiver has been made by unanimous vote of the
members of the licensed organization. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-9: RAFFLE TICKETS AND PRIZES:
   A.   Raffle Tickets:
      1.   Each raffle ticket, chance or other raffle token shall state on its
face the name and address of the licensee, the date or dates of the drawings
and the prize or prizes to be awarded; provided, however, that this requirement
shall not apply to any raffle in which prizes in aggregate value under fifty
dollars ($50.00) are awarded or to any raffle in which raffle chances are sold
only on the date of the drawing during the event at which the drawing is to be
conducted. No such ticket, chance or token shall be sold or issued more than
two hundred forty (240) days before the determination of the winning chance or
chances.
      2.   If any raffle for which a license is issued under this article is
canceled or if any such raffle is not conducted on the date contained in the
application for license, the licensee shall refund all money paid for any
raffle chances issued or sold to the persons to whom such raffle chances were
sold or issued within forty five (45) days after cancellation of the raffle,
whichever is sooner. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
   B.   Prizes: The maximum cash prize awarded in any raffle shall be two
million five hundred thousand dollars ($2,500,000.00); the maximum retail value
of a noncash prize awarded in any raffle shall be one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00). The aggregate value of all prizes awarded in any raffle shall
not exceed two million six hundred thousand dollars ($2,600,000.00). (Ord. O-
08-2018, 4-16-2018)
   C.   Motor Vehicles: Any motor vehicle being offered as a raffle prize by a
not for profit organization is exempt from the City's license registration
requirements during the time that the motor vehicle is being offered as a
raffle prize provided that no such motor vehicle may be operated on a public
street or right-of-way without all required licenses and registrations. (Ord.
O-04-2008, 3-3-2008)
3-4C-10: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
   A.   Records Kept:
      1.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to the payee, purpose,
amount and date of payment.
      2.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor issued by the Department of Revenue of the State
of Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have
separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
      3.   Records required by this section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
   B.   Reports Required: Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall
report promptly after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership and the
City its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles and the
distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section. Such reports
shall be filed with the City Clerk no later than forty five (45) days after
each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined.
(Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-11: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The City or its designated agent may publish rules and regulations consistent
with this article or Illinois law governing the conduct of raffles licensed
hereunder. (Ord. O-27-90, 6-4-1990)
3-4C-12: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be
punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day
that a violation exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. (Ord.
O-08-2018, 4-16-2018)
ARTICLE D. ADULT USES OF PROPERTY
SECTION:
3-4D-1: Findings
3-4D-2: Purpose Of Regulations
3-4D-3: Definitions
3-4D-4: Location
3-4D-5: Registration
3-4D-6: Exterior Display
3-4D-7: License Required; Fees
3-4D-1: FINDINGS:
The Mayor and City Council make the following findings:
   A.   It is uncontested that the City may regulate, through its zoning power,
the location of sexually explicit businesses;
   B.   Zoning, when used to preserve the character of the residential and
commercial areas of the City, is perhaps the most essential function performed
by the City;
   C.   The City is predominately a single-family residential community with
approximately seventy percent (70%) of the total land area of the City zoned
and used for residential, school, park, cemetery and governmental purposes;
   D.   The Board of Appeals-Plan Commission held a public hearing, reviewed
the experiences of other municipalities, counties and units of local government
relative to adult uses;
   E.   The City is only about three (3) square miles in size and there are
many locations available for adult uses in the larger, immediately surrounding
communities, such as the City of Chicago, unincorporated Cook County and in
other municipalities;
   F.   The proposed regulation of adult uses serves a substantial governmental
interest, while allowing for reasonable alternative avenues of communication;
   G.   The Illinois Supreme Court has judicially confirmed that the regulation
of adult uses serves a valid governmental interest;
   H.   The proposed regulations are not aimed at the content of adult
entertainment, but at the secondary effects associated with it including, but
not limited to:
      1.   An increase in crime rates, particularly those that are sex-related;
      2.   A negative impact on the real estate market where adult
entertainment is offered; and
      3.   Urban blight as a result of the decrease in property values.
In particular, the Mayor and City Council have taken notice of the blighted,
dangerous and crime-producing conditions which have existed on nearby Mannheim
Road, on which a number of adult-oriented businesses have located.
In attempting to curb these secondary effects, the regulations serve the City's
substantial interest in the health, safety and welfare of the people of the
City; and
   I.   The detailed findings summarized in the U.S. Supreme Court opinion in
City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S. 41, 106 S.Ct. 925 (1986),
the Illinois Supreme Court opinion in County of Cook v. Renaissance Arcade and
Bookstore, 122 III.2d 123 (1988), and the United States District Court, Eastern
Division of Michigan opinion in S&G News, Inc. v. City of Southgate, 638
F.Supp. 1060 (E.D. Mich. 1986) aff'd 819 F.2d 1142 (6th Cir. 1987), were before
the Board of Appeals- Plan Commission when it recommended the adoption of these
regulations. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
3-4D-2: PURPOSE OF REGULATIONS:
These regulations are aimed at the secondary effects of adult uses, and not at
the content of the activities performed at such uses. In addition, these
regulations are based on the City's substantial interest in preventing crime,
protecting retail trade, maintaining property values, and generally to protect
and preserve the quality of the City's neighborhoods, commercial districts, and
the quality of urban life. Furthermore, it is not the purpose of these
regulations to deny anyone a reasonable opportunity to open and operate adult
uses within the City. The predominate purpose of these regulations is the
amelioration of socially adverse secondary effects of adult uses. Finally, the
Illinois Supreme Court has judicially confirmed that the purpose of these
regulations as hereinafter provided serves a valid governmental interest. (Ord.
O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
3-4D-3: DEFINITIONS:
ADULT BOOKSTORE: An establishment having, as a substantial or significant
portion of its sales or stock in trade, books, magazines, films for rent, sale
or for viewing on-premises by use of motion picture devices or by coin-operated
means, and periodicals, which are distinguished or characterized by their
emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual
activities, or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment with a
substantial or significant segment or section devoted to the sale or display of
such materials; or an establishment that holds itself out to the public as a
purveyor of such materials based upon its signage, advertising, displays,
actual sales, presence of video preview or coin-operated booths, exclusion of
minors from the establishment's premises or any other factors showing the
establishment's primary purpose is to purvey such materials.
ADULT ENTERTAINMENT CABARET: A public or private establishment which:
   A.   Features topless dancers, strippers, or male or female impersonators;
or
   B.   Not infrequently features entertainers who display specified anatomical
areas; or
   C.   Features entertainers who by reason of their appearance or conduct
perform in a manner which is designed primarily to appeal to the prurient
interest of the patron; or
   D.   Features entertainers who engage in or are engaged in explicit
simulation of specified sexual activities.
ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER: A building or area used for presenting materials
distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing
or relating to specified activities or specified anatomical areas for
observation by patrons therein.
ADULT USE: Adult bookstores, adult motion picture theaters, adult entertainment
cabarets, and/or other similar uses.
SPECIFIED ANATOMICAL AREAS:
   A.   Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region,
buttock, or female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the
areola; and/or
   B.   Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely
and opaquely covered.
SPECIFIED SEXUAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Human genitals in the state of sexual stimulation or arousal;
   B.   Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; and/or
   C.   Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region,
buttock or female breasts. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
3-4D-4: LOCATION:
Adult uses are permitted uses only on lots which are more than one thousand
feet (1,000') from a lot on which an elementary or secondary school is located
and which are in the I-3 Industrial District. For the purpose of this Section,
the one thousand feet (1,000') is measured from the points on the boundaries of
the respective zoning lots which are closest to each other. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-
1998)
3-4D-5: REGISTRATION:
The owner of any building or premises, said owner's agent for the purposes of
managing, controlling or collecting rents, or any other person managing or
controlling any building or premises used in whole or in part for an adult use,
shall register the following information with the City Clerk:
   A.   The address of the premises;
   B.   The name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s) of the premises and the
beneficial owner(s) if the property is in a land trust;
   C.   The name of the business or establishment;
   D.   The name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s), beneficial owner(s) and/or
the major stockholder(s) of the business or establishment;
   E.   The date of the initiation of the adult use;
   F.   The nature of the adult use;
   G.   If the premises or building is leased, a copy of said lease must be
attached to the registration form. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
3-4D-6: EXTERIOR DISPLAY:
No adult use shall be conducted in any manner that permits the observation of
any material depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities
or specified anatomical areas from any public way or from any property not
registered as an adult use. This provision shall apply to any display,
decoration, sign, show window or other opening. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
3-4D-7: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEES:
No person shall operate adult uses within the City without first applying for
an adult uses license therefor. The fee for an adult uses license and related
procedures governing the licenses shall be as set forth in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. An adult use license shall be nontransferable and shall
be issued only for one specific business location. (Ord. O-11-98, 2-9-1998)
ARTICLE E. MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS
SECTION:
3-4E-1: License Required
3-4E-2: Application for License
3-4E-3: License Fees
3-4E-4: Conditions of License
3-4E-5: Building Requirements
3-4E-6: Order; Crowding
3-4E-7: Penalty
3-4E-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall give, present or conduct any motion pictures or theatricals,
for admission to which a fee is charged 1 , without first having obtained a
license therefor as is herein provided. (1976 Code §
3-4-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-2-6 of this Title for amusements tax.
3-4E-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for theater licenses shall be made in conformity with the general
provisions of this Code relating to applications for licenses 1  and shall
state, in addition to the other information required, the place of the intended
performance and the seating capacity thereof. (1976 Code §
3-4-2)
 
Notes
1 2. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-4E-3: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Licensed Premises: Any person securing any annual license for motion
pictures or theatricals, naming a specific place or building where the
performances are to be presented, may present therein any number of
performances, including theatricals, during the year for which the license was
obtained without having to pay any additional fee. (1976 Code §
3-4-3)
   B.   Unlicensed Premises: For motion pictures and theatricals which are to
be presented in premises which are not covered by the theater license fees, the
licensee shall pay a fee as provided in Chapter 1, Article A of this Title;
provided, that no such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on
any premises or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of
the ordinances for the construction or maintenance of buildings for this
purpose. (1976 Code §
3-4-4)
3-4E-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Sunday Operations: No person shall present any motion picture or
theatrical or allow any premises to remain open for the purpose of presenting
any motion picture or theatrical before one thirty o'clock (1:30) P.M. on
Sunday. (1976 Code §
3-4-5)
   B.   Prohibited Motion Pictures: No licensee shall offer or permit any
person to offer or present any motion picture which has a tendency to cause a
riot or public disturbance of the peace. (1976 Code §
3-4-6)
3-4E-5: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Generally: No person shall present any public motion picture in any
building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required by
the provisions of the City or by the statutes of the State concerning buildings
or places intended for motion picture performances or in premises in which the
electric wiring does not fully comply with the provisions of the City. All
places used for the exhibition of theatricals must be kept adequately
ventilated during the performance and for so long a time as the audience
remains therein. (1976 Code §3-4-9)
   B.   Scenery: No person shall use any scenery in any theater other than
nonflammable scenery or such as shall have been rendered nonflammable by the
application of fire-preventive coatings. (1976 Code §3-4-8)
3-4E-6: ORDER; CROWDING:
   A.   No person shall permit any person, except ushers or other theater
employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is
presented during the time of such performance or admit to any such hall more
persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements for the premises.
(1976 Code §
3-4-7)
   B.   Obstructing Exits Prohibited: No person shall obstruct or permit the
obstruction of any aisles, corridors or exits leading from the room or
enclosure in which a motion picture performance or theatrical is being given or
in which an audience for such performance is gathered. (1976 Code §3-4-10)
3-4E-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (1992 Code)
ARTICLE F. PUBLIC DANCES
SECTION:

3-4F-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or conduct a public dance without having first obtained
a license therefor as provided in this Article. (1976 Code §
3-5-1)

Application for a public dance license shall be made in conformance with the

(1976 Code §

3-4F-3: QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT; INVESTIGATION:
No public dance license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of
good moral character nor to a corporation or organization which is not
represented in the City by a person of good moral character.
The Chief of Police shall make or cause to be made an investigation into the
character of each applicant and report the results of such investigation to the
City Clerk. (1976 Code §
3-5-2)
3-4F-4: EXITS REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a public dance or operate a dance hall in any hall or
place which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits. Any hall or
building which is not provided with at least two (2) exits of four feet (4') or
more in width shall not be used for such purpose. (1976 Code §
3-5-4)
3-4F-5: IMPROPER CONDUCT PROHIBITED:
No person shall indulge in or permit any improper or immoral conduct at any
public dance. (1976 Code §
3-5-5)
3-4F-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (1992 Code)
ARTICLE G. COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES; TABLE GAMES 1
SECTION:
3-4G-1: Table Games; Amusement Devices
3-4G-2: Coin-Operated Amusement Devices
3-4G-3: Restrictions in Businesses and Public Places
 
Notes
1 1. See also Article A of this Chapter for pool halls.
3-4G-1: TABLE GAMES; AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
   A.   License Required; Definition: No person shall maintain or expose for
public use any table game or amusement device operated with a slug or coin or
for the use of which a fee is charged without having first obtained a license
therefor.
As used in this subsection, the term "table game" shall mean and include any
device, whether controlled by skill or chance, for the operation of a game,
pastime or contest by the manipulation of a marble sphere or of objects or
figures or by controlling the movements of the same or setting them in motion
by mechanical means. (1976 Code §
3-1-4)
   B.   License Fee: The annual fee for a table game or amusement device
license shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §
3-1-5)
3-4G-2: COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
   A.   License Required: No person shall maintain or expose for public use any
coin-operated amusement device other than table games without first having
obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code §
3-1-6)
   B.   License Fee: The annual fee for a coin-operated amusement device shall
be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §
3-1-7)
3-4G-3: RESTRICTIONS IN BUSINESSES AND PUBLIC PLACES:
   A.   Definitions: When used in this Section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
    INCIDENTAL TO THE PRIMARY PURPOSE, USE OR FUNCTION OF SAID PLACE: Where
such use either:
   A.   Constitutes not more than five percent (5%) of the floor space of such
place; or
   B.   Where the revenue therefrom comprises not more than ten percent (10%)
of the gross revenues of such place.
   JUKE BOX: Any phonograph, music box, combination motion picture and sound
machine or other instrument or device capable of producing or reproducing any
vocal or instrumental sound which is governed by the deposit of a coin or
token.
   PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT: Any premises wherein any service or merchandise is
offered for sale to the public or any premises used as clubhouse or clubrooms.
   B.   Devices Restricted: It shall be unlawful for any person to set up, keep
or maintain, or permit to be set up, kept or maintained, in any place of
business or place of public resort any coin-operated amusement devices, pinball
machines, table games or other implements, excepting therefrom juke boxes as
herein defined, kept for a similar purpose where such devices constitute the
primary purpose or use in such place and are not incidental to the primary
purpose, use or function of said place. (Ord. 0-38-75, 10-28-75)
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this Section shall be
fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and each
day that such violation exists shall constitute a separate and distinct
offense. (Ord. 0-38-75, 10-28-75; 1992 Code)
ARTICLE H. SIMULATED VIDEO GAMING DEVICES
SECTION:
3-4H-1: Definitions
3-4H-2: Video Gaming Permitted
3-4H-3: Video Gaming Establishment License
3-4H-4: Video Gaming Terminal Permit Sticker
3-4H-5: Regulations Governing Licensed Establishments Operating Video Gaming
Terminals
3-4H-6: Inspection Of Premises
3-4H-7: Revocation/Suspension Of License And Permit Sticker
3-4H-8: Seizure Of Unlawful Video Gaming Terminals
3-4H-9: Push Tax
3-4H-10: Tax Additional
3-4H-11: Registration
3-4H-12: Collection, Payment, and Accounting
3-4H-13: Violation; Penalties
3-4H-99: Penalty
3-4H-1: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   For the purpose of this article the definitions contained in section 5
of the Video Gaming Act ("Act"), 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/5, are
incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth herein. (Ord. O-23-
2012, 11-5-2012)
   B.   Play: Each individual push of the video gaming terminal which initiates
the simulation provided by the video gaming terminal. Play shall not include
the push of individual wager amounts, selection of types of games on the video
gaming terminal or entry of any information or printing of winning receipts.
(Ord. O-16-2021, 10-31-2021)
3-4H-2: VIDEO GAMING PERMITTED:
Subject to the conditions set forth in this article and the Act, video gaming
is permitted at licensed establishments and at licensed veterans establishments
in accordance with the Act. (Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-3: VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE:
In order for an establishment to operate video gaming terminals, the
establishment is required to obtain an annual video gaming establishment
license from the City by submitting a written application, on a form provided
by the City. The burden is upon each establishment to demonstrate its
suitability for licensure. All video gaming establishment licenses issued by
the City shall expire on April 30, following the date of issuance, with an
annual license fee as established in section
3-1A-1 of this title payable in full at the time the application is filed with
the City. A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for a time
period not to exceed one year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as provided
by law, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to
attachment, garnishment, or execution, nor shall it be alienable or
transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered.
(Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-4: VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL PERMIT STICKER:
   A.   In order for a video gaming terminal to be operated at a licensed
veterans establishment, the licensed veterans establishment is required to
obtain an annual video gaming terminal permit sticker from the City for each
video gaming terminal located on its premises by submitting a written
application, on a form provided by the City. Each video gaming terminal permit
sticker issued by the City shall expire on April 30, following the date of
issuance, with an annual fee as established in section
3-1A-1 of this title per video gaming terminal payable in full at the time the
application is filed with the City.
   B.   In order for a video gaming terminal to be operated at a licensed
establishment, the licensed establishment is required to obtain an annual video
gaming terminal permit sticker from the City for each video gaming terminal
located on its premises by submitting a written application, on a form provided
by the City. Each video gaming terminal permit sticker issued by the City shall
expire on April 30, following the date of issuance, with an annual fee as
established in section
3-1A-1 of this title per video gaming terminal payable in full at the time the
application is filed with the City. (Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-5: REGULATIONS GOVERNING LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS OPERATING VIDEO GAMING
TERMINALS:
The following regulations apply to all licensed establishments and licensed
veterans establishments operating a video gaming terminal on its premises with
a valid gaming establishment license and valid video gaming terminal permit
stickers for each video gaming terminal:
   A.   A valid City video gaming establishment license must be clearly
displayed at all times.
   B.   A valid City video gaming terminal permit sticker shall be clearly
displayed at all times on each video gaming terminal. (Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-
2013)
   C.   No more than six (6) video gaming terminals may be located on the
premises of a licensed establishment or a licensed veterans establishment.
(Ord. O-10-2019, 7-15-2019)
   D.   Other than having up to six (6) video gaming terminals with valid video
gaming terminal permit stickers, a licensed establishment or licensed veterans
establishment is prohibited from having, anywhere on its premises, an
electronic video gaming machine that may be available to play or simulate the
play of poker, line up, blackjack, faro, roulette, craps, slots, or any other
card or dice game or other game of chance, or that is otherwise akin to a
gambling or gaming device, even if solely for amusement purposes. (Ord. O-24-
2013, 11-18-2013; amd. Ord. O-10-2019, 7-15-2019)
   E.   All video gaming terminals must be located in an area restricted to
persons twenty one (21) years of age or older. The entrance to such area must,
at all times, be within the view of at least one employee who is at least
twenty one (21) years of age.
   F.   No licensed establishment or licensed veterans establishment may cause
or permit any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to use, play or
operate a video gaming terminal.
   G.   No video gaming terminal may be played except during the legal hours of
operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed
establishment or licensed veterans establishment pursuant to the applicable
provisions of this Code.
   H.   Licensed establishments and licensed veterans establishments shall
fully comply with the Act and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed
by the Illinois Gaming Board. (Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-6: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Every licensed establishment and licensed veterans establishment where a video
gaming terminal is kept shall be subject to inspection by the City, at any
time, to ensure compliance with this Code. This includes licensed
establishments and licensed veterans establishments applying for a video gaming
establishment license and/or video gaming terminal permit stickers. It shall be
unlawful for any person to hinder, resist, oppose or attempt to hinder, resist
or oppose the City in the course of an inspection. (Ord. O-24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-7: REVOCATION/SUSPENSION OF LICENSE AND PERMIT STICKER:
The City may revoke or suspend any video gaming license and any video gaming
terminal permit sticker issued by the City if it determines that a licensed
establishment or licensed veterans establishment has violated any of the
provisions of this article. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any licensed
establishment or licensed veterans establishment that has its liquor license
revoked or suspended by the City or by the Illinois State Liquor Commission, or
has its video gaming license revoked or suspended by the Illinois Gaming Board,
shall automatically and without a hearing by the City, have its City video
gaming establishment license and all City video gaming terminal permit stickers
revoked or suspended for the same time frame as its liquor and/or Illinois
Gaming Board gaming license is suspended, whichever the case may be. (Ord. O-
24-2013, 11-18-2013)
3-4H-8: SEIZURE OF UNLAWFUL VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
Every video gaming terminal that does not have a valid video gaming terminal
permit sticker or is otherwise unlawful shall be considered a gambling device
subject to seizure and shall be turned over to the Illinois Gaming Board, in
accordance with board regulations and applicable law, unless otherwise ordered
by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. O-23-2012, 11-5-2012)
3-4H-9: PUSH TAX:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, an amusement tax is
imposed upon any person who participates in the play of a video gaming terminal
that takes place within the jurisdictional boundaries of the City. The rate of
tax shall be equal to one cent ($0.01) per play on a video gaming terminal.
   B.   The terminal operator of a video gaming terminal may separately itemize
and charge each person who plays a video gaming terminal. (O-16-2021, 10-31-
2021)
3-4H-10: TAX ADDITIONAL:
The tax imposed by this chapter is in addition to all other taxes imposed by
the State of Illinois or the city or any other unit of government. (O-16-2021,
10-31-2021)
3-4H-11: REGISTRATION:
Every terminal operator of a video gaming terminal located in the city shall
apply for registration as a tax collector with the city no later than thirty
(30) days after commencing such business or thirty (30) days after the
effective date of the ordinance imposing the push tax, whichever occurs later.
The application shall be submitted to the city on forms provided by the city
and shall contain such information as reasonably required by the city to
impose, collect, and audit all amounts related to the push tax. (O-16-2021, 10-
31-2021)
3-4H-12: COLLECTION, PAYMENT, AND ACCOUNTING:
   A.   It shall be the joint and several duty of every terminal operator of a
video gaming terminal to secure from each person participating in the play of a
video gaming terminal the push tax imposed by this chapter. For purposes of
this chapter, it shall be presumed that the amount of the push tax imposed on
each person, unless the taxpayer or tax collector proves otherwise with books,
records, or other documentary evidence, has been collected from the person by
the terminal operator. Push tax payments accompanied by tax returns prescribed
by the city shall be remitted to the city on or before the 20th day of the
month following the month in which payment of the push tax is made.
   B.   Every terminal operator of a video gaming terminal who is required to
collect the push tax by this chapter shall be considered a tax collector for
the city. All push tax amounts collected shall be held by the terminal operator
as trustee for and on behalf of the city. The failure of the terminal operator
to collect the tax shall not excuse or release the person from the obligation
to pay the tax. The ultimate incidence of the push tax shall remain on the
person and shall never be shifted to the terminal operator.
   C.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, in order to permit
sound fiscal planning and budgeting by the city, no person shall be entitled to
a refund of, or credit for, the push tax imposed by this chapter unless the
person files a claim for a refund or credit within one (1) year after the date
on which the push tax was remitted to the city.
   D.   The terminal operator of any video gaming terminal shall be subject to
the audit, inspection, and record keeping provisions of this code. It shall be
unlawful for any terminal operator and/or person to prevent, hinder, or
interfere with the city's officials, employees, and/or agents designated to
discharge their respective duties in the performance of their duties and the
enforcement of this chapter. (O-16-2021, 10-31-2021)
3-4H-13: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
   A.   It shall be a violation of this chapter for a terminal operator to fail
to file a tax return described in Section
3-4H-12 within the time prescribed in this chapter.
   B.   A terminal operator who falsely reports or fails to report the amount
of push tax due required by this chapter shall be in violation of chapter and
is subject to suspension and/or revocation of their terminal operator license.
All payments not remitted when due shall be paid together with a penalty
assessment on the unpaid balance at a rate of one and one-half percent (1.5%)
per month.
   C.   Suspension Or Revocation of License: The Mayor or his or her designee
shall have the power to suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke
any video gaming license issued under the provisions of this chapter, or if he/
she determines that a terminal operator shall have violated any of the
provisions of this chapter, any of the statutes of the State or any other valid
ordinance or resolution enacted by the city. However, no such license shall be
revoked or suspended except after the holding of a hearing by the Mayor or his
or her designee. Ten (10) days' notice of the hearing shall be given to the
terminal operator. Alternatively, the terminal operator shall have the
opportunity to engage in a prehearing conference and agree to negotiated
penalties rather than proceed to a hearing. (O-16-2021, 10-31-2021)
3-4H-99: PENALTY:
Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of
not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day any violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense. This monetary penalty shall be
in addition to any and all other remedies which may be available to the City.
(Ord. O-23-2012, 11-5-2012; O-16-2021, 10-31-2021)
ARTICLE I. BINGO
SECTION:
3-4I-1:    Definitions
3-4I-2: License Required
3-4I-3: Application For License
3-4I-4: Issuance Of License; Restrictions
3-4I-5: License Fee; Term; Revocation
3-4I-6: Restrictions On Conduct Of Bingo
 
3-4I-7: Penalties
 
3-4I-1: DEFINITIONS:
The definitions contained in Section 1.1 of the Bingo License and Tax Act
("Act") (230 ILCS 25/1.1) are incorporated herein as though fully set forth
herein. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-2024)
3-4I-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a bingo event without first having obtained licenses
from the State of Illinois and the City. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-2024)
3-4I-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license shall be made, in writing, at the Office of the City
Clerk, not less than thirty (30) days before the intended bingo event on forms
provided by the City Clerk's Office.
Each license and application for license shall contain the following
information:
   A.   The name and address of the applicant;
   B.   A copy of the applicant's articles of incorporation and/or charter;
   C.   The license issued by the State of Illinois; and
   D.   Such other information as the City Council requires. (Ord. O-11-2024,
5-6-2024)
3-4I-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Licenses for bingo events are subject to the limitations that licenses
shall be issued only to bona fide religious, charitable, labor, fraternal,
educational or vet-erans' organizations that operate without profit to their
members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5)
years immediately before making application for a license and have had, during
that entire five (5) year period, bona fide membership engaged in carrying out
the organization's objectives or to a nonprofit fund-raising organization that
the City determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial
assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering
extreme hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster.
   B.   No license shall be issued to:
      1.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-
2024)
3-4I-5: LICENSE FEE; TERM; REVOCATION:
Licenses issued under this Article shall be valid for one year and may be
suspended or revoked for any violation of this Code. The annual license fee
shall be Five Dollars ($5.00). All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each
year. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-2024)
3-4I-6: RESTRICTIONS ON CONDUCT OF BINGO:
The conduct of a bingo event is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds from the bingo event must be exclusively
devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that
game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member or employee of the sponsoring
organization may participate in the management or operation of a bingo event.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the bingo event.
   D.   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded in any
single day of bingo may not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00). The prize awarded for any one game shall not exceed five hundred
dollars ($500.00) cash or its equivalent.
   E.   The number of games, including regular and special games, may not
exceed twenty-five (25) in any one day.
   F.   The price paid for a single bingo card under the license may not exceed
One Dollar ($1.00) and such card is valid for regular games on that day of
bingo.
   G.   The number of bingo days conducted by a licensee is limited to one (1)
per week.
   H.   A licensee may rent premises on which to conduct a bingo event only
from an organization which is also licensed as a provider of premises or exempt
from licensing requirements under the Act.
   I.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may play or participate
in the conducting of a bingo event. Any person under the age of eighteen (18)
years may be within the area where bingo is being played only when accompanied
by a parent or guardian.
   J.   The promoter of the bingo event may not have a proprietary interest in
the bingo event. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-2024)
3-4I-7: PENALTIES:
Any violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine of not less than
One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) nor more than One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.00).
Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate and distinct
offense. (Ord. O-11-2024, 5-6-2024)
CHAPTER 5
SOLICITATION
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definitions
3-5-2: Permit Required
3-5-3: Prohibition Of Solicitation At Certain Times And In Certain Places
3-5-4: Soliciting From Occupants Of Vehicles
3-5-5: Commercial Solicitation Permit
3-5-6: Appeal
3-5-7: Violation
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
APPLICANT: Any person or entity that has filed an application for a commercial
solicitation permit as hereinafter provided.
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: As that same term is defined in 225 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 460/1, or a not for profit organization incorporated pursuant to 805
Illinois Compiled Statutes 110/0.01 and 110/35, or any other organization that
has been granted tax exempt status from the state of Illinois or the internal
revenue service.
CHARITABLE PURPOSE: Charitable purposes as that same term is defined in 225
Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/1, and as that term is construed by the Illinois
courts under such statute. For the purpose of this chapter, solicitation for a
charitable purpose shall include solicitation for or on behalf of a "charitable
organization", as that term is defined herein.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police of the city of Northlake or his designee.
COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION: Seeking to sell, offer for sale, sell and deliver,
barter, exchange, or obtain, for profit or any kind of consideration whatever;
gifts; contributions of money; and orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description,
insurance, books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers, and every other type of
publication or subscriptions therefor; or distribution to the public, by
leaving the same at stores, offices, residences or on public property in the
city any paper, document or article of a commercial nature including, but not
limited to, cards, circulars, handbills, samples, merchandise or any
advertising matter whatsoever; except when the same is conducted for any
charitable purpose, religious purpose, or political purpose, or on behalf of
any charitable organization.
NONRESIDENTIAL PREMISES: Means and includes all buildings, structures, and
units in the city occupied for nonresidential purposes.
POLITICAL PURPOSE: Any activity in support of bona fide candidates for public
office, or any matter related to the election, nomination, or performance of
public officials, or issues presented to the electorate of any election.
REGISTERED SOLICITOR: Means and includes any person who has obtained a valid
commercial solicitation permit as hereinafter provided.
RESIDENCE: Means and includes every separate living unit in the city occupied
for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
SOLICITATION: Includes any one or more of the following activities:
   A.   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise,
foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description whatever, for any
kind of consideration whatever.
   B.   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of
insurance of any type, kind or character.
   C.   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other type or kind of publication.
   D.   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any
other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any commercial, charitable,
nonprofit or political purpose.
   E.   Distributing pamphlets, handouts or any other material or seeking
signatures in support of any commercial, charitable, nonprofit or political
purpose.
"Solicitation" does not include the actions of any federal, state, local
government employee or public utility employee performing duties for his or her
employer. (Ord. O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
3-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct commercial solicitation within
the city without having first applied for, obtained and maintained a commercial
solicitation permit as hereinafter provided. While conducting commercial
solicitation within the city, a person must carry the permit and display it
upon the request of any law enforcement officer or any individual being
solicited. (Ord. O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
3-5-3: PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION AT CERTAIN TIMES AND IN CERTAIN PLACES:
The following guidelines shall apply to all solicitation within the city,
whether or not the solicitation is for commercial purposes:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon any residence or
nonresidential premises for the purpose of conducting solicitation if such
residence or nonresidential premises is posted with a sign bearing the words
"No Trespassing", "No Peddlers", "No Solicitors", or any other similar notice
indicating in any manner that the occupants of such residence or nonresidential
premises desire not to be molested or to have their rights of privacy
disturbed, unless such occupant has specifically requested such solicitation.
   B.   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, whether licensed pursuant to this chapter or not, to go upon
any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located
thereon or rap or knock upon any door or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in
soliciting prior to ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. or after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
of any day or on a state or national holiday.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person conducting solicitation at any
residence or nonresidential premises to fail to leave, and to fail to cease
conducting solicitation at, such residence or nonresidential premises
immediately upon receiving, from any person present at such residence or
nonresidential premises, a request to leave or cease conducting solicitation.
   D.   It shall be unlawful to use or attempt to use any entrance other than
the front or main entrance to a residence, except by the express invitation of
the resident or occupant of the property.
   E.   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct solicitation in or on
any sidewalk or other public property, way or place in a manner that completely
or substantially impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic in, on or
around such sidewalk or public property, way or place. No person conducting
solicitation shall have the exclusive right to any sidewalk or other public
property, way or place.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person under eighteen (18) years of age to
conduct solicitation within the city without supervision of someone twenty one
(21) years of age or older. Said supervisor must remain in the immediate
vicinity of the minor at all times the minor is engaging in solicitation
activity.
   G.   No person shall perpetrate a fraud or a misrepresentation of any kind
while engaged in solicitation within the city. (Ord. O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
3-5-4: SOLICITING FROM OCCUPANTS OF VEHICLES:
   No person may conduct any type of solicitation from any operator or occupant
of any vehicle traveler upon any street or highway located in the City. (Ord.
O-21-2009, 7-6-2009; amd. Ord. O-04-2025, 3-3-2025)
3-5-5: COMMERCIAL SOLICITATION PERMIT:
   A.   Application: An applicant for a commercial solicitation permit shall
file with the city an application upon the form provided by the city,
accompanied by an application fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per person for the
applicant and for anyone acting on his behalf who will engage in solicitation
activity within the city. The applicant shall verify under oath all statements
made by the applicant upon or in connection with the application. The
application shall be submitted twenty (20) business days prior to the first
date for which the applicant seeks a permit to solicit and shall contain the
following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of person, company or
organization applying for permit.
      2.   Type of soliciting to be employed.
      3.   Solicitation period or dates requested.
      4.   Name, address, telephone number, social security number and driver's
license number of applicant.
      5.   Name, address, telephone number, social security number and driver's
license number of the person or persons supervising the solicitation activity.
      6.   Name, address, telephone number, social security number and driver's
license number of each person to be engaged in solicitation.
      7.   Year, make, and license plate number of any vehicle used in
soliciting activity.
      8.   State whether or not the applicant, or any person soliciting on
applicant's behalf pursuant to the permit applied for hereunder, has ever been
convicted of a violation of any ordinance or any municipality regulating
soliciting; if the answer is affirmative, identify such person, municipality
and furnish all details relating to such conviction.
      9.   State whether or not the applicant, or any person soliciting on
applicant's behalf pursuant to the permit applied for hereunder has ever been
convicted of a felony; if answer is affirmative, identify such person and
furnish a certified copy of the judgment of conviction.
      10.   For applicant and each person soliciting on applicant's behalf,
state a physical description, including sex, height, weight, hair color and eye
color, and submit two (2) copies of a photograph showing the person's full
facial features.
      11.   The undersigned being first duly sworn on oath states that the
answers and statements in the aforesaid application for permit to solicit are
true.
(Signature of Applicant)
(Position of person signing application)
Subscribed and sworn to before me this          day of              ,
20        .
Notary Public
   B.   Background Investigation: A criminal background investigation,
including a check of fingerprints, shall be conducted upon all applicants and
on those supervising and/or soliciting on the applicant's behalf. The city may
deny any application based upon the results of the background investigation. No
permit shall be issued until the results of the background investigation are
received by the Northlake police department.
   C.   Change In Information: If, during the pendency of any application for,
or during the term of, any commercial solicitation permit, there is any change
in any material information given in the application for such permit, the
applicant shall promptly notify the police chief in writing of such change.
   D.   Issuance Or Denial: The police chief may deny an application for a
commercial solicitation permit:
      1.   Pursuant to information obtained from the application pursuant to
subsection A8 or A9 of this section, or information obtained from the
background investigation conducted pursuant to subsection B of this section;
      2.   If any portion of the application contains false information;
      3.   If the applicant or anyone soliciting on his behalf has had a
previously issued commercial solicitation permit revoked by the city within
three (3) years of the date of the application; or
      4.   If the applicant or anyone soliciting on his behalf has been
convicted of violating any provisions of this chapter within three (3) years of
the date of the application.
If the application for a permit is denied, the police chief shall give written
notification of such denial to the applicant. Such notice shall be delivered in
person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to the applicant's current residence
address set forth in the application.
If the police chief determines and finds that the application should be
approved, the police chief shall issue the permit within ten (10) business days
of receiving the application results of the background investigation of the
applicant or anyone soliciting on behalf of the applicant. The solicitation
permit is nontransferable, and duplication of the solicitation permit is
prohibited.
   E.   Photo IDs: If the application is approved, the city police department
or the city will issue photo IDs for the applicant and those listed on the
application who are soliciting on his behalf. Such identification must be worn
at all times the individual is conducting solicitation within the city. Upon
completion of solicitation activity within the city, the photo IDs must be
immediately returned to the city police department. Failure to return a photo
ID shall result in a fifty dollar ($50.00) fine.
   F.   Application Record: The police chief shall cause to be kept in his
office an accurate record of every commercial solicitation permit application
received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining
thereto, including commercial solicitation permits issued or denied under the
provisions of this section.
   G.   Revocation: The police chief may revoke any commercial solicitation
permit if, after the issuance of such permit, he determines and finds that:
      1.   The registered solicitor made a false material statement in the
application for such commercial solicitation permit; or
      2.   The registered solicitor, or anyone soliciting on his behalf, has
violated any other provisions of this chapter; or
      3.   The registered solicitor, or anyone soliciting on his behalf, has
violated any local ordinance or state or federal law while engaging in
solicitation activity within the city.
The police chief shall give a registered solicitor written notice immediately
upon such revocation of the registered solicitor's commercial solicitation
permit. Such notice shall be delivered in person or by certified U.S. mail
addressed to the registered solicitor's current residence address set forth in
the application. Revocation shall be effective immediately upon delivery of
such notice.
   H.   Effective Period: A commercial solicitation permit shall be valid for a
consecutive period of time not to exceed thirty (30) calendar days. The
expiration date shall be expressly stated on the face of each commercial
solicitation permit. Upon completion of solicitation activity within the city,
the solicitation permit must be immediately returned to the city police
department. Failure to return a solicitation permit shall result in a fifty
dollar ($50.00) fine. (Ord. O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
3-5-6: APPEAL:
Any person aggrieved by the police chief's denial or revocation of a
solicitation permit shall have a right to appeal such decision to the mayor of
the city of Northlake as provided in this section. Within ten (10) days after
receipt of the police chief's notice of denial or revocation, the applicant or
permit holder may make a written request for a hearing regarding the denial or
revocation. After receipt of such written request, the mayor shall set a date
and time for the hearing within ten (10) days of receipt of the request. The
mayor shall give written notice of such hearing to the applicant or permit
holder postmarked or delivered at least five (5) days in advance of the hearing
date. At the hearing, the applicant or permit holder may present and submit
evidence and witnesses to rebut the reasons cited by the police chief for
revoking or denying the permit. Within five (5) days after the close of the
hearing, the mayor shall issue a written decision. The mayor may reinstate a
revoked permit, grant the requested permit or a renewal thereof, or affirm the
police chief's decision. The decision of the mayor is final. Any challenge or
appeal of the decision of the mayor shall be governed by the Illinois
administrative review act, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq. (Ord.
O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
3-5-7: VIOLATION:
Any person in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a
fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation
occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense subject to fine.
Additionally, a violation may also be prosecuted as a public nuisance or as any
other applicable statutory violation. (Ord. O-21-2009, 7-6-2009)
CHAPTER 6
FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Rules And Regulations Adopted
3-6-2: Inspection Fees
3-6-3: Posting
3-6-4: Violation; Penalties
3-6-1: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The issuance, suspension and revocation of permits to operate retail food
establishments, the prohibiting of the sale of unsound or mislabeled food or
drink and the enforcement of this chapter shall be regulated in accordance with
chapter 10, compliance procedures, of the 1976 and subsequent editions of the
food and drug administration "Food Service Sanitation Ordinance", except
sections 10-601 and 10-602, and defining regulatory authority to mean the Cook
County department of public health as the authorized agent of the city
department of health and inspectional services.
The inspection of food service establishments shall be regulated in accordance
with the current and subsequent Illinois department of public health "Food
Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations" on file with the Illinois secretary
of state; the inspection of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance
with the current and subsequent Illinois department of public health's "Retail
Food Store Sanitation Rules And Regulations" on file with the Illinois
secretary of state.
Three (3) certified copies of the food and drug administration "Food Service
Sanitation Ordinance" and the Illinois department of public health's "Food
Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations" and "Retail Food Store Sanitation
Rules And Regulations" shall be on file at the office of the city clerk. (Ord.
O-32-89, 8-21-1989; amd. 1992 Code)
3-6-2: INSPECTION FEES:
Each food service establishment and retail food store which is inspected or
reinspected by the department pursuant to the intergovernmental agreement for
the provision of environmental health inspection service shall pay a fee of
seventy dollars ($70.00) to the city at the time of said inspection and
reinspection. (Ord. O-24-2001, 12-17-2001)
3-6-3: POSTING:
All licensees shall be required to post on or near the entrances to the
licensed premises a decal or placard to be provided by the city stating the
licensee's health department scores. (Ord. O-16-2013, 8-5-2013)
3-6-4: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty
of a class C misdemeanor as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). In addition thereto, such persons may be enjoined from
continuing such violations. Each day upon which such a violation occurs
constitutes a separate violation. (Ord. O-32-89, 8-21-1989; amd. Ord. O-01-
2005, 2-7-2005, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2005)
CHAPTER 7
MOTOR VEHICLES – RELATED BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A. TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-7A-1: Definitions
3-7A-2: Taxicab Business License Provisions
3-7A-3: Taximeters
3-7A-4: Taxicab Fares
3-7A-5: Taxicab Drivers
3-7A-6: Operation Of Taxicabs
3-7A-7: Parking In, Use Of Taxicab Stands
3-7A-8: Vehicle Requirements
3-7A-9: Disposition Of Material Left In Taxicabs
3-7A-10: Enforcement
3-7A-11: Penalties
3-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases shall have the meanings and are hereby defined
as follows:
OWNER: Every person having the use or control of one or more taxicabs as
defined in this section.
TAXICAB: All public vehicles driven by mechanical power and used for the
carriage of persons for hire, except those vehicles commonly known as buses.
TAXIMETER: An instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is
calculated either for distance traveled or for waiting time or for both and
upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of figures. (Ord. O-61-89,
12-18-1989; amd. 1992 Code)
3-7A-2: TAXICAB BUSINESS LICENSE PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required; Term: No taxicab shall pick up passengers in the city
unless there shall first have been obtained therefor a taxicab license from the
city clerk. Such taxicab license shall be issued annually, May 1 in each and
every year, and should be valid to and including April 30 next succeeding and
shall be effective for such period of time unless sooner suspended or revoked.
   B.   Application For License; Issuance: Applications for taxicab licenses
shall be made to the city clerk by the owner thereof upon blank forms to be
furnished by the city clerk, and such application shall contain the full name
and address of the owner or operator, a list containing the class of the
vehicles for which the license is desired, the length of time the vehicles have
been in use, the number of persons each vehicle is capable of carrying and the
motor power thereof. Such application shall thereupon be referred by the City
Clerk to the Director of Health and Inspectional Services. Upon approval of the
application by the Director of Health and Inspectional Services, he shall so
endorse such application and file the same with the City Clerk who shall, upon
payment of the fee prescribed by this Code, 1  issue the license, complying
with subsection F of this Section.
   C.   Determination of Necessity of Taxicab Service; Hearing:
      1.   No taxicab license shall be issued under this Chapter unless the
City Council, after a hearing, shall, by resolution, declare and determine that
public convenience and necessity require the proposed taxicab service for which
application for a license is made; provided, that such declaration of public
convenience and necessity shall not be necessary:
         a.   For the licensing of the same number of taxicabs licensed for
operation and operated by the applicant under the same name and colors for
which a license was issued previously or the renewal of the license annually
thereafter; or
         b.   For the renewal of a license to the applicant for the number of
taxicabs of the applicant for which the City Council shall have at any time
prior to the date of application for such renewal made a declaration of public
convenience and necessity.
      2.   In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the
licensing of such taxicabs for which application may be made, the City Council
shall take into consideration:
         a.   Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require
such proposed or such additional taxicab service within the City;
         b.   The financial responsibility of the applicant;
         c.   The number, kind and type of equipment;
         d.   The schedule of maximum rates proposed to be charged;
         e.   The color scheme to be used by the applicant;
         f.   The increased traffic congestion and demand for increased parking
spaces on the streets of the City which may result;
         g.   Whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular
and pedestrian, will be preserved by the granting of such additional license;
and
         h.   Such other relevant facts as the City Council may deem advisable
or necessary.
      3.   If the City Council finds from the investigation and hearing that
the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the taxicab for
which license is desired, it shall notify the applicant of its finding. Within
sixty (60) days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish to the City Council any
and all additional information which may be required, and if the City Council
then finds that the applicant is the owner and bona fide operator of the
vehicle for which the license is desired and that such vehicle complies with
all of the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the City, the
license shall thereupon be issued to the applicant upon the payment of the
proper license fee. 2
If the City Council finds from such investigation and hearing that the public
convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the vehicle for which
the license is desired, it shall forthwith notify the applicant of such
finding.
   D.   Bond or Insurance Required: No owner shall be licensed to operate a
taxicab until he has complied with the State law pertaining to a surety bond or
liability insurance coverage and filed a copy of such surety bond or liability
insurance with the City Clerk.
   E.   Certification Decals: All taxicabs licensed by the City as provided in
subsection B of this Section shall be issued quarterly decals which shall
contain a number assigned to the taxicab, together with the date of the most
recent inspection. Such decal shall contain a space upon which an entry shall
be made of the date of inspection of the taxicab by the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services or an inspector appointed by him. Certification decals
shall be of a distinctly different color each quarter and shall be affixed to
the lower right-hand corner of the windshield of each taxicab.
   F.   Register of Licenses: The City Clerk shall keep a register of the name
and address of each person owning or operating a taxicab licensed under this
Chapter, together with the decal number and the description, make and necessary
dimensions of such taxicab, with the date and complete record of inspections
made of it. Such records shall be open to the inspection of the public at all
reasonable times, and shall be public records, extracts of which may be
certified for use as evidence by the City Clerk.
   G.   Revocation or Suspension of License: Any taxicab license shall be
