subject to suspension or revocation upon conviction of the holder thereof for
any violation of this Chapter. The City Council may, at its discretion, suspend
or revoke a license granted upon any provision of this Chapter pending or in
advance of the criminal prosecution of the licensee, after notice and hearing.
(Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1A-1 of this Title.
2 1. See Section
  3-1A-1 of this Title.
3-7A-3: TAXIMETERS:
   A.   Taximeter Required: Each taxicab must have a taximeter affixed thereto
and in good working order.
   B.   Inspections and Tests:
      1.   No taxicab license shall be issued for any taxicab until the
taximeter attached thereto shall have been inspected as provided by this
Section and found to be accurate, and no person shall drive a taxicab to which
is attached a taximeter that has not been duly inspected and approved.
      2.   Authority to Make Inspections: Before any license shall be issued to
a taxicab, it shall be the duty of the Director of Health and Inspectional
Services to examine and inspect the taximeter attached thereto and report its
condition to the City Clerk. At least once, annually, said Director of Health
and Inspectional Services shall in like manner examine, inspect and seal all
taximeters used in vehicles licensed in the City; provided, however, that in
the event complaint is made to the Director of Health and Inspectional Services
that any taximeter registers improperly or inaccurately, then it shall be the
duty of the Director to examine and inspect such taximeter complained of. If
such taximeter does not comply with the requirements of subsection C of this
Section then, and in that event, it shall be unlawful for the owner or person
in charge of such taxicab to permit its use until such taxicab is equipped with
a taximeter approved by the Director.
      3.   Tests:
         a.   Every taximeter shall be tested by running the taxicab to which
it is attached over a course of a standard mile in length or by a mechanical
test to prove the accuracy of the register thereof. Either of the foregoing
tests may be made in the discretion of the Director of Health and Inspectional
Services.
         b.   In order to determine whether such taximeter correctly registers
"waiting time", it shall be the duty of the Director of Health and Inspectional
Services to test such taximeter by comparing the time recorded as shown by the
fare computed on the dial thereof with the standard time.
         c.   It shall be the duty of any person owning, controlling or
operating a taxicab to deliver either the taxicab, together with the taximeter,
or the taximeter detached therefrom, to the Director of Health and Inspectional
Services or any of his deputies for the purpose of making the aforesaid test
upon demand; provided, however, such person may, if desired, be present at the
time such test is made.
      4.   Sealing Taximeters; Records Kept: It shall be the duty of the
Director of Health and Inspectional Services to seal all taximeters found
accurate and correct and to keep a record of the numbers of each taximeter and
the date of the inspection thereof in the books of his office.
      5.   Inspection Fees: The fee to be charged for the annual inspection of
each taximeter is hereby fixed at the sum of five dollars ($5.00). No charge
shall be made for additional inspections unless the taximeter registers
incorrectly or inaccurately, in which case an additional inspection fee of five
dollars ($5.00) shall be charged.
   C.   General Requirements:
      1.   The dial of every taximeter with which every taxicab shall be
equipped shall show but one tariff. Such taximeter shall also properly and
accurately register, indicate and display the distance traveled and the amount
of fare to be determined and charged therefor.
      2.   Each taximeter shall be equipped with a flag at least three inches
by two inches (3" x 2") in size, either painted red or bearing thereon in
letters at least one inch (1") in height, the word "Vacant" or the words "For
Hire". The flag post of such flag shall be kept up or towards a vertical
position when the taxicab is for hire, and when such taxicab is engaged in the
service of a passenger or passengers, such flag post shall be kept down or in a
horizontal position.
      3.   Each taxicab shall, during the period between sunset and sunrise, be
equipped with a light which shall be so reflected upon the dial of the
taximeter as to enable the passenger engaging and using such taxicab to read
the figures indicated thereon.
      4.   Every taximeter placed on a taxicab shall be so arranged that the
dial thereof is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such taxicab or
upon alighting from the same.
   D.   Transferring Taximeters: No person shall detach any certified or
inspected taximeter from any taxicab and attach the same to any other taxicab,
the front wheels of which are of different diameter from those with reference
to which the taximeter was originally tested unless a new inspection or
certification is had on such taximeter.
   E.   False Signals: No driver of a taxicab equipped with a taximeter, while
carrying a passenger or under employment, shall display the signal affixed to
such taximeter or other similar device in such a position as to denote that he
is employed at a rate of fare different from that to which he is entitled under
the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-4: TAXICAB FARES:
   A.   Rates of Fares; Rate Card Required: No person owning, operating or
controlling any taxicab within the limits of the City shall charge to exceed
the following rates to be determined by the taximeter:
 
For the first 1/6 mile or fraction thereof, for one person:            $1.00
For each succeeding 1/6 mile or fraction thereof:                      .20
For each additional person over 12 years of age for the whole journey: .50
For each minute of waiting time or fraction thereof:                   .20
 
Waiting time shall include the time when the taxicab is not in motion,
beginning with the arrival at the place to which it had been called, or the
time consumed while standing at the direction of the passenger or time consumed
while standing because of conditions beyond control of the operator, but no
charge shall be made for time lost for inefficiency of the taxicab or its
operator or time consumed by premature response to a call.
   B.   Rate Card Displayed: Every taxicab operated under this Chapter shall
have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such a
place as to be in view of all passengers.
   C.   Multiple Passengers: A licensed taxicab company may provide for
multiple passengers and shared rides; provided, that the passengers are advised
when ordering a cab that the ride will be shared. Group rates for shared rides
will be established by the taxi company; provided, the rate for the group does
not exceed the rate that would have been applicable under subsection A of this
Section to one passenger multiplied by the number of persons in the group.
   D.   Receipt for Fare Paid: If demanded by the passenger, the driver in
charge of a taxicab shall deliver to the person paying for the hiring of the
same, at the time of such payment, a receipt therefor in legible type or
writing containing the name of the owner or operator, the City decal number or
the driver's City license number or the taximeter number and any items for
which a charge is made, the total amount paid and the date of payment.
   E.   Prepayment of Fare; Duty of Drivers to Convey Orderly Persons: Every
driver of a taxicab shall have the right to demand payment of the legal fare in
advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid, but no driver of a taxicab
shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person upon request
anywhere in the City unless previously engaged or unable to do so.
   F.   Overcharging Prohibited: No driver of any taxicab shall charge or
attempt to charge any passenger a greater fare than that to which such driver
is entitled under the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-5: TAXICAB DRIVERS:
   A.   License Required; Qualifications: Every person driving a taxicab must
be licensed by the City as a taxicab driver.
   B.   Application of License; Affidavit; Photographs Generally: Any person
desiring to secure a City taxicab driver's license shall make application in
writing therefor to the City Clerk upon a form to be provided by the City
Clerk. Such application shall set forth the name of the applicant, his
residence and occupation and shall be endorsed by at least two (2) responsible
citizens who shall certify that the applicant is a person of good habits,
honest, sober and industrious and a fit person to drive or operate a taxicab.
Along with such application, the applicant shall file an affidavit stating the
applicant's full name, residence, places of residence during the previous five
(5) years, age, sex, race, height, color of eyes and hair, place of birth,
whether a citizen of the United States, places of previous employment, whether
he has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, whether he has
previously been licensed as a driver or chauffeur and if so, whether his
license has ever been revoked and for what cause, which affidavit shall be
filed with the City Clerk as a permanent record.
Such applicant shall also file with the application to the City Clerk two (2)
recent photographs of himself of a size which may be easily attached to the
license, one of which shall be attached to the license when issued and the
other shall be filed with the application in the office of the City Clerk.
Each applicant for a taxicab drivers license must:
      1.   Be of the age of eighteen (18) years or over;
      2.   Be of sound physique with good eyesight and not subject to epilepsy,
vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might
render such applicant unfit for the safe operation of a taxicab;
      3.   Be able to read, write and speak the English language;
      4.   Be clean in dress and person and not be addicted to the use of
narcotics or intoxicating liquors.
   C.   Investigation and Examination of Applicant; Issuance or Refusal of
License:
      1.   The application, affidavit and photographs referred to in subsection
B of this Section shall be referred to the Director of Inspectional Services
who shall investigate the qualifications and the physical and mental condition
of the applicant.
      2.   Each applicant for a City taxicab driver's license under the
provisions of this Chapter shall be examined by the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services or some person by him designated as to the applicant's
knowledge of the provisions of this Chapter, the traffic regulations and the
geography of the City.
      3.   If the results of the examinations be unsatisfactory, the applicant
shall be refused a license. If the Director of Health and Inspectional Services
shall approve the application he shall endorse thereon such approval and return
the same together with the affidavit and photographs to the City Clerk, who
shall forthwith issue such license.
   D.   Date of Issuance; Expiration: Taxicab drivers' licenses shall be issued
as of May 1 or as of the date of initial application in each and every year and
shall be valid to and including April 30 next succeeding.
   E.   Contents of License:
      1.   Taxicab drivers' licenses shall be in such form as to contain the
signature of the licensee and blank spaces upon which a record may be made of
any arrest of or serious complaint against him.
      2.   All taxicab drivers' licenses shall be numbered when issued.
      3.   The taxicab drivers' license issued by the City Clerk shall have
attached thereto one of the photographs of the driver previously deposited with
that office, as provided in subsection B of this Section, in such manner that
it cannot be removed and another photograph substituted without detection.
   F.   Renewal of License: The City Clerk may renew a taxicab driver's license
from year to year by appropriate endorsement thereon. A taxicab driver, in
applying for a renewal of his taxicab driver's license, shall make an
application upon a form to be furnished by the City Clerk entitled "Application
for Renewal of License" which shall be filled out with the full name and
address of the applicant, together with a statement of the date upon which his
original license was granted and the number thereof.
   G.   Conditions of License:
      1.   License to be Posted: Each licensed driver shall, while operating a
taxicab, display this license in a prominent place.
      2.   Defacing Licenses Prohibited: No holder of a taxicab driver's City
license shall deface, remove or obliterate any official entry made upon said
license.
      3.   Drivers to Report Changes of Residence: If any person licensed as a
taxicab driver under this Chapter shall change residence at any time while his
license is in force, the driver shall forthwith notify the City Clerk.
   H.   Suspension and Revocation of License: A taxicab driver's license may be
suspended or revoked at any time for violation of the provisions of this
Chapter or other cause after notice and hearing as provided in this Code. The
Director of Health and Inspectional Services may suspend such license for ten
(10) days pending final action by the City Council. Any such suspension shall
be noted on the license, together with a statement of the reasons therefor, and
the driver shall be deprived of his license by the officer suspending or
revoking such license. No driver whose license has been revoked shall again be
licensed as a taxicab driver in the City unless upon presentation of reasons
satisfactory to the City Council. The City Clerk shall notify the Police
Department when any such license is revoked.
   I.   License Records: There shall be kept in the office of the City Clerk a
complete record of each taxicab driver's City license issued and of all
renewals, suspensions or revocations thereof. The City Clerk's record shall be
kept on file with the original application by the driver for a license. (Ord.
0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-6: OPERATION OF TAXICABS:
   A.   Duty of Owners to Furnish Service; Abandonment of Service: The
applicant shall operate his licensed vehicle or vehicles during each day of the
licensed year to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demand of
such service.
Upon complete abandonment of such service for the period of ten (10)
consecutive days by the owner or operator of such service, the Director of
Health and Inspectional Services, upon hearing, after five (5) days' notice to
such owner or operator, shall thereupon recommend to the City Council that the
license of such owner or operator shall be revoked, covering all licensed
vehicles of such owner or operator.
   B.   Carrying Additional Passengers: No driver of a taxicab licensed under
this Chapter shall carry any person other than the first passenger first
employing the taxicab without the consent of the first passenger.
   C.   Cruising Streets Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the driver of any
taxicab to seek employment by repeatedly and persistently driving his taxicab
about the streets of the City or otherwise interfering with the proper and
orderly access to or egress from any theater, hall, hotel, public resort,
railway station or other place of public gathering. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-7: PARKING IN, USE OF TAXICAB STANDS: 1
   A.   Taxicabs:
      1.   Only taxicabs in such numbers and of such kinds as are set forth on
the required metal sign may remain at the stand while waiting for employment
and only in single file pointed in accordance with the traffic regulations. No
taxicab standing at the head of any such line shall refuse to carry any orderly
person applying for a taxicab who agrees to pay the proper fare, but this shall
not prevent any person from electing any taxicab he may desire on the stand,
whether it be at the head of the line or not. As the taxicabs leave the line
with passenger, those behind shall move up, and any taxicab seeking a space on
the stand shall approach the same only from the rear of the stand and shall
stop as near as possible to the last cab already on the line.
      2.   No taxicab shall stand at the curb within fifteen feet (15') of the
entrance of any building adjacent to a taxicab stand located and designed by
the City Council, which distance shall be determined by measuring fifteen feet
(15') on each side of the point of the curb opposite the middle of the entrance
to the adjacent building.
   B.   Private Vehicles: No private vehicle shall be permitted to stand or use
the space in a public stand except to receive or to discharge passengers or
merchandise. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Section
  6-3-4 of this Code.
3-7A-8:VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Age and Condition of Vehicles; Inspections:
      1.   No vehicle shall be licensed as a taxicab, whether upon new
application or renewal, unless it is less than four (4) years old or until it
has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined and found to be in a
thoroughly safe condition for the transportation of passengers, clean, fit, of
good appearance and well painted.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the owner of each taxicab to submit to the
Director of Health and Inspectional Services each taxicab for inspection prior
to the issuance of the license and at least once every three (3) months
thereafter, or at any time upon complaint.
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall make or have made by his
inspectors or a qualified automobile mechanic such examination and inspection
before a license shall be issued.
   B.   Taxicab Colors and Name: No taxicab license shall be issued under the
provisions of this Chapter to any person having the name or colors of his
taxicab similar to that of any other person having a taxicab license within the
corporate limits of the City. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-9: DISPOSITION OF MATERIAL LEFT IN TAXICABS:
Whenever any package or article of baggage or goods of any kind shall be left
in or on any taxicab or shall be left in the custody of the driver thereof, the
driver of the taxicab shall, upon the discovery of such package or article,
forthwith deliver the same to the police station of the City, unless such
package or article shall be sooner delivered to the owner thereof or upon the
order of such owner. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89)
3-7A-10: ENFORCEMENT:
The licensing and inspecting of taxicabs, the examining of applicants for
licenses to drive such taxicabs, the licensing of drivers and enforcing of the
provisions of this Chapter shall be under the control of the Director of Health
and Inspectional Services.
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall require that all
taxicabs are kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use. (Ord. 0-
61-89, 12-18-89; 1992 Code)
3-7A-11: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition to such fine, any
license issued pursuant to this Chapter may be suspended or revoked as provided
in this Code. (Ord. 0-61-89, 12-18-89; 1992 Code)
ARTICLE B. GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS
SECTION:
3-7B-1: Definition
3-7B-2: License Required
3-7B-3: Application for License; Fee
3-7B-4: Nontransferability of License
3-7B-5: Change of Location
3-7B-6: Fire Prevention Regulations; Inspections
3-7B-7: Exemptions from Provisions
3-7B-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, "gasoline service station" shall mean any building, structure,
premises, enclosure or other place within the City where a container or
containers, tank or tanks, either portable or stationary, and containing either
carbon bisulfate, gasoline, naphtha, benzol, hydrocarbon (gas drips), liquefied
petroleum gas, kerosene, turpentine or other flammable liquids, having a flash
point below one hundred eighty seven degrees (187°) Fahrenheit, are kept or
located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale or distributing any such
liquids from containers, tank or tanks. (1976 Code §6-12-1)
3-7B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall manage, conduct, operate or carry on the business of a gasoline
service station without first having obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code
§6-12-2)
3-7B-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license for the business of managing, conducting,
operating or carrying on a gasoline service station shall conform to the
general provisions of this Code relating to applications for license 1  and
shall specify the location of the building, structure, premises, enclosure or
other place in which it is proposed to keep such filling station and the
capacity or capacities, in gallons, of the container or containers, tank or
tanks. Every such application shall be approved by the Chief of Police and the
Fire Marshal before a license shall be issued. (1976 Code §6-12-3)
The annual license fee for a gasoline service station shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-2 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-12-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-7B-4: NONTRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE:
No license granted under the provisions of this Article shall be assigned or
transferred to any person other than the licensee named therein to do business
or act under such license. (1976 Code §6-12-6)
3-7B-5: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
If any person licensed under the provisions of this Article shall, before the
expiration of such license, desire to change the location of the business
conducted thereunder, the licensee shall notify the City Clerk and shall
furnish all of the information which is required to be furnished on an original
application for license. Every such application for a change of location shall
be approved by the Chief of Police and the Fire Marshal before a change of
location shall be authorized. (1976 Code §6-12-8)
3-7B-6: FIRE PREVENTION REGULATIONS; INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Generally: All gasoline service stations shall be conducted and
maintained in accordance with the provisions of this Code with regard to fire
prevention and storage of flammable liquids 1  and shall be inspected by the
Fire Marshal or his duly authorized representative at least once every year.
(1976 Code §6-12-7)
   B.   Smoking Prohibited: No person shall permit smoking in any gasoline
service station. (1976 Code §6-12-9)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection
  8-1D-2A of this Code.
3-7B-7: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this Article shall not apply to any place where flammable
liquids are kept or sold for medicinal purposes only. (1976 Code §6-12-10)
ARTICLE C. PUBLIC PARKING LOTS AND GARAGES
SECTION:
3-7C-1: Definitions
3-7C-2: License Required
3-7C-3: Application for License
3-7C-4: License Fee
3-7C-5: Bond or Insurance Required
3-7C-6: Rates and Charges
3-7C-7: Signs
3-7C-8: Building and Premises Requirements
3-7C-9: Operation of Parking Lots and Garages
3-7C-10: Notice of Lost, Damaged or Unclaimed Property
3-7C-11: Prohibited Acts and Conditions
3-7C-12: Inspections
3-7C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
PARKING LOT: Means and includes any premises, enclosures or other places (other
than a licensed public garage) where four (4) or more automobiles may be stored
or parked and where rent or compensation is paid to the owner, manager or
lessee of such premises for the storing or parking of such vehicles.
PUBLIC GARAGE: Any premises used for housing or caring of more than four (4)
motor-driven vehicles or where any such vehicles are equipped for operation,
repaired or kept for remuneration, hire or sale, not including exhibition or
showrooms for model cars. (1976 Code §6-28-1)
3-7C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No per son shall operate or maintain a parking lot or public garage in the City
without first having obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-28-2)
3-7C-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a parking lot or public garage license shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications
for licenses 1  and shall set forth the following:
   A.   If a person, the name and address of the applicant;
   B.   If a partnership, the name, residence and business address of each
partner;
   C.   If a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such
corporation was organized, and if a foreign corporation, whether authorized to
do business in the State, the names of the principal officers, directors and
local representatives, their residences and business addresses;
   D.   A plot or drawing of the parking lot or garage, showing:
      1.   The location, size and capacity;
      2.   The location and size of entrance and exit;
      3.   The kind of floor or ground surface;
      4.   The location, size and construction of attendant's station; and
      5.   The wall or barriers surrounding said premises.
   E.   The hours for storage or parking of the vehicles and whether night
storage is to be maintained upon the premises;
   F.   The hours during which parking attendants will be on duty;
   G.   A complete schedule of the rates to be charged for storing or parking
of vehicles; and
   H.   Such other information as the City Clerk may deem necessary. (1976 Code
§6-28-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-7C-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a parking lot or public garage license shall be as provided
in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. The maintenance fee for commercial driveways need not be
paid when the driveway is for a licensed parking lot. (1976 Code §6-28-5)
3-7C-5: BOND OR INSURANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Bond: Every application for a license hereunder shall be accompanied by
a bond, approved by the City Attorney, executed by a bonding or surety company
authorized to do business in the State, in the penal sum of five thousand
dollars ($5,000.00) conditioned upon the payment by the licensee of any and all
final judgments for damages resulting to persons or property including the
theft of any motor vehicle or any part or accessory thereof arising out of the
operation or maintenance of any parking lot or garage. Such bond shall run to
the City for the benefit of any person who may claim redress for property
damage or theft resulting from the operation or maintenance of a parking lot or
garage. The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the full period of
time for which the license is effective.
   B.   Insurance: A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company
authorized to do business in the State of Illinois conforming to the
requirements of this Section may be permitted in lieu of a bond. (1976 Code §6-
28-4)
3-7C-6: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Rates and Charges to be Filed with Clerk: Every licensee shall file
with the City Clerk at the time of application for license a complete schedule
of rates and charges to be made for storing or parking motor vehicles on the
premises to be licensed. (1976 Code §6-28-6)
   B.   Day and Night Rates: Where separate rates or charges are made for day
parking and night parking, the night rate shall become effective at six thirty
o'clock (6:30) P.M., and notice thereof shall be posted on the signs described
in Section
3-7C-7 of this Article. (1976 Code §6-28-9)
   C.   Change in Rates: No licensee shall make any charge for storing or
parking any vehicle in a parking lot or garage in excess of that set forth in
his application for a license unless and until he has notified the City Clerk
in writing of the new schedule of rates and posted signs showing such increase
in the same manner as required by this subsection.
Every application for a change in the schedule of rates or charges as filed
under subsection A of this Section shall first be submitted, in writing, to the
City Council which shall hold hearings on such application to determine the
necessity of such change. In making its decision, the City Council shall take
into consideration in each case where application is made, operating and labor
costs, increases in rental or maintenance costs and such other factors as may
reasonably enter into the conduct of the business. If the City Council approves
the proposed change in rates and charges, the schedule as filed shall be
amended. (1976 Code §6-28-7)
3-7C-7: SIGNS:
   A.   Rate and Hour Signs Required: Each licensee shall maintain at each
entrance to its parking lot or garage a permanently affixed sign suitable to
apprise persons using same of the name of the licensee, the hours of the date
or night when such places are open for parking or storing motor vehicles, the
rates charged and the closing hours of such parking lot or garage.
Where more than one rate is charged for parking, the figures for each rate will
be of the same size and dimensions and such figures shall measure not less than
six inches (6") in height, and the letters and figures indicating the closing
hours shall be not less than six inches (6") in height. All such signs shall be
subject to the approval of the Director of Health and Inspectional Services or
his representative. (1976 Code §6-28-8)
   B.   Height Above Sidewalk: All signs shall be erected at a height not less
than eight feet (8') and not more than twelve feet (12') above the sidewalk
level and shall not be erected in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead
or confuse traffic. (1976 Code §6-28-10)
3-7C-8: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Generally: No person shall maintain or operate any public garage in a
frame building or in any building or structure used for school, church or
theater purposes or in any building which does not conform to the requirements
of the Building Code. 1  The premises of every garage must be kept clean and
free from flammable waste material. (1976 Code §6-28-30)
   B.   Entrances and Exits: Each parking lot or garage shall have one common
entrance and one common exit, which may or may not be combined, and the
operator of such parking lot or garage shall keep such entrance and exit
properly attended at all times during the period the parking lot or garage is
in operation. (1976 Code §6-28-14)
   C.   Barrier Requirements in Parking Lots: Except for places of entrance and
exit, every parking lot shall be completely enclosed by barriers constructed
and maintained so as to withstand the shocks and stresses to which they will
normally be subjected by vehicles using the premises and shall be of such
height as to engage the bumper of any motor vehicle on the lot so that no
portion of the vehicles shall extend over the property lines. When the lot
abuts on a building, barriers shall be erected as provided in this subsection
to prevent motor vehicles from striking the building. (1976 Code §6-28-27)
   D.   Maintenance Requirements:
      1.   Sidewalk Maintenance: Every operator of a parking lot or garage
shall keep the sidewalk surrounding the premises free from dirt, ice, sleet and
snow and shall keep the sidewalk and driveways in a safe condition for the
travel of pedestrians.
      2.   Surface Maintenance: The ground or floor space of each parking lot
or garage, if made of dirt, sand, cinders or other loose mixture, shall at all
times be kept thoroughly sprinkled or treated with water, calcium chloride or
other means so that the dust, sand, cinders or other substance of which the
ground or floor space is made will not be raised, carried or blown by the wind,
movement of vehicles or other causes into or upon public property or the
adjacent property of others. The surface or floor of the premises shall be
constructed so as to prevent retention of water thereon. (1976 Code §6-28-15)
   E.   Fire Protection: Every parking lot or garage shall be equipped with
proper fire extinguishing apparatus, subject to the approval of the Fire
Department, and all vehicles shall be parked or stored that they may be reached
readily in case of fire or other emergency. (1976 Code §6-28-22)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 1, Article A of this Code.
3-7C-9: OPERATION OF PARKING LOTS AND GARAGES:
   A.   Refusing Vehicles Prohibited: No licensee shall refuse to park or store
any vehicle for which there shall be accommodation in such parking lot or
garage on tender of the stated fee for such parking lot. (1976 Code §6-28-11)
   B.   Claim Checks; Return of Vehicle: When a vehicle is left for storing or
parking, the licensee of the parking lot or garage, his agent, servant or
employee, shall furnish the owner or operator of the vehicle with a distinctive
claim check which shall have printed thereon the full name and address of the
parking lot or garage, a number corresponding to a coupon placed upon the
vehicle and shall have written or stamped thereon the date and license number
of the motor vehicle. The licensee shall not deliver any vehicle without the
proper claim check being presented, or without satisfactory proof of ownership
of the vehicle.
This subsection shall not apply where vehicles are stored or parked on a weekly
or monthly fee basis. (1976 Code §6-28-12)
   C.   Parking Coupons on License Plates: No person shall affix any parking
coupon upon any vehicle so as to obliterate in whole or in part any portion of
the license plates on such vehicle. (1976 Code §6-28-13)
   D.   Ingress and Egress of Vehicles:
      1.   The loading or unloading of passengers or drivers of vehicles across
or upon a public sidewalk is hereby expressly prohibited, and any operator or
employee who, by receiving or delivering vehicles other than within the
property line of the parking lot or garage, aids and assists in blocking any
sidewalk or street shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this
Article. (1976 Code §6-28-17)
      2.   No person operating a parking lot or garage shall invite or permit
any person to drive into or out of such lot or garage over any sidewalk, curb
or parkway at any place other than a permanent driveway or in any way in
violation of any City ordinance. Vehicles driven into or out of such parking
lot or garage shall be driven with due respect to traffic conditions and in
accordance with police regulations. (1976 Code §6-28-23)
   E.   Unauthorized Use or Removal of Vehicles Prohibited:
      1.   No licensee of a parking lot or garage shall make or permit any use
for any purpose whatsoever of any vehicle parked in such place, unless the use
shall have first been expressly authorized by the owner or person having
control of the vehicle.
      2.   No licensee shall transfer or cause to be moved or transferred any
parked vehicle through or upon the streets or alleys of the City without the
written consent of the owner or person having control of the vehicle. (1976
Code §6-28-20)
   F.   Changing Identification Marks:
      1.   No person shall change the identification marks on the engine of any
car or automobile in any public garage or parking lot.
      2.   No person shall change the license tags on such cars except in
accordance with the register of motor vehicles kept by the Secretary of State
of Illinois. (1976 Code §6-28-24)
   G.   Care of Vehicles After Closing Time: When vehicles are not called for
at closing time, the attendant shall leave the keys and parking coupon for
safekeeping at a place within a reasonable distance of the parking lot or
garage with a responsible person whose name and address shall be posted in a
conspicuous place on said premises. (1976 Code §6-28-21)
3-7C-10: NOTICE OF LOST, DAMAGED OR UNCLAIMED PROPERTY:
   A.   Every licensee shall immediately notify the Police Department of every
claim made by reason of loss, theft or conversion or any damage or injury to
person or property from the operation of a parking lot or garage and occurring
during the hours the premises are regularly open for business. The obligation
created by this subsection shall not extend beyond the regular hours of
attendance as posted upon the premises and printed upon the regular receipt
furnished to the owner or person parking a vehicle. (1976 Code §6-28-18)
   B.   Every licensee shall immediately notify the Police Department, in
writing, of the license number, make and the name of the owner, if known to
him, of every vehicle left in the parking lot or garage for a period of more
than forty eight (48) consecutive hours. (1976 Code §6-28-19)
3-7C-11: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Distribution of Handbills: No person shall distribute literature or
place handbills in or upon any vehicle while parked in a parking lot or garage.
(1976 Code §6-28-16)
   B.   Disabled or Abandoned Vehicles in Parking Lots: No person shall park or
store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in condition for use or
permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially dismantled vehicle in
any such lot. (1976 Code §6-28-28)
   C.   Displaying or Repairing Vehicles in Parking Lot: No person shall use
any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of
displaying it for sale or use any parking lot or portion thereof as an
automobile repair shop. (1976 Code §6-28-29)
   D.   Smoking in Public Garages: No person shall smoke or light a cigarette,
pipe or cigar in any public garage. (1976 Code §6-28-31)
3-7C-12: INSPECTIONS:
The Chief of Police and the Fire Marshal shall make or cause to be made such
inspection of public garages and parking lots as may be necessary to insure
compliance with the provisions of this Article. Any police officer shall be
permitted at any reasonable hour to view every car stored in any public garage
or parking lot, and no person shall hinder any such inspection or conceal any
car or motor vehicle from such inspection. (1976 Code §6-28-25)
ARTICLE D. SNOW REMOVAL AND PLOWING BUSINESSES
SECTION:
3-7D-1: License Required
3-7D-2: Application For License
3-7D-3: License Fee And Term
3-7D-4: Penalties
3-7D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No vehicle utilized within the city for purposes of removing or plowing snow,
for profit, shall be operated unless there shall have been obtained therefor a
snow removal and snowplowing business license from the city clerk and paid the
required license fee as provided herein 1 . (Ord. O-02-79, 1-23-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1A-1 of this title.
3-7D-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a snow removal and plowing business license shall be submitted
to the city clerk on a form provided by the city and shall contain information
regarding a full name, address and age of the applicant, a complete description
of each vehicle utilized for said purposes, a statement as to whether or not
the vehicle is properly equipped with necessary and required safety features
and a statement as to whether or not the vehicle is properly covered by
property damage and personal liability insurance by the applicant. (Ord. O-02-
79, 1-23-1979)
3-7D-3: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
A business license fee as provided in section 1-3A-1 of this title shall be
required to be paid prior to the issuance of any said license.
A snow removal or snowplowing business license shall be issued for the term of
the fiscal year or such portion thereof as remains at the time a license is
issued and shall be effective until the end of the fiscal year unless sooner
suspended or revoked. (Ord. O-02-79, 1-23-1979)
3-7D-4: PENALTIES:
The failure of any snow removal or snowplowing vehicle's owner or operator to
secure the required business license shall result in such owner or operator
being subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be
considered a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. O-02-79, 1-23-1979; amd. 1992
Code)
ARTICLE E. CATALYTIC CONVERTERS
SECTION:
3-7E-1: Prohibited Acts
3-7E-2: Exceptions
3-7E-3: Maintenance Of Records
3-7E-4: Violation
3-7E-1: PROHIBITED ACTS:
Except as otherwise permitted in this article it shall be illegal for any
person, firm, entity or corporation to purchase, collect, transport or dispose
of any catalytic converter or any portion of a catalytic converter that is not
attached to a motor vehicle. (Ord. O-21-2015, 9-14-2015)
3-7E-2: EXCEPTIONS:
The prohibition contained in section
3-7E-1 of this article shall not apply to any business licensed by the city to
repair motor vehicles. (Ord. O-21-2015, 9-14-2015)
3-7E-3: MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS:
A dated invoice shall be prepared for each catalytic converter that is removed
from a motor vehicle. The invoice shall include the full name, address,
telephone number, and driver's license number of the owner of the motor vehicle
from which the catalytic converter was removed, and the make, model, year, and
VIN number of the vehicle. The invoices shall be kept by the licensee for two
(2) years and, upon request by the city, shall be made available for inspection
during the business' regular business hours. (Ord. O-21-2015, 9-14-2015)
3-7E-4: VIOLATION:
Any violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day that a violation exists constitutes a
separate and distinct offense. In addition to a fine the business license of
any licensee violating this article may be suspended or revoked. (Ord. O-21-
2015, 9-14-2015)
CHAPTER 8
ANIMAL – RELATED BUSINESSES
ARTICLE A. SMALL ANIMAL DEALERS
SECTION:
3-8A-1: License Required
3-8A-2: Application For License; Investigation
3-8A-3: License Fee And Term
3-8A-4: Compliance With Health Provisions
3-8A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of buying, selling or dealing in birds,
dogs or other small animals used as household pets or used for domestic
purposes without first obtaining a license. (1976 Code §
6-7-1)
3-8A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for small animal dealer's license shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for
licenses 1 . (1976 Code §
6-7-2)
The director of health and inspectional services shall cause an investigation
to be made of the premises named and described in the application for a license
for the purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of such premises for
such business from a sanitary standpoint. (1976 Code §
6-7-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-3 of this title.
3-8A-3: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
The annual fee for a license for a dealer in birds, dogs and other small
animals shall be provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1976 Code § 6-7-4)
Every license issued under this article shall expire on April 30 following the
date of its issuance. (1976 Code § 6-7-5)
3-8A-4: COMPLIANCE WITH HEALTH PROVISIONS:
Every person licensed to engage in the business of dealing in birds, dogs and
other small animals used as household pets or for domestic purposes shall
comply with the provisions of this code regulating health and sanitation
applicable thereto.
The director of health and inspectional services shall periodically inspect
each such place of business to determine whether the applicable provisions of
this code regulating health and sanitation are being complied with. (1976 Code
§ 6-7-6)
ARTICLE B. DOG KENNELS AND CATTERIES
SECTION:
3-8B-1: Definitions
3-8B-2: License Required
3-8B-3: Applications for Licenses; Investigation
3-8B-4: License Fee and Term
3-8B-5: Building and Premises
3-8B-6: Removal of Dog or Cat
3-8B-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
CATTERY: Any establishment wherein three (3) or more cats over the age of eight
(8) weeks are kept.
DOG KENNEL: Any establishment where three (3) or more dogs over the age of
eight (8) weeks are kept harbored or boarded. (1976 Code §
6-8-1)
3-8B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of operating a dog kennel or a cattery
without having obtained a license therefor. In case the business of buying,
selling or dealing in birds, dogs and other small animals used as household
pets or for domestic purposes is conducted or carried on in connection with the
business of a dog kennel or a cattery in the same premises and by the same
person, then only one license need be obtained, and that license shall be that
which requires the payment of the higher license fee under either of the two
(2) license provisions of this Code. 1
 
Notes
1 1. See Article A of this Chapter for small animal dealers.
3-8B-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; INVESTIGATION:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  Such application shall also state the number of animals which it
is proposed to keep in the establishment or premises for which application for
license is made. (1976 Code §
6-8-3)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall cause an investigation
to be made of the premises named and described in the application for license
for the purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of such premises for
such business from a sanitary standpoint. (1976 Code §
6-8-4)
 
Notes
1 2. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-8B-4: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
The annual license fee for each dog kennel or cattery shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §
6-8-5)
Any person licensed to operate a kennel shall be exempt from the payment of the
dog license fee for each and every dog which is kept in any licensed kennel.
(1976 Code §
6-8-2)
All licenses issued for the business of operating a dog kennel or cattery shall
expire on April 30 following the date of issuance. (1976 Code §
6-8-6)
3-8B-5: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
   A.   Location: No person shall maintain any dog kennel or cattery in any
location in which business uses are prohibited by the Zoning Ordinance. 1
   B.   Sanitary Provisions: All dog kennels and catteries shall be kept free
and clean from decaying food and from filth of any kind. The kennels, buildings
and pens shall be whitewashed or disinfected from time to time and shall be
kept in a sanitary condition satisfactory to the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services. (1976 Code §
6-8-9)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall periodically inspect
each such place of business to determine whether the applicable provisions of
this Code regulating health and sanitation are being complied with. (1976 Code
§
6-8-10)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 10 of this Code.
3-8B-6: REMOVAL OF DOG OR CAT:
No dog or cat shall be permitted to stray or be taken outside the limits of the
kennel or cattery unless such animal is on leash or is taken out temporarily
for the purpose of hunting, breeding, trial, show or exhibition. (1976 Code §
6-8-8)
CHAPTER 9
CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
3-9-1: Bond And Insurance
3-9-1: BOND AND INSURANCE:
   A.   Bond: All contractors and subcontractors including, but not limited to,
general building contractors, electrical contractors, carpenter contractors,
excavation contractors, plumbing contractors, or cement or masonry contractors
shall be required to post an indemnity bond in the amount of ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) for improvements costing up to five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00); the amount of twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00)
for improvements costing up to one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) and the
amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for improvements costing over one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) protecting the City against any and all damages
that may arise to the public ways and to the City and to any person in
consequence of or by reason of such contractor's occupation and operation
within the City. A person bonded as a general building contractor need not be
bonded as a subcontractor or any other kind of contractor. (Ord. O-40-96, 8-19-
1996)
   B.   Insurance: In addition to such bond, each contractor and subcontractor
shall be required to maintain, at all times such license is in effect,
liability insurance with a minimum coverage of three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage or in the
alternative minimum coverage of two hundred fifty thousand dollars
($250,000.00) per person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per
occurrence for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per
occurrence for property damage. Evidence of such insurance shall be filed with
the City Clerk and updated periodically upon request. In the event such
insurance coverage is not maintained, the license shall be revoked. (Ord. O-17-
90, 4-2-1990)
ARTICLE A. ELECTRICAL CONTRACTORS 1
SECTION:
3-9A-1: Definition
3-9A-2: Registration Required
3-9A-3: Application For Registration; Certificate
3-9A-4: Registration Fee; Expiration Of Registration
3-9A-5: Supervising Electrician
 
Notes
1 1. See title 8, chapter 1, article C of this Code.
3-9A-1: DEFINITION:
"Electrical contractor", as used in this article, shall mean any person engaged
in the business of installing or altering by contract or otherwise electrical
equipment for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power
not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and
signals, and not including apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed
for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the
jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission, for use in their operation as
public utilities; and the term does not include employees employed by such
contractor to do or supervise such work. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
3-9A-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of electrical contractor without being
registered as an electrical contractor in the manner hereinafter set forth. An
electrical contractor shall be required to pay a registration fee for the year
and shall post bond as required in section
3-9-1 of this chapter. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-49-89, 10-16-
1989; Ord. O-32-93, 10-18-1993)
3-9A-3: APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION; CERTIFICATE:
Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contractor shall
apply for registration to the Department of Public Services; it being
understood that any such person or representative of a firm or corporation
making application for registration shall have had at least four (4) years'
experience as a journeyman electrician, and in case any statements made by such
person or representative of a firm or corporation shall be found to be untrue,
such application for registration shall immediately become null and void.
Upon the filing of such application in proper form and the payment of the
registration fee fixed herein, the Department of Public Services shall register
the applicant as an electrical contractor and shall issue to the applicant a
certificate of registration which will authorize the applicant to engage in
such business for the year in which issued. No such certificate of registration
will be transferable, and the certificate shall be kept conspicuously in view
in the business place of the registrant. The Department of Public Services
shall keep a record of such registration. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord.
O-49-89, 10-16-1989; Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-1994)
3-9A-4: REGISTRATION FEE; EXPIRATION OF REGISTRATION:
The fee for registration as an electrical contractor shall be as provided in
section
3-1A-1 of this title, which sum shall be paid by the applicant to the
Department of Public Services in advance upon filing the application. All such
fees collected shall be paid by the department to the Finance Director.
The certificate or registration issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 of
the year in which it is issued. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-49-89,
10-16-1989; Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-1994; Ord. O-24-2018, 11-19-2018)
3-9A-5: SUPERVISING ELECTRICIAN:
   A.   Supervising Electrician Required for Permit; Qualifications: Before any
permit shall be issued to any person, he shall appoint or employ a supervising
electrician in conformity with this Code who shall be responsible for all
installations to be in compliance with this Code.
Minimum requirements for supervising electricians are as follows:
      1.   Minimum of twenty one (21) years of age;
      2.   Minimum of four (4) years' journeyman experience, particularly
motors, controls, circuitry and have a basic understanding of the National
Electrical Code 1 ;
      3.   Must pass the Electrical Commission's written and oral examination.
The fee for examination shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00) or as set by the
Electrical Commission from time to time. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; 1992 Code)
   B.   Certification: When the person employed or appointed to perform the
work or supervise the installation, alteration and repair of electrical wires
and apparatus under the authority of semi-annual permits as provided in section
8-1C-4-2 of this Code shall have complied with the requirements of the
Electrical Commission, the electrical inspector shall certify him as a
supervising electrician by placing his name on the affidavit form filed by the
person desiring to secure permits to perform electrical work. (Ord. O-23-79,
11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-49-89, 10-16-1989)
   C.   Termination Of Supervising Electricians: Whenever a supervising
electrician shall leave or be discharged from the employ of any person required
to employ a supervising electrician, within fourteen (14) days, written notice
shall be given the Department of Public Services by the employer. Permit
privileges of such person shall be suspended until a certified supervising
electrician is employed or appointed. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-
06-94, 3-7-1994)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 8, chapter 1, article C of this Code.
ARTICLE B. SEWER AND WATER CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
3-9B-1: License Required
3-9B-2: Application for License; Issuance
3-9B-3: License Fee
3-9B-4: Revocation of License
3-9B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall be permitted to engage in the business of sewer and water
contractor, including the business of laying water or sewer pipes for
connection to the waterworks and sewerage systems of the City, unless he shall
have obtained a license for that purpose. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79; amd. Ord. 0-
34-90, 6-18-90)
3-9B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE: 1
An application for a sewer and water contractor license shall be made to the
Director of Public Works setting out therein the name, residence and place of
business of such applicant.
The Director of Public Works, upon receipt of such application, shall ascertain
or cause to be ascertained whether such applicant is in possession of the
necessary skill to enable him to engage in the business. If such applicant
shall be duly qualified, such officer shall, upon the payment by such applicant
to the City Clerk of the license fee and upon the order of the Mayor and the
City Council so to do, issue or cause to be issued a license authorizing such
applicant to engage in the business of sewer and water contractor. (Ord. 0-23-
79, 11-20-79)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-9-1 of this Chapter for bond.
3-9B-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a sewer and water contractor license shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. No license shall be issued for less than the full annual
fee herein specified. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
3-9B-4: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any licensed sewer and water contractor who shall violate any provision of this
Article or Title 7, Chapter 7, Articles A and B of this Code or shall perform
any work other than in a safe and workmanlike manner, shall have his license
revoked by the Mayor and City Council, upon recommendations of the Director of
Public Works, and shall not again be permitted to engage in the business of
sewer and water contractor unless satisfactory assurance shall be given to the
Mayor and City Council that such person thereafter will faithfully observe said
provisions, and until such sewer and water contractor shall have made good any
loss, damage or expense caused by or on account of any negligence or misconduct
on his part which was the cause of revocation of his license. (Ord. 0-23-79,
11-20-79)
ARTICLE C. DRAIN LAYERS
SECTION:
3-9C-1: License Required
3-9C-2: Application for License; Issuance
3-9C-3: License Fee
3-9C-4: Renewal of License
3-9C-5: Drain Laying Requirements
3-9C-6: Revocation of License
3-9C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of drain layer without first obtaining a
license therefor. (1976 Code §6-9-1)
3-9C-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE: 1
An application for license under this Article shall be made to the Director of
Health and Inspectional Services, setting forth therein the name, residence and
place of business of the applicant. (1976 Code §6-9-2)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services, upon receipt of the license
application, shall ascertain or cause to be ascertained whether the applicant
is in possession of the necessary skill to enable him to engage in the
business; if such applicant shall be duly qualified, such officer shall, upon
the payment by the applicant to the City Clerk of the license fee and upon the
order of the Mayor and the City Council to do so, issue or cause to be issued a
license authorizing such applicant to engage in the business of drain layer.
(1976 Code §6-9-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
   3-9-1 of this Chapter for bond.
3-9C-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a drain layer's license shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. No license shall be issued for less than the full annual
fee. (1976 Code §6-9-4)
3-9C-4: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Any person licensed as a drain layer shall be entitled to have his license
renewed without filing an application upon payment by him of the annual license
fee and the renewal of the bond provided for in Section
3-9-1 of this Chapter. (1976 Code §6-9-6)
3-9C-5: DRAIN LAYING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Supervision:
      1.   All work done by licensed drain layers on drains or pipes inside any
building or structure and all work done on any catch basin or cesspool located
on or in any private premises shall be done according to plans approved by the
Department of Health and Inspectional Services and under the supervision and to
the satisfaction and approval of the Director of Health and Inspectional
Services.
      2.   All work done by licensed drain layers on drains or pipes outside
any building or structure or upon any public way shall be done under the
supervision and subject to the approval of the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services.
   B.   Permit Required: No such work shall be done except on a permit in
writing issued by the Director of Health and Inspectional Services. (1976 Code
§6-9-7)
   C.   Inspections: All work done by licensed drain layers, other than work
done on local improvements paid wholly or in part by special assessment, while
such work is under the supervision and control of the Board of Local
Improvements, 1  shall be subject to the inspection, supervision, and approval
of the Director of Health and Inspectional Services. Any faulty or defective
work done by any licensed drain layer which may at any time be discovered by
the said officer shall be made satisfactory to the officer. (1976 Code §6-9-8)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 2, Chapter 2 of this Code.
3-9C-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any licensed drain layer who shall violate any of the provisions of this
Article or any rule or regulation of the building ordinance governing or
regulating the business of drain laying 1  shall have his license revoked by
the Mayor and the City Council upon the recommendation of the Director of
Health and Inspectional Services and shall not again be permitted to engage in
the business of drain laying until satisfactory assurance shall be given to the
Mayor and City Council that such person will thereafter faithfully observe the
provisions of this Article and the rules and regulations of the building
ordinances and until such drain layer shall have made good any loss, damage or
expense caused by or on account of any negligence or misconduct on his part
which was the cause of the revocation of his license. (1976 Code §6-9-9)

ARTICLE E. MASON CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
3-9E-1: Definition
3-9E-2: License Required
3-9E-3: Application for License; Fee and Term
3-9E-4: Exemptions from Provisions
3-9E-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, "mason contractor" shall mean any person engaging in the
business of work in brick, stone, concrete, terracotta, tile and fireproofing
or any combination of these materials as used in and about the construction of
buildings or structures above or below the surface of the ground. (1976 Code
§6-27-1)
3-9E-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of a mason contractor or of constructing
or repairing sidewalks in any public street or place in the City without first
having obtained a license therefor and furnishing a bond as provided in Section
3-9-1 of this Chapter. (1976 Code §6-27-2)
3-9E-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE AND TERM:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  (1976 Code §6-27-3)
The annual license fee for a mason contractor shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-27-4)
All licenses shall be due on May 1 of each year and shall expire on April 30
following the date of issuance. (1976 Code §6-27-5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-9E-4: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this Article shall not apply to any person who, by himself,
lays a sidewalk in front of property owned by him. (1976 Code §6-27-2)

cinders, building material, sand, debris or other substance or material in

public or private building or structure requiring a foundation to be
constructed below the level of the street or any sewer, vault or other like
work requiring the removal of dirt, rock, sand, debris or other substance.
(1976 Code §6-11-1)
