CHAPTER 10
RETAIL DEALERS AND OCCUPATIONS
ARTICLE A. CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS
SECTION:
3-10A-1: License Required; Restrictions
3-10A-2: Application For License; Fee
3-10A-3: Required Warning Signs
3-10A-4: Location Restrictions
3-10A-5: Tobacco Vending Machines
3-10A-6: Inspections And Analyses
3-10A-7: Penalties
3-10A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall sell or offer for sale cigarettes or tobaccos within the city
without obtaining a license therefor. Nothing herein contained shall be held to
authorize the following: (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
   A.   Selling, buying for, distributing samples of or furnishing any cigar,
cigarette, electronic cigarette, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its
forms, either over the counter or through vending machines, to any minor under
eighteen (18) years of age.
For the purpose of this section, "smokeless tobacco" means any tobacco products
that are suitable for dipping or chewing.
For the purposes of this section "electronic cigarette" means any
electronically actuated device which in operation causes the user to exhale any
smoke, vapor or other substance other than those produced by unenhanced human
exhalation. "Electronic cigarette" includes any such device, whether
manufactured, distributed, marketed or sold as an electronic cigarette, an
electronic cigar, an electronic cigarillo, an electronic pipe, an electronic
hookah or under any other product name or descriptor. The term "electronic
cigarette" does not include any asthma inhaler or other device that has been
specifically approved by the United States food and drug administration. (Ord.
O-13-2014, 4-21-2014)
   B.   Cigarettes containing opium, morphine or any other narcotic or
hallucinatory drug or jimsonweed, belladonna, glycerine, sugar or so called
marijuana cigarettes. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation, including
any licensee, to sell or offer for sale individual cigarettes to any person;
said cigarettes shall be contained in the original package, pack or carton upon
sale. (Ord. O-20-96, 3-18-1996)
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any minor under eighteen (18) years of age to
possess or use any cigar, cigarette, electronic cigarette, smokeless tobacco or
tobacco of any form. (Ord. O-13-2014, 4-21-2014)
3-10A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license under this article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for
licenses.
The annual fee for a license for the sale of cigarettes or tobaccos in the city
shall be as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
3-10A-3: REQUIRED WARNING SIGNS:
All persons licensed under this article shall post a sign at or near "over the
counter sales" display locations and on tobacco vending machines. Each such
sign shall be plainly visible and shall state the following:
   NOTICE
The Sale of Tobacco Products to Persons Under 18 Years of Age is Prohibited by
Law.
The text shall be at least one inch (1") high and on white background. Persons
or businesses covered by this article shall have sixty (60) days after passage
of this article to comply. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
3-10A-4: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away, or
deliver tobacco products within one hundred feet (100') of any school,
childcare facility, or other building used for education, or recreational
programs for persons under the age of eighteen (18) years. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-
1996)
3-10A-5: TOBACCO VENDING MACHINES:
It shall be unlawful to install, place or permit the use of any tobacco vending
machines in any establishment which is open to minors, except in a place where
the machine is not accessible to or cannot be used by minors; provided,
however, that this section shall not apply to the installation and use by the
proprietor, his agent or employees of tobacco vending machines behind a counter
or in some place in any establishment in which access by minors is prohibited
by law; provided further, this article shall not apply to the installations and
use of a tobacco vending machine in commercial buildings of industrial plants
where the public is not usually admitted and where such machines are intended
for the sole use of the employees who are not minors. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
3-10A-6: INSPECTIONS AND ANALYSES:
The chief of police shall, from time to time, inspect and examine all places
where cigarettes and tobaccos are sold or offered for sale with a view of
ascertaining whether the provisions of this code or any laws of the state
relating to cigarettes and tobaccos are complied with.
All persons licensed under this article shall, upon demand of the chief of
police, furnish to the chief of police for his inspection samples of all
cigarettes and tobaccos sold or offered for sale. The said samples shall be
analyzed by or under the direction of the chief of police. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-
1996; amd. Ord. O-06-2014, 3-3-2014)
3-10A-7: PENALTIES:
Any person or business accused of violating any of the provisions of this
article shall be subject to the following penalties as recommended by the
license committee of the city council.
First offense:
Shall pay a fine not to exceed $1,000.00.
Second offense:
Tobacco license suspended for 3 months and a fine not to exceed $1,000.00.
Third offense:
Tobacco license suspended for 6 months and a fine of $1,000.00.
Fourth offense:
Tobacco license revoked and a fine of $1,000.00. (Ord. O-04-96, 1-22-1996)
ARTICLE B. JUNK DEALERS
SECTION:
3-10B-1: Definitions
3-10B-2: License Required; Application; Issuance
3-10B-3: License Fee
3-10B-4: Separate License for Each Location; Change of Location
3-10B-5: Contents of License; License Posted
3-10B-6: Closing Hours
3-10B-7: Building and Premises
3-10B-8: Prohibited Acts and Conditions
3-10B-9: Lost or Stolen Articles
3-10B-10: Vehicle Requirements
3-10B-11: Inspections
3-10B-12: Revocation of License
3-10B-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
FENCE: Means and includes any place for the purchase, reception or keeping of
stolen goods.
JUNK: Means and includes old iron, brass, copper, tin, lead and other base
metals, old rope, bags, rags, wastepaper, paper clippings, bagging, rubber and
glass, empty bottles, old or used chain, cable, wire, tires, batteries and
battery parts and all other articles, goods or things which have been discarded
or are no longer used as manufactured articles composed of or consisting of any
one or more of the materials or articles herein mentioned.
JUNK DEALER: Means and includes every person who shall buy, sell, barter or
exchange or collect, receive, store or hold in his possession for sale, barter
or exchange any of the articles, goods or things in this Section defined as
"junk" and that does not perform work or service on such articles, goods or
things so as to enhance the value thereof and carries on such business as a
main pursuit rather than as an incident to any other principal business.
JUNK STORE: Means and includes any store, shop, house, warehouse or other
building where junk is bought, sold, bartered, traded or exchanged or is
collected, received, stored or held in possession for sale, barter, trade or
exchange.
JUNK YARD: Means and includes any yard, place, enclosure or premises other than
a "junk store", as herein defined, where junk is bought, sold, bartered,
traded, or exchanged or where junk is collected, received, stored or held in
possession for sale, barter, trade or exchange.
JUNK WAGON: Means and includes every wagon, automobile, car or other vehicle
used by a junk dealer in the collection, disposition or transportation of junk
from one place to another. (1976 Code §6-23-1)
3-10B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE:
No person shall maintain or conduct the business of a junk dealer without first
obtaining a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-23-2)
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the provisions of this Code relating to applications for licenses. 1  In
addition, the application shall be executed under oath. The application shall
also, if the applicant is a natural person, state that the applicant has not
kept, conducted or operated and has not, within one year prior to the date of
the application, been convicted of keeping, conducting or operating a fence.
The application, if by a corporation, shall state that the applicant has not,
nor has any of its officers, stockholders or employees, kept, conducted or
operated, or within one year prior to the date of application, been convicted
of keeping, conducting or operating a fence. The application shall, in
addition, furnish satisfactory evidence of good character and repute. If the
application is granted, license shall issue upon payment of the prescribed fee.
(1976 Code §6-23-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-10B-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a license as a junk dealer shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-23-4)
3-10B-4: SEPARATE LICENSE FOR EACH LOCATION; CHANGE OF LOCATION:
   A.   A junk dealer's license shall be valid only for the particular place of
business designated therein. Every junk dealer conducting business at more than
one place in the City shall procure a separate license for each place of
business; provided, that where a junk store and yard located upon the same,
contiguous or adjoining premises are conducted by the same junk dealer, such
business shall be considered as one business and only one license shall be
required therefor. (1976 Code §6-23-5)
   B.   In case any licensed junk dealer shall desire for any reason to remove
his place of business from the place or location designated in his license to
another place or location within the City, such junk dealer shall make and file
written notice with the City Clerk who shall issue a new license, and the
license previously issued shall be returned to the City Clerk for cancellation.
(1976 Code §6-23-6)
3-10B-5: CONTENTS OF LICENSE; LICENSE POSTED:
Every junk dealer's license shall state, in addition to the name of the
licensee, the nature of the business, the term of the license and the
particular location within the City where such business is to be conducted. The
license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of
business so as to be easily seen. (1976 Code §6-23-7)
3-10B-6: CLOSING HOURS:
No junk dealer shall purchase or receive, in the exercise and conduct of his
business any goods, articles or things from any person between the hours of six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and at any time on Sunday.
(1976 Code §6-23-10)
3-10B-7: BUILDING AND PREMISES: 1
   A.   No junk dealer shall establish, conduct or operate any junk store or
junk yard in the City at any location other than that provided for and
permitted by the zoning ordinances of the City. 2
   B.   Sanitary and Safety Conditions:
      1.   The premises shall at all times be maintained so as not to
constitute a nuisance or menace to the health of the community or of residents
nearby or a place for the breeding of rodents and vermin.
      2.   No garbage or other organic waste and no paper, rubbish, rags or
other flammable article or materials shall be stored in such premises.
      3.   Whenever any motor vehicle shall be received in such premises as
junk, all gasoline and oil shall be drained and removed therefrom, and none
shall be permitted to remain upon the premises.
      4.   The manner of storage, arrangement of junk and the drainage
facilities of the premises shall be such as to prevent the accumulation of
stagnant water upon the premises and to facilitate access for firefighting
purposes.
      5.   All outdoor storage facilities shall be enclosed in a substantial,
solid, nontransparent fence not less than eight feet (8') nor more than ten
feet (10') high. Such enclosure shall at all times be painted and kept in good
order.
      6.   No materials or wastes shall be deposited on any premises in such
form or manner that they may be transferred off such premises by natural causes
or forces.
      7.   No material or merchandise of any sort shall be stored in front of
the enclosure provided for in subsection B5 hereof.
      8.   No person shall burn in any junk yard refuse or junk including
rubber tires, batteries and rubber from wires or any type of junk or old used
automobiles which may cause fumes or odors injurious to the health and welfare
of adjoining residents. (1976 Code §6-23-16)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 4, Chapter 2 of this Code for nuisances.
2 2. See Title 10 of this Code.
3-10B-8: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   No junk dealer shall:
      1.   Sale Without Holding: Expose or offer for sale, sell, exchange or
dispose of any goods or junk of any kind within seventy two (72) hours next
following the actual time of purchase, collection, receipt or taking possession
thereof. (1976 Code §6-23-13)
      2.   Purchasing From Minors: Purchase, collect or receive any goods,
articles or things of any kind from any minor without the written consent first
had of the parents or guardian of such minor. (1976 Code § 6-23-14)
      3.   Acting As Or Carrying Of License Of Pawnbroker:
         a.   Receive any goods, articles or things of any kind, character or
description as a pledge or pawn nor lend or advance any sum of money or credit
on the security of such goods, articles or things. (1976 Code § 6-23-17)
         b.   During the period of his license, receive or hold any license to
engage in the business of pawnbroker. (1976 Code § 6-23-18)
   B.   Maintaining A Fence: No person conducting or operating a junk store or
junkyard shall conduct or maintain the same as a fence. (1976 Code § 6-23-15)
3-10B-9: LOST OR STOLEN ARTICLES:
Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles
or things which may have been lost or stolen, or are alleged or supposed to
have been lost or stolen shall forthwith, upon demand, exhibit the same for
inspection by any member of the police department or any member of the city
council. (1976 Code § 6-23-12)
3-10B-10: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Every junk wagon used or operated in the city for the collection, handling,
transportation or disposition of junk, shall have painted on each side thereof,
in letters and figures not less than two and one-half inches (21/2") in height,
of sufficient width to be clearly legible and in a position thereon so as to be
plainly visible, the name of the junk dealer owning, using or operating such
junk wagon, the street and number and the name of the city, town or village
wherein such junk dealer's principal place of business is located. (1976 Code §
6-23-9)
3-10B-11: INSPECTIONS:
The place of business of every junk dealer shall, at all reasonable times, be
open to inspection by any member of the police department, and no junk dealer
shall refuse access thereto or permission for such inspection. (1976 Code § 6-
23-11)
3-10B-12: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The license of any junk dealer issued under this article may be revoked and
canceled by the mayor or city council when and after such junk dealer or any of
his officers, stockholders, employees, agents or representatives has been
convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of the charge of keeping,
conducting or maintaining a fence. Whenever any junk dealer or any officer,
stockholder, employee, agent or representative thereof has been so convicted,
he shall thereafter be barred, for a period of not less than one year next
following the date of such conviction, from receiving or holding a license
under this article. (1976 Code § 6-23-19)
ARTICLE C. SECONDHAND DEALERS
SECTION:
3-10C-1: License Required; Exceptions
3-10C-2: Application For License; Investigation
3-10C-3: License Fee
3-10C-4: Purchase From Minors Prohibited
3-10C-5: Lost Or Stolen Goods
3-10C-6: Records
3-10C-7: Melting, Wrecking And Remodeling Of Items
3-10C-8: Revocation Of License
3-10C-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person shall engage in the business of a secondhand dealer or any type of
resale store or of issuing payment in exchange for jewelry, merchandise or
other items within the city limits without first obtaining a license therefor
for each separate place, premises or location where such business is to be
carried on; provided, that the words "secondhand dealer", as used in this
section, shall not include pawnbrokers or junk dealers as provided in other
provisions of this title, or sales or exchanges of used articles or materials
conducted by charitable or religious organizations. (Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-2010)
3-10C-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for a license as a secondhand dealer shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for
licenses 1 . (1976 Code § 6-37-2)
When an application for a license under this article is made, the chief of
police shall cause an investigation to be made to ascertain whether the
applicant has complied with the state laws and the provisions of this code, and
whether the applicant is of good character and repute. (1976 Code § 6-37-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-3 of this title.
3-10C-3: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a secondhand dealer's license shall be as provided in
section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1976 Code § 6-37-4)
3-10C-4: PURCHASE FROM MINORS PROHIBITED:
No secondhand dealer or keeper of a resale store shall purchase any secondhand
article whatsoever from any minor without the written consent of his parent or
guardian. (1976 Code § 6-37-5)
3-10C-5: LOST OR STOLEN GOODS:
Any secondhand dealer, keeper, operator or manager of a resale or secondhand
store who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles of personal
property or things of value, which may have been lost or stolen or which may be
alleged to have been lost or stolen shall, upon demand to view or examine the
same, forthwith produce such goods, articles of personal property or things of
value to the mayor or any officer of the police department. (1976 Code § 6-37-
6; amd. 1992 Code)
3-10C-6: RECORDS:
   A.   Records Kept: Every secondhand dealer doing business in the city shall
keep a record, in English, of every article pledged with him or sold to him,
and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any
time during business hours.
The record maintained by the secondhand dealer shall be made at the time of the
transaction and shall set forth the following information:
      1.   Name, age, sex, and a general description of the individual with
whom the transaction is had, as well as the individual's residence and his
signature on the receipt and permanent record kept by the secondhand dealer;
      2.   A photocopy of a driver's license;
      3.   Confirmation that a second item of identification was shown;
      4.   The price of consideration paid or received at the time of the
transaction;
      5.   A description of every article received, purchased, sold or
exchanged by the secondhand dealer giving the manufacturer's name and other
marks of identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to,
the serial number, if any on the article. If writing a description of every
article is impracticable because of the number of items being sold as a unit
(for example, a coin, magazine or baseball card collection), then the
secondhand dealer shall write as detailed description as practicable for the
unit as a whole, which may include such details as number of estimated of items
within the unit, the range of dates appearing on the items, general physical
description of unit as a whole, etc.;
      6.   All entries in the record shall be signed by the person making the
entry; and
      7.   Such records shall be retained for a period of at least one year
from the date of the transaction. (Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-2010)
   B.   Inspections:
      1.   Such record shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection
of the mayor, chief of police and any member of the police department or any
person duly authorized to make such inspection. (1976 Code § 6-37-7; amd. 1992
Code)
      2.   The chief of police or some person duly authorized by him shall
inspect the register book and other records of the secondhand dealer or owner,
operator or manager of a licensed resale store at least once every six (6)
months to assure compliance with the provisions of this article. (1976 Code §
6-37-8)
3-10C-7: MELTING, WRECKING AND REMODELING OF ITEMS:
No secondhand dealer shall melt, or transfer to another to be melted, any
watch, watchcase, jewelry, or other identifiable article composed, or
manufactured, in whole or in part, of gold, silver, platinum, or other precious
metals until such secondhand dealer has made a record of his intention to do
so, along with all other data required to be recorded by the specific
recordation provisions of this article, and has reported the same to the chief
of police or his designated agent(s), and unless and until he has kept such
article intact in his licensed place of business, for inspection for seven (7)
working/business days after the report has been made sent to the chief of
police or his designated agent(s). However, if the identifiable article
proposed to be melted down, wrecked, or remodeled has been sooner inspected by
the chief of police or his designated agent(s) and has received written
clearance for such melting, wrecking, or remodeling from same, said article may
be melted, wrecked, or remodeled prior to the expiration for the seven (7)
working/business days. (Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-2010)
3-10C-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued pursuant to this article may be revoked for any violation of
any provision of this article. (1976 Code § 6-37-9; amd. Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-
2010)
ARTICLE D. LUMBERYARDS; MATERIALS STORAGE YARDS
SECTION:
3-10D-1: License Required
3-10D-2: Applications For Licenses; Fees
3-10D-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Lumberyard: No person shall maintain or operate within the city any
lumberyard or place where lumber is sold without first obtaining a license so
to do. (1976 Code § 6-25-1)
   B.   Material Storage Yard: No person shall maintain or operate within the
city any material storage yard, meaning thereby, a yard or place where brick,
stone, gravel, cement, tile, sewer pipe or other building materials are stored
or kept for sale, without first obtaining a license therefor. (1976 Code § 6-
25-2)
   C.   Contractor's Storage Yard: No person shall keep or maintain within the
city any contractor's storage yard, meaning thereby, any yard or place where
contractor's equipment including, but without limitation thereto, steamrollers,
excavating machinery, asphalt pavement plants, tar kettles, wagons, graders and
building forms are kept or stored, without first obtaining a license therefor.
(1976 Code § 6-25-3)
3-10D-2: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; FEES:
An application for any license under the provisions of this article shall be
made in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to
applications for licenses 1 . (1976 Code § 6-25-4)
The annual license fee for operating a lumberyard or a material storage yard or
a contractor's storage yard shall be as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1976 Code § 6-25-5)

1 1. See section
  3-1-3 of this title.
ARTICLE E. FLORISTS
SECTION:
3-10E-1: Definitions
3-10E-2: Licenses Required
3-10E-3: Application for License; Fee
3-10E-4: Separate License for Each Business and Each Location or Vehicle
3-10E-5: Sanitary Conditions
3-10E-6: Inspections
3-10E-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
RETAIL FLORIST: Any person engaged in the business of selling, offering for
sale or keeping with the intention of selling at retail flowers, bridal
bouquets, funeral designs or growing plants.
WHOLESALE FLORIST: Any person engaged in the business of selling, offering for
sale or keeping with the intention of selling at wholesale flowers, bouquets,
funeral floral designs or growing plants. The term shall also include any
person not operating from a fixed location in the City who shall deal, sell,
offer for sale or deliver at wholesale within the City from any vehicle
flowers, bouquets, funeral floral designs or growing plants. (1976 Code §6-14-
1)
3-10E-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of retail florist or wholesale florist
without first having procured a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-14-2)
3-10E-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  Every application for a license as an itinerant wholesale florist
shall also contain the address of the applicant. The application shall indicate
the nature of the business which the applicant desires to engage in. (1976 Code
§6-14-3)
The annual license fee for a retail florist or a wholesale florist shall be as
provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-14-5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-10E-4: SEPARATE LICENSE FOR EACH BUSINESS AND EACH LOCATION OR VEHICLE:
   A.   Every person who shall engage in both a retail florist business and a
wholesale florist business shall procure a separate license for each. (1976
Code §6-14-2)
   B.   A separate license shall be required for each location, place or
premises where a person is wholesale florist, and a separate license shall be
required for each vehicle from which flowers, bouquets, funeral floral designs
and growing plants are sold. (1976 Code §6-14-4)
3-10E-5: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
Every establishment where the business of a florist is conducted, managed or
carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No decayed,
decaying, unwholesome, contaminated or diseased flowers, plants or other things
shall be allowed to remain in or about such establishment, and such
establishment shall be kept clear of rubbish and inflammable matter. Such
establishment shall comply with all State laws governing the sale, possession,
growing or disposition of noxious, diseased or infected plants, trees or
shrubs. (1976 Code §6-14-6)
3-10E-6: INSPECTIONS:
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall cause an annual
inspection to be made of all florist establishments to determine whether the
requirements of this Code relating to health, sanitation and safety are being
complied with. (1976 Code §6-14-7)

3-10F-3: BOND: 1
A cash bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be
deposited with the City Clerk for the purpose of indemnifying the City against
having any location remain in an unsanitary and unhealthy condition after the
Christmas season. Such cash bond shall be refunded within five (5) days after
discontinuance or termination of the Christmas tree sale business so long as
the location has been placed in a sanitary and safe condition. If the material
and debris remain on the premises, then the City shall cause the same to be
removed and pay the cost of removal out of the said deposit. The balance, if
any, shall then be returned to the licensee. (1976 Code §

license shall be granted except for locations that are properly zoned. (1976

ARTICLE G. HARDWARE AND PAINT STORES
SECTION:
3-10G-1: Definitions
3-10G-2: License Required
3-10G-3: Application for License; Fee
3-10G-4: Investigations and Inspections
3-10G-5: Rights and Conditions of License
3-10G-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
RETAIL: Sales other than those for the purpose of resale or for use by
manufacturers, contractors, trades, railroads, public service corporations and
institutions or for the supplying of branch or general establishments from a
central depot or store and shall not include the sale at retail of secondhand
or used goods, wares or commodities.
RETAIL HARDWARE STORE: Any building, room, enclosure, premises, place,
establishment or part of an establishment in the City operated, maintained or
conducted for the sale or offering for sale at retail any of the following
articles: hardware, tinware, aluminumware, enamelware, cutlery, tools,
implements, apparatus, machinery, plumbing, engineers', janitors',
blacksmiths', contractors' or electrical supplies, gas, plumbing or electrical
fixtures, other articles or wares made largely of metals, kerosene, rifles,
shotguns and loaded shot shells or cartridges; provided, however, that dealers
or establishments or parts of establishments of a similar nature specifically
defined and licensed by other parts of this Article shall be exempt from the
provisions licensing retail hardware stores.
RETAIL PAINT STORE: Any building, room, enclosure, premises, place,
establishment or part of an establishment in the City operated or conducted for
the sale or offering for sale at retail of any paints, dry colors, wallpaper,
varnishes, calcimine, white or red lead, raw or boiled linseed oil, turpentine,
dryer, benzine, naphtha and painters' tools, supplies and equipment. Dealers or
establishments or parts of establishments of a similar nature specifically
defined and licensed by other provisions of this Article shall be exempt from
the provisions of that part of this Article dealing with paint stores. (1976
Code §6-19-1)
3-10G-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate a retail hardware store or paint store
without first obtaining a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-19-2)
3-10G-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a retail hardware store license or retail paint store
license shall be made in conformity with the requirements of this Code relating
to applications for licenses, 1  and the applicant shall also describe the
premises to be licensed and state the location of same. Every such application
shall be approved by the Fire Marshal and by the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services before the license shall be issued. (1976 Code §6-19-3)
The annual fee for a retail hardware store or retail paint store license shall
be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-19-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-10G-4: INVESTIGATIONS AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Initial Investigations:
      1.   The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall cause an
investigation to be made of the premises named and described in the application
for a license for the purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of
such premises for such business from a sanitary standpoint and determining
whether or not such premises comply with all the provisions of this Article and
laws of the State regulating health, safety and sanitation.
      2.   The Fire Marshal shall also cause an investigation to be made of
such premises for the purpose of determining whether the same comply with all
the fire regulations of this Code.
   B.   Annual Inspections: The Director of Health and Inspectional Services
and the Fire Marshal, in addition to making an initial inspection provided for
herein, shall visit or cause to be visited all such places of business licensed
under this Article as often as they deem necessary, but at least once a year.
(1976 Code §6-19-5)
3-10G-5: RIGHTS AND CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Every licensed retail hardware store shall have the privilege of
engaging in the business of a retail paint store within the same building,
room, enclosure, premises, place, establishment or part of an establishment
without the necessity of obtaining an additional license.
   B.   No retail hardware store license shall include the right or privilege
of selling deadly weapons or air rifles and toy weapons or gunpowder and
explosives. 1  (1976 Code §6-19-2)

ARTICLE H. FIREARMS DEALERS

3-10H-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling or to
sell or to give away to any person within the City any firearms which are of
such size or nature as may be concealed upon the person without securing a
license therefor. (Ord. 0-42-90. 8-6-90)
3-10H-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE; FEE:
Any dealer desiring a license to sell firearms shall make written application
to the City Council, stating in such application his full name and residence
or, if a corporation, the name thereof and of its principal officers and their
addresses. Such application shall also state the location at which it intends
to conduct such business. Upon the receipt of such application, with the City
Council's approval, it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to issue a license
to the applicant upon payment to the City Treasurer of the required applicant
up on payment to the City Treasurer of the required annual license fee. 1
(Ord. 0-42-90, 8-6-90)

  3-1A-1 of this Code for fee.

Ord. 0-42-90, 8-6-90)
3-10H-4:PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be punished by a fine
of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and a dealer in firearms
convicted of violating any provision of this Article shall, in addition to such
penalty, forfeit his license. (Ord. 0-42-90, 8-6-90; 1992 Code)
CHAPTER 11
LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANERS
ARTICLE A. LAUNDRIES AND LAUNDROMATS
SECTION:
3-11A-1: Definitions
3-11A-2: License Required
3-11A-3: Application for License; Fee
3-11A-4: Investigation; Issuance of License
3-11A-5: Attendant
3-11A-6: Revocation of License
3-11A-7: Laundry Vehicles
3-11A-8: Penalty
3-11A-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
LAUNDROMAT: Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion
thereof having within such premises one or more automatic washing machines and/
or drying machines which are rented, leased or hired out to any member of the
public for a consideration and for use upon such premises.
LAUNDRY: Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof
which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing shirts,
dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs or other wearing apparel, table, bed or
other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies or other washable fabrics,
such work being done for the general public. The word "laundry", as used in
this Article, shall also be held to include any private laundry maintained or
operated in connection with any hotel, restaurant or public institution, except
a hospital or charitable institution where no charge is made for laundry
service.
LAUNDRY VEHICLE: Any wagon, automobile or other vehicle used for the purpose of
collecting and delivering laundry within the City. (1976 Code §6-24-1)
3-11A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct, operate, maintain or carry on the business of any
laundry or laundromat without first obtaining a license to do so. (1976 Code
§6-24-2)
3-11A-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
The application for a license to conduct a laundry or laundromat shall be made
in writing and shall conform to the general provisions of this Code relating to
applications for licenses 1  and shall also state the maximum number of persons
to be employed therein. (1976 Code §6-24-3)
The annual license fee for a laundry or laundromat shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-24-7)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-11A-4: INVESTIGATION; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The director of public services shall cause an investigation to be made of the
premises named and described in the application for license for the purpose of
determining whether the sanitary conditions and the other requirements of this
article are fully complied with. If the director of public services shall find
that the proposed laundry or laundromat and the premises wherein it is located
are in conformity with the provisions of this article, he shall transmit his
recommendations to the mayor for the issuance of a license. (1976 Code §§ 6-24-
4, 6-24-5; amd. Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-1994)
The mayor, upon receipt of the recommendation of the director of public
services, shall issue or cause to be issued to the applicant, upon payment of
the license fee, a license to conduct or operate a laundry or laundromat at the
place designated in the application. (1976 Code § 6-24-6; amd. Ord. O-06-94, 3-
7-1994)
3-11A-5: ATTENDANT:
   A.   Attendant Required: No coin operated, self-service laundry or
laundromat shall be operated between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
and six thirty o'clock (6:30) A.M. without having present on the premises an
attendant. (1976 Code § 6-24-8)
   B.   Information On Attendant To Police: The owner or operator of a laundry
or laundromat employing an attendant shall provide the police department with
the name and address of such attendant and all other information that may be
required by the police department. (1976 Code § 6-24-9; amd. Ord. O-30-93, 10-
4-1993; Ord. O-06-2014, 3-3-2014)
   C.   Posting Of Emergency Numbers By Owner: All laundry and laundromat
owners shall post the name, address and phone number of a contact person and a
police emergency phone number in a clearly visible section of their businesses.
(Ord. O-23-95, 6-5-1995)
3-11A-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The license granted under this article shall be subject to revocation for cause
as in the case of all other licenses, and in addition thereto, the mayor may
revoke it at any time that it shall appear to his satisfaction from any report
or recommendation of the director of public services that the maintenance of
any such laundry or laundromat is dangerous or detrimental to the health of the
residents of the city or the health of the persons employed therein. (1976 Code
§ 6-24-12; amd. Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-1994)
3-11A-7: LAUNDRY VEHICLES:
   A.   License Required: No person shall operate or cause to be operated, on
any of the streets, alleys or other public places in the city any laundry
vehicle without first obtaining a license therefor. (1976 Code § 6-24-13)
   B.   Application For License; Fee: Any person desiring to operate a laundry
vehicle on any of the streets, alleys or other public places of the city shall
make an application in writing to the city clerk which shall conform to the
general provisions of this code relating to applications for licenses 1  and
stating the character of the vehicle for which the license is applied for.
(1976 Code § 6-24-14)
The annual license fee for each laundry vehicle shall be as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1976 Code § 6-24-18)
   C.   Inspection Of Vehicle; Issuance Of License: Upon receipt of the
application for a laundry vehicle license, the city clerk shall forward the
same to the director of public services, who shall cause such investigation to
be made as is necessary for the purpose of determining whether such laundry
vehicle complies with the sanitary and health regulations of the city. If the
director of public services finds that such laundry vehicle complies with the
sanitary and health regulations, he shall forward such application with his
approval to the mayor. (1976 Code §§ 6-24-15, 6-24-16; amd. Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-
1994)
The mayor, upon receipt of the recommendation of the director of public
services, shall cause a license to be issued to such applicant upon the payment
of the license fee. (1976 Code § 6-24-17; amd. Ord. O-06-94, 3-7-1994)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-3 of this title.
3-11A-8: PENALTY:
Any person who shall establish, maintain, conduct, carry on or operate a
laundry or laundromat without first procuring a license or who fails to employ
and have present on the licensed premises, when required to do so, an
attendant, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense. (1976 Code § 6-24-11; amd. 1992 Code)
ARTICLE B. DRY CLEANERS
SECTION:
3-11B-1: License Required
3-11B-2: Application for License; Fee
3-11B-3: Fire Prevention and Protection
3-11B-4: Inspections
3-11B-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate a dry cleaning establishment in which
gasoline, benzine, turpentine, petroleum or any of the products thereof are to
be used without first obtaining a license so to do. (1976 Code §6-10-1)
3-11B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  Such application shall be accompanied by a sketch or plan of the
building in which such business is to be conducted showing the proposed
location of the dry cleaning equipment and showing all measures proposed to be
taken to avoid damage from fire and explosion. (1976 Code §6-10-2)
The annual license fee for a dry cleaning establishment shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-10-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-11B-3: FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION:
   A.   No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in other than a
fireproof building, as defined in the Building Code. 1
   B.   Such establishment shall be kept free from flammable wastes, so far as
possible, and no stove or open flame of any kind shall be kept or maintained in
the premises.
   C.   No smoking shall be permitted in such premises.
   D.   All operations shall be conducted in compliance with the standards of
the National Fire Protection Association, Pamphlet No. 32, Drycleaning Plants,
1972 Edition, for safeguarding dry cleaning and dry dyeing plants. (1976 Code
§6-10-4)
 
Notes
1 2. See Title 8, Chapter 1, Article A of this Code.
3-11B-4: INSPECTIONS:
The Fire Marshal shall, from time to time, make inspections of premises used as
dry cleaning establishments to determine that all provisions of this Article
relating to the storage or handling of volatile flammable liquids are being
complied with. (1976 Code §6-10-5)
CHAPTER 12
BUSINESSES DEALING WITH HAZARDOUS MATERIALS OR CONDITIONS
ARTICLE A. FUEL OIL DEALERS
SECTION:
3-12A-1: License Required; Exceptions
3-12A-2: Application for License; Investigation
3-12A-3: License Fees
3-12A-4: Sanitary and Safety Conditions
3-12A-5: Inspections
3-12A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person shall engage in the business of fuel oil dealer without first having
obtained a license so to do. This Section shall not be construed to include or
apply to dealers in fuel oil who are licensed at the same place, location or
premises under the provisions of Chapter 7, Article B of this Title, licensing
gasoline service stations, in such a way as to require an additional license
fee from persons so licensed who pay an annual license fee that is equal to or
greater than the annual license fee required of a fuel oil dealer hereunder who
uses or proposes to use storage facilities in connection with his business;
except, that all such persons shall be required to procure an additional
license hereunder for each vehicle used by them for the conveyance of fuel oil.
(1976 Code §6-16-61)
3-12A-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for such license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  In addition, such application shall state whether the applicant
uses or proposes to use storage facilities in connection with the business of
fuel oil dealer and, if so, the location, place or premises where such storage
facilities are located or to be located, their capacity and the number of
vehicles, if any, to be used in connection with the business. (1976 Code §6-16-
2)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services and the Fire Marshal shall
investigate application for a license and the matters and things therein
stated. (1976 Code §6-16-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12A-3: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fee for a fuel oil dealer who stores and sells fuel oil and
for a fuel oil dealer who sells but does not store or possess facilities for
storing fuel oil within the City shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title and, in addition thereto, an annual fee as provided in
said Section
3-1A-1 of this Title for each vehicle, if any, in excess of one used by the
licensee in connection with such business. (1976 Code §6-16-4; amd. Ord. 0-62-
89, 12-18-89)
3-12A-4: SANITARY AND SAFETY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Generally: All places of business of fuel oil dealers shall be kept in
a clean condition, free from accumulations of rags, wastepaper and other
combustible waste materials.
   B.   Smoking Prohibited: Smoking shall be prohibited in all such places of
business.
   C.   Toilets: Adequate toilet facilities shall be provided.
   D.   Filling Tanks:
      1.   No fuel oil dealer shall refill any fuel oil storage container or
tank used in connection with an oil burning heater, boiler or furnace unless
such storage container or tank is equipped with an automatic or return vent
pipe or unless the fill pipe or such storage container or tank is equipped with
a screw or automatic cap.
      2.   Every dealer, after filling or refilling any fuel oil storage
container or tank, shall replace the screw cap on such fill pipe or, if
equipped with an automatic cap, shall see to it that the fill cap is properly
closed. (1976 Code §6-16-6)
3-12A-5: INSPECTIONS:
All premises and all vehicles used in connection with the business of fuel oil
dealers shall be inspected by the Fire Marshal or his duly authorized
representative at least once every year. (1976 Code §6-16-6)
ARTICLE B. FLAMMABLE CHEMICALS
SECTION:
3-12B-1: Acetylene Gas
3-12B-1-1: Generating Acetylene Gas
3-12B-1-2: Compressing Acetylene Gas
3-12B-2: Generating or Compressing Oxygen and Hydrogen
3-12B-3: Storage of Flammable Liquids
3-12B-4: License Fees
3-12B-5: Exemptions from Provisions
3-12B-1: ACETYLENE GAS:
3-12B-1-1: GENERATING ACETYLENE GAS:
   A.   Definition: As used herein, "portable generator" shall mean an
acetylene generator of not more than thirty (30) pounds' carbide capacity which
has been approved for portable use by the underwriters Laboratories and
included in the "List of Inspected Gas, Oil and Miscellaneous Appliances" dated
July 1934 with supplement to June 1935 of low pressure and medium pressure
acetylene generators. (1976 Code §6-13-3)
   B.   License Required: No person shall generate acetylene gas in any form of
generator, holder, container or associated apparatus at a pressure which
exceeds fifteen (15) pounds to the square inch in the generator without first
obtaining a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-13-1)
   C.   Application for License: An application for a license under this
Section
3-12B-1-1 shall be made to the Fire Marshal. Such application shall be in
writing and shall conform to the general requirements of this Code relating to
applications for licenses 1  and shall set forth the proposed location of the
generator or generators, together with the name and type of generator or
generators to be used. (1976 Code §6-13-2)
   D.   Restrictions on Portable Generators:
      1.   Installation: Portable generators shall not be installed in a
permanent or semi-permanent location unless provided with vent and relief
piping equipped with approved, interlocking devices to the open air outside of
buildings. (1976 Code §6-13-5)
      2.   Use: Portable generators shall not be used in rooms of total volume
less than thirty five (35) times the nominal aggregate gas-generating capacity
per hour of all such generators in the room. Portable generators shall not be
used in any room containing flammable liquids or gases or in which any dust-
producing process is carried on or in which any highly combustible or explosive
materials are contained. Portable generators shall not be used in any poorly
ventilated room. (1976 Code §6-13-4)
   E.   Exemptions from Provisions: The provisions of this Section
3-12B-1-1 relating to the generation of acetylene gas shall not apply to
portable generators used exclusively for lighting, to generators used in
connection with vehicle lighting, or to plants devoted to the manufacture and
compression of dissolved acetylene for sale purposes. (1976 Code §6-13-6)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12B-1-2: COMPRESSING ACETYLENE GAS:
   A.   License Required: Except as otherwise provided herein, no person shall
engage in the business of collecting or compressing acetylene gas at any
pressure in excess of fifteen (15) pounds to the square inch or of selling or
distributing acetylene gas under pressure unless such person shall have
procured a license so to do. (1976 Code §6-13-7)
   B.   Application for License: An application for a license under this
Section
3-12B-1-2 shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this
Code relating to applications for licenses 1  and shall set forth the location
and description of the building in which in which such business is to be
carried on. (1976 Code §6-13-8)
   C.   Inspection of Premises and Equipment: The application for a license
shall be referred to the Fire Marshal who will make or cause an investigation
to be made to determine whether the location, buildings, premises, machinery
and equipment comply with the provisions of this Code applicable thereto. (1976
Code §6-13-9)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12B-2: GENERATING OR COMPRESSING OXYGEN AND HYDROGEN:
   A.   License Required: No person shall generate or compress oxygen or
hydrogen in any form of generator, container or associated apparatus without
first obtaining a license so to do. (1976 Code §6-13-10)
   B.   Application for License: An application for a license under this
Section shall be made to the Fire Marshal in conformity with the general
requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses1 and shall give
the proposed location of such generator or generators, holders, containers and
associated apparatus, together with the name and type of the equipment to be
used. (1976 Code §6-13-11)
   C.   Inspection of Premises and Equipment: Upon receipt of the application
for a license, the Fire Marshal shall make or cause to be made an investigation
for the purpose of ascertaining whether the premises and the apparatus and
equipment are of such type and so located that they would not constitute a
nuisance or be a menace to the safety of the employees or to the general public
or to adjoining property. (1976 Code §6-13-12)
3-12B-3: STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS:
   A.   License Required; Exceptions: No person shall keep on hand or store for
use in any business any flammable liquid having a flash point below one hundred
eighty seven degrees (187°) Fahrenheit or eighty eight degrees (88°) Centigrade
(closed cup tester) without first procuring a license so to do for each
location, place or premises where such person keeps on hand or stores for use
any such flammable liquid.
Nothing herein contained shall require any gasoline service station, 1  dry
cleaner and spotter, 2  drug, chemical or paint factory, drug, chemical or
paint store (wholesale), fuel oil dealer, 3  fuel oil storer, retail hardware
store or retail paint store 4  duly licensed under any other provisions of this
Code to obtain a license hereunder. (1976 Code §6-13-13)
   B.   Application for License: An application for a license under this
Section shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this Code
relating to applications for licenses 5  and, in addition, the applicant shall
state the location desired or intended to store flammable liquids for use in
applicant's business, the maximum aggregate quantity to be stored for use and
shall give a description of the business engaged in, the location and capacity
of all containers or tanks having a capacity of fifteen (15) gallons or more
for the storage of any flammable liquid and such other information as may be
required by the Fire Marshal. (1976 Code §6-13-14)
   C.   Inspection of Premises and Equipment: The Fire Marshal, upon receipt of
application for license, shall investigate or cause to be investigated the
place of business described in the application and the methods and equipment
intended to be used by the applicant. (1976 Code §6-13-15)
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 7, Article B of this Title.
2 2. See Chapter 11, Article B of this Title.
3 3. See Article A of this Chapter.
4 4. See Chapter 10, Article G of this Title.
5 5. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12B-4: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fee for the generation of acetylene gas or for the use of
portable generators of acetylene gas or for the compression or sale of
acetylene gas or for the generation or compression of hydrogen or oxygen or for
the storage and handling of flammable liquids shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-13-16)
3-12B-5: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
Nothing contained in this Article shall be construed as applying to the
transportation of any article or thing shipped in conformity with the
regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission nor as applying to the Armed
Forces of the United States. (1976 Code §6-13-17)
ARTICLE C. ROOFING OR PAVING MATERIALS FACTORY
SECTION:
3-12C-1: Definition
3-12C-2: License Required
3-12C-3: Application for License; Investigation
3-12C-4: License Fee and Term
3-12C-5: Sanitary and Safety Conditions
3-12C-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, the term "roofing or paving materials factory" shall mean any
premises, building or structure where the business of boiling, distilling,
mixing or otherwise changing the form of crude asphalt, crude tar, coal-gas by-
products, with or without other materials for roofing, paving or similar uses,
is carried on. The by-products of such boiling, distilling or other process in
the manufacture of roofing or paving materials shall be considered as
incidental to and a part of such manufacture for the purposes of this Article.
(1976 Code §6-35-1)
3-12C-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate any roofing or paving materials factory
without first having obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-35-2)
3-12C-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  (1976 Code §6-35-3)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall make or cause to be made
an investigation of the premises described in the application for license for
the purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of the premises for the
conduct of such business from a sanitary standpoint and also as to whether the
applicant has complied with the State laws and provisions of this Code
regulating such establishments. Plans and specifications shall be submitted to
the Director for approval of all new roofing or paving materials factories and
subsequent additions to the same.
The Chief of the Fire Department shall investigate the premises described in
the application to determine whether fire regulations of this Code applicable
thereto have been complied with. (1976 Code §6-35-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12C-4: LICENSE FEE AND TERM:
The annual fee for a roofing or paving materials factory license shall be as
provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-35-5)
Every roofing or paving materials factory license shall expire on April 30
following the date of its issuance. (1976 Code §6-35-6)
3-12C-5: SANITARY AND SAFETY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Sanitary Conditions: No person shall conduct or operate a roofing or
paving materials factory in such a way as to permit the escape of gases, fumes
or odors that are deleterious or offensive or that are detrimental to health.
All the necessary precautions or installations, including condensers, shall be
installed to prevent the escape of offensive, deleterious or obnoxious fumes,
gases, odors or dust. Adequate measures shall be taken to safeguard the health
and lives of all persons employed in such establishments, and adequate and
convenient toilet facilities shall be provided for such employees. (1976 Code
§6-35-7)
   B.   Prevention and Protection: Every person licensed to conduct a roofing
or paving materials factory shall comply with the fire regulations of this Code
applicable thereto, and the Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall
periodically inspect each such place of business to determine whether the
regulations are being complied with. (1976 Code §6-35-8)
ARTICLE D. MACHINE SHOPS
SECTION:
3-12D-1: Definition
3-12D-2: License Required; Exceptions
3-12D-3: Application for License; Investigation
3-12D-4: License Fee
3-12D-5: Building and Premises
3-12D-6: Noise Restrictions
3-12D-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, "machine shop" shall mean a workshop in which machines are made
or metal parts thereof are repaired or where parts of machines or tools,
implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped,
punched, stamped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery. (1976 Code
§6-26-1)
3-12D-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
No person shall conduct or operate a machine shop within the limits of the City
without having first obtained a license therefor. This Section shall not apply
to any class of machine shops specifically licensed under other provisions of
this Code. (1976 Code §6-26-2)
3-12D-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for a license under this Article shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  (1976 Code §6-26-3)
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services and the Fire Marshal shall
make separate investigations in order to determine whether the building or
place within which such machine shop is conducted or is to be conducted
complies with all the provisions of this Code relating to health, safety and
sanitation, buildings and fire prevention, respectively. (1976 Code §6-24-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-12D-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for each machine shop license shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-26-5)
3-12D-5: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
   A.   Location: No machine shop shall be conducted or operated on any lot or
plot of ground of which any portion shall be within two hundred feet (200') of
any lot occupied by a public or parochial school, hospital or church. (1976
Code §6-26-6)
   B.   Fire Regulations: Each person conducting a machine shop shall comply
with the fire regulations of this Code. 1  The Fire Marshal shall inspect,
periodically, each such premises to determine whether such regulations are
being complied with. (1976 Code §6-26-8)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 1, Article D of this Code.
3-12D-6: NOISE RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall operate, within two hundred feet (200') of any residence, a
machine shop wherein pneumatic hammers or other apparatus are used which cause
loud or unusual noises. (1976 Code §6-26-7)

SECTION:
3-12E-1: License Required
3-12E-2: Application For License
3-12E-3: License Fee
3-12E-4: Bond And Insurance
3-12E-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of pest control without a license to so

An application for a license under this article shall be made in conformity

CHAPTER 13
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
3-13-1: License Required
3-13-2: Application For License; Investigation
3-13-3: Restrictions On Issuance Of License
3-13-4: License Fee
3-13-5: Lost Or Stolen Goods
3-13-6: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
3-13-7: Records
3-13-8: Melting, Wrecking And Remodeling Of Items
3-13-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without having
first obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code § 6-29-1)
3-13-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
An application for a pawnbroker's license shall be made to the mayor and city
council in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to
applications for licenses 1  and shall state thereon the name of the applicant,
the place of business and the number of employees intended to be engaged. (1976
Code § 6-29-2)
The chief of police or any other officer designated by the city council shall
investigate each applicant for license and shall report back whether or not
such applicant is a person of good character. (1976 Code § 6-29-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-3 of this title.
3-13-3: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
No license shall be issued to:
   A.   A person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen
goods or of burglary or robbery. (1976 Code § 6-29-4)
   B.   Any person who is not twenty one (21) years of age or over. (1976 Code
§ 6-29-10)
3-13-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual fee for a pawnbroker's license shall be as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (1976 Code § 6-29-5)
3-13-5: LOST OR STOLEN GOODS:
Every pawnbroker shall report to the police any article pledged with him, or
which is sought to pledge with him, if he shall have reason to believe that the
article was stolen or that the article was lost and found by the person
attempting to pledge it. (1976 Code § 6-29-8)
3-13-6: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Pawnbroker As Secondhand Dealer: No pawnbroker shall conduct the
business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained the license required
for such dealer in addition to his pawnbroker's license 1 . (1976 Code § 6-29-
9)
   B.   Weapons: No pawnbroker shall receive as a pledge or purchase any
revolver, pistol, blackjack or sawed off shotgun or display in his window or
shop any such weapons for sale. (1976 Code § 6-29-7)
   C.   Minors: No pawnbroker shall:
      1.   Employ a person of less than twenty one (21) years of age to assist
him in his business.
      2.   Have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with any person less than
twenty one (21) years of age except with the written consent of the parent or
guardian of the minor to each particular transaction. (1976 Code § 6-29-10)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 10, article C of this title.
3-13-7: RECORDS:
Every pawnbroker doing business in the city shall keep a record, in English, of
every article pledged with him or sold to him, and this record shall be open to
the inspection of any police officer at any time during business hours.
The record maintained by the pawnbroker shall be made at the time of the
transaction and shall set forth the following information:
   A.   Name, age, sex, and a general description of the individual with whom
the transaction is had, as well as the individual's residence and his signature
on the receipt and permanent record kept by the pawnbroker;
   B.   A photocopy of a driver's license;
   C.   Confirmation that a second item of identification was shown;
   D.   The price of consideration paid or received at the time of the
transaction;
   E.   A description of every article received, purchased, sold or exchanged
by the pawnbroker giving the manufacturer's name and other marks of
identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to, the
serial number, if any on the article. If writing a description of every article
is impracticable because of the number of items being sold as a unit (for
example, a coin, magazine or baseball card collection), then the pawnbroker
shall write as detailed description as practicable for the unit as a whole,
which may include such details as number of estimated of items within the unit,
the range of dates appearing on the items, general physical description of unit
as a whole, etc.;
   F.   All entries in the record shall be signed by the person making the
entry; and
   G.   Such records shall be retained for a period of at least one year from
the date of the transaction. (Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-2010)
3-13-8: MELTING, WRECKING AND REMODELING OF ITEMS:
No pawnbroker shall melt, or transfer to another to be melted, any watch,
watchcase, jewelry, or other identifiable article composed, or manufactured, in
whole or in part, of gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metals until
such pawnbroker has made a record of his intention to do so, along with all
other data required to be recorded by the specific recordation provisions of
this chapter, and has reported the same to the chief of police or his
designated agent(s), and unless and until he has kept such article intact in
his licensed place of business, for inspection for seven (7) working/business
days after the report has been made sent to the chief of police or his
designated agent(s). However, if the identifiable article proposed to be melted
down, wrecked, or remodeled has been sooner inspected by the chief of police or
his designated agent(s) and has received written clearance for such melting,
wrecking, or remodeling from same, said article may be melted, wrecked, or
remodeled prior to the expiration for the seven (7) working/business days.
(Ord. O-14-2010, 4-19-2010)
CHAPTER 14
TELEVISION STUDIOS AND TOWERS
SECTION:
3-14-1: Television Studios And Communications Businesses
3-14-2: Television Broadcasting Apparatus
3-14-1: TELEVISION STUDIOS AND COMMUNICATIONS BUSINESSES:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a
television or communications studio, business or venture within the city for
purposes of transmitting, publishing, broadcasting or otherwise disseminating
television shows, either with or without subscription, to the public, without
first obtaining a license or permit as required by this code 1 .
   B.   License Fee: Any person operating a television or communications
studio, business or venture within the city for purposes of transmitting,
publishing, broadcasting or otherwise disseminating television shows, either
with or without subscription, to the public, shall pay to the city a license
and permit fee as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (Ord. O-18-80, 10-14-1980)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
3-14-2: TELEVISION BROADCASTING APPARATUS:
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to use, install,
construct, build or assemble an antenna, tower or other structure for purposes
of transmitting, publishing, broadcasting or otherwise disseminating television
programming for public use, with or without subscription, unless said person
first obtains a license or permit for the construction, building or assemblage
of such structure.
   B.   License Fee: Any person using, installing, constructing, building or
assembling an antenna, tower or other structure for purposes of transmitting,
publishing, broadcasting or otherwise disseminating television programming for
public use, with or without subscription, shall pay to the city a license and
permit fee as provided in section
3-1A-1 of this title. (Ord. O-18-80, 10-14-1980)

FURNITURE MOVERS

3-15-3: Application for License; Fee
3-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this Section:
03 FURNITURE MOVER: Any person using or operating one or more wagons, trucks,
vans or other vehicles for the purpose of moving or transporting household or
office furniture for hire upon the public ways of the City.
HOUSEHOLD OR OFFICE FURNITURE: Means and includes all articles of furniture
which have been in use as such. It shall not be construed to mean any furniture
owned or possessed as merchandise for sale by any merchant where transporting
or cartage of the same is incident to the conducting or operation of his
business. (1976 Code §6-18-1)

having obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-18-2)
3-15-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license under this Chapter shall be made in conformity
with the general provisions of this Code relating to applications for licenses.
1  In addition, the applicant shall state the number of vehicles which it is
proposed to use in the conduct of such business. (1976 Code §6-18-3)
The annual license fee for each furniture mover shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. No license shall be issued for the sum of less than one-
half (1/2) of the annual license fee. (1976 Code §6-18-4)

CHAPTER 16
HOTELS AND MOTELS 1
SECTION:
3-16-1: License Required
3-16-2: Application for License; Fee
3-16-3: Building and Premises
3-16-4: Guests
3-16-5: Inspections
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-2-7 of this Title for hotel/motel operator's tax.
3-16-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate a hotel, motel or building or part thereof
used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are
furnished for twenty (20) or more persons for a period of one day or more
without having first secured a license therefor. (1976 Code §6-20-1)
3-16-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
An application for a license under this Chapter shall be made in conformity
with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for
licenses. 1  (1976 Code §6-20-2)
The annual fee for a license under this Chapter shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. (1976 Code §6-20-3)
 
Notes
1 2. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-16-3: BUILDING AND PREMISES:
   A.   Sanitary and Safety Conditions:
      1.   All premises used for hotel or motel purposes shall be kept in a
clean and sanitary condition, and all portions of such premises that are open
for use by guests or by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are
so open to use.
      2.   All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1
to a temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees (68°) Fahrenheit between
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and to a
temperature of not less than fifty five degrees (55°) Fahrenheit at all other
hours. (1976 Code §6-20-4)
      3.   Water closets and lavatories shall be available to all guests using
any hotel or motel. There shall be at least one bathroom equipped with water
closet, shower or tub and lavatory facilities for each unit on the premises.
(1976 Code §6-20-6)
   B.   Exits:
      1.   No building shall be used for a hotel or motel unless it is
furnished with the number of exits and fire escapes required by the building
ordinances of the City for the construction of a new hotel or motel. 1
      2.   No person shall block or permit the blocking of any exit from any
premises used for a hotel or motel. (1976 Code §6-20-5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 1 of this Code.
3-16-4: GUESTS:
   A.   Prohibited Guests: No person shall knowingly permit any fugitive from
justice to stay in any hotel or motel.
   B.   Register: Each hotel or motel proprietor shall keep or cause to be kept
a register of guests as required by State law. Such registration or list shall
be made available for inspection by any member of the Police Department at any
time. (1976 Code §6-20-7)
3-16-5: INSPECTIONS:
The Chief of Police shall inspect or cause to be inspected every hotel or motel
operated in the City as frequently as may be necessary to insure compliance
with the provisions of this Chapter. (1976 Code §6-20-8)
CHAPTER 17
DANCE SCHOOLS
SECTION:
3-17-1: Definition
3-17-2: License Required; Application
3-17-3: Investigation of Applicant; Issuance of License
3-17-4: License Fee
3-17-5: Revocation of License
3-17-1: DEFINITION:
As used herein, "dancing school" shall mean any building, room, enclosure,
premises, place or establishment in the City where instruction in the art of
dancing or dancing lessons are given and where charge or fee for such
instruction or lessons is made, paid or received. (1976 Code §
6-6-1)
3-17-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
No person shall manage, conduct, operate or carry on any dancing school in the
City without first having obtained a license therefor. (1976 Code §
6-6-2)
Any person desiring to conduct a dancing school shall make application in
writing therefor which application shall conform to the general provisions of
this Code relating to applications for licenses 1  and shall state the place of
business. (1976 Code §
6-6-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-3 of this Title.
3-17-3: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
   A.   Upon receipt of the application for license, the City Clerk shall refer
the same to the Chief of Police who shall cause an investigation to be made as
in his judgment is necessary to ascertain whether the applicant is of good
character, and he shall thereupon forward such application, together with his
recommendation, to the Mayor and City Council. (1976 Code §
6-6-4)
   B.   The Director of Health and Inspectional Services and the Fire Marshal
may cause such investigation to be made, as in their judgment is deemed
necessary, for the purpose of determining whether the premises occupied by the
applicant comply with the provisions of this Code relating to health, safety
and sanitation so as to properly safeguard the lives and health of the
employees engaged and pupils receiving their instruction therein.
If, from such investigation, they find that the applicant has failed to comply
with the fire prevention, sanitary and health regulations of the City relating
to such business, they shall forthwith report same in writing to the Mayor and
City Council who shall refuse to issue such license. (1976 Code §
6-6-5)
   C.   Upon receipt of the recommendations of the Chief of Police, the Mayor
and City Council, in their discretion, shall cause a license to be issued to
the applicant upon the payment of the license fee. (1976 Code §
6-6-6)
3-17-4: LICENSE FEE:
The annual license fee for each dancing school licensed under the provisions of
this Chapter shall be graded upon the basis of the number of instructors
engaged in the dancing school and shall be as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Title. The number of instructors engaged shall be determined by
the average number engaged during the preceding year in such establishment. In
case of an initial license, the number of instructors shall be estimated. (1976
Code §6-6-7)
3-17-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If, at any time after the granting of a license, the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services or the Fire Marshal shall certify to the Mayor and City
Council that the safety or health of the public or of pupils taught in the
dancing school or of the persons employed therein is endangered by the
maintenance of such dancing school in such building, room, enclosure, premises,
place or establishment, the Mayor and City Council shall forthwith revoke the
license therefor. (1976 Code §6-6-8)
