   B.   In addition any person convicted of four (4) or more violations of
Section
6-8-11 of this Chapter within any twelve (12) month period shall be fined an
additional amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the
fourth and each subsequent conviction within the twelve (12) month period.
Provided, however, that with regard to a firm or corporation, a fourth or
subsequent conviction shall mean a fourth or subsequent conviction attributable
to any one employee driver.
   C.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of
Section
6-8-2,
6-8-3 or
6-8-6 of this Chapter, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of such violation and may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person,
convicted of any violation of Section
6-8-2,
6-8-3 or
6-8-6 of this Chapter, shall be fined for the first or second conviction any
amount equal to not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00), and for the third and subsequent convictions by the same
person, within a period of one year after the date of the first offense, not
less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than two thousand dollars
($2,000.00). (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-14: VIOLATIONS, SENTENCE OF PERMIT MOVES:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit
issued under the provisions of Sections
6-8-20 through
6-8-32 of this Chapter by operating under a fraudulent permit or under a permit
not specifically covering the move, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall
be deemed guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of
such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. When any person is convicted
of such violation, the permit shall be null and void and such person, shall be
fined in an amount not less than ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound the
gross weight of the vehicle exceeds the gross weight of such vehicles allowable
under Section
6-8-11 of this Chapter. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-15: VIOLATIONS, SENTENCE OF PERMIT MOVES EXCEEDING AXLE WEIGHTS:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit
issued under the provisions of Sections
6-8-20 through
6-8-32 of this Chapter by operating with axle weights in excess of those
authorized in such permit, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle
may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, convicted of such violation
shall be fined in an amount not less than two cents ($0.02) nor more than five
cents ($0.05) per pound for each pound of excess weight on such axle or tandem
axle in excess of the weight authorized in the permit when the excess is one
thousand (1,000) pounds or less; not less than five cents ($0.05) nor more than
ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess
exceeds one thousand (1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less;
not less than ten cents ($0.10) nor more than fifteen cents ($0.15) per pound
for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand (2,000)
pounds and is three thousand (3,000) pounds or less; and not less than fifteen
cents ($0.15) nor more than twenty cents ($0.20) per pound for each pound of
excess weight when the excess exceeds three thousand (3,000) pounds.
Penalties for violation of this Section shall be in addition to any penalties
imposed for violation of subsection
6-8-20J of this Chapter. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-16: VIOLATIONS, SENTENCE OF PERMIT MOVES EXCEEDING GROSS WEIGHT:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit
issued under the provisions of Sections
6-8-20 through
6-8-32 of this Chapter by operating with the gross weight in excess of that
authorized in such permit, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed
guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle
may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, convicted of such violation
shall be fined in an amount not less than two cents ($0.02) nor more than five
cents ($0.05) per pound for each pound of excess weight in excess of the gross
weight authorized in the permit when the excess is one thousand (1,000) pounds
or less; not less than four cents ($0.04) nor more than seven cents ($0.07) per
pound for each pound of excess eight when the excess exceeds one thousand
(1,000) pounds and is two thousand (2,000) pounds or less; not less than seven
cents ($0.07) nor more than ten cents ($0.10) per pound for each pound of
excess weight when the excess exceeds two thousand (2,000) pounds and is three
thousand (3,000) pounds or less; not less than ten cents ($0.10) nor more than
fifteen cents ($0.15) per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess
exceeds three thousand (3,000) pounds and is four thousand (4,000) pounds or
less; not less than fifteen cents ($0.15) nor more than twenty cents ($0.20)
per pound for each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds four thousand
(4,000) pounds and is five thousand (5,000) pounds or less; and not less than
seventeen cents ($0.17) nor more than twenty five cents ($0.25) per pound for
each pound of excess weight when the excess exceeds five thousand (5,000)
pounds.
Penalties for violations of this Section shall be in addition to any penalties
imposed for violation of subsection
 6-8-20J of this Chapter. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-17: PUSHING OF DISABLED VEHICLES:
It is unlawful under any circumstances for any vehicle to push any other
vehicle on or along any street or highway in the City, except in extreme
emergency and then the vehicle shall not be pushed farther than is reasonably
necessary to remove it from the roadway or from the immediate hazard that
exists. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-18: VEHICLES EXCEEDING PRESCRIBED WEIGHT LIMITS, PREVENTING USE OF STREETS
AND HIGHWAYS BY:
The Police Department is authorized to institute and maintain a program
designed to prevent the use of public streets and highways by vehicles which
exceed the maximum weights allowed by this Chapter or which exceeds the maximum
weights allowed as evidenced by the license plates attached to such vehicle.
(Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-19: ENFORCEMENT:
Such program shall make provision for an intensive campaign by the Police
Department to apprehend any violators of the acts above mentioned, and at all
times to maintain a vigilant watch for possible violators of such acts. (Ord.
O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-20: PERMITS FOR EXCESS SIZE AND WEIGHT:
   A.   The City, with respect to streets and highways under its jurisdiction
may, in its discretion, upon application and good cause being shown therefor,
issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle
or combination of vehicles of a size or weight of vehicle or load exceeding the
maximum specified in this Chapter or otherwise not in conformity with this
Chapter upon any street or highway under its jurisdiction and for the
maintenance of which the City is responsible. Applications and permits other
than those in written or printed form may only be accepted from and issued to
the company or individual making the movement. Except for an application to
move directly across a street or highway the application shall show that the
load to be moved by such vehicle or combination of vehicles cannot reasonably
be dismantled or disassembled.
   B.   The application for any such permit shall: 1) state whether such permit
is requested for a single trip or for limited continuous operation; 2) state if
the applicant is an authorized carrier under the Illinois Motor Carrier of
Property Law, if so, his certificate, registration or permit number issued by
the Illinois Commerce Commission; 3) specifically describe and identify the
vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved; 4) state the routing
requested including the points of origin and destination; and 5) state if the
vehicles or loads are being transported for hire. No permits for the movement
of a vehicle or load for hire shall be issued to any applicant who is required
under the Illinois Motor Carrier of Property Law to have a certificate,
registration or permit and does not have such certificate, registration or
permit.
   C.   The Police Department when not inconsistent with traffic safety, is
authorized to issue or withhold such permit at its discretion; or, if such
permit is issued at its discretion to prescribe the route or routes to be
traveled, to limit the number of trips, to establish seasonal or other time
limitations within which the vehicles described may be operated on the highways
indicated, or otherwise to limit or prescribe conditions of operations of such
vehicle or vehicles, when necessary to assure against undue damage to the road
foundation, surfaces or structures, and may require such undertaking or other
security as may be deemed necessary to compensate for any injury to any roadway
or road structure. The Police Department shall maintain a daily record of each
permit issued along with the fee and the stipulated dimensions, weights,
conditions and restrictions authorized and this record shall be presumed
correct in any case of questions or dispute.
   D.   The Police Department shall, upon application in writing from any local
authority, issue a semiannual permit authorizing the local authority to move
oversize highway construction, transportation, utility and maintenance
equipment over roads under the jurisdiction of the City. The permit shall be
applicable only to equipment and vehicles owned by or registered in the name of
the local authority, and no fee shall be charged for the issuance of such
permits.
   E.   Reserved.
   F.   The form and content of the permit shall be determined by the Police
Department. Every permit shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of
vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any police
officer or authorized agent of the City and no person shall violate any of the
terms or conditions of such special permit. Violation of the terms and
conditions of the permit shall not be deemed a revocation of the permit. No
rule or regulation, nor anything herein shall be construed to authorize any
police officer, or authorized agent of the City to remove the permit from the
possession of the permittee. However, upon arrest for a violation of permit,
the permittee, or his agent, must produce the permit at any court hearing
concerning the alleged violation of permit.
If the permit designates and includes a routing to a certified scale, the
permittee, while en route to the designated scale, shall be deemed in
compliance with the weight provisions of the permit provided the axle or gross
weights do no exceed any of the permitted limits by more than the following
amounts:
 
Single axle 2,000 pounds
Tandem axle 3,000 pounds
Gross       5,000 pounds
 
   G.   The Police Department is authorized to adopt, amend, and to make
available to interested persons a policy concerning reasonable rules,
limitations and conditions or provisions of operation upon streets and highways
under the City's jurisdiction in addition to those contained in this Section
for the movement by special permit of vehicles, combinations, or loads which
cannot reasonably be dismantled or disassembled. All rules, limitations and
conditions or provisions adopted in the policy shall have due regard for the
safety of the traveling public and the protection of the highway and street
system. The requirements of the policy for flagmen and escort vehicles shall be
the same for all moves of comparable size and weight. When escort vehicles are
required, they shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   All operators shall be eighteen (18) years of age or over and
properly licensed to operate the vehicle.
      2.   Vehicles escorting oversized loads more than twelve feet (12') wide
must be equipped with a rotating or flashing amber light mounted on top as
specified under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-215.
Applicants shall be required to furnish a bond in the sum of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to the City conditioned so as to save the City,
its officers, agents and employees harmless from any claim, loss or damage that
may result from the granting of such permit or that may arise from or on
account of any work done thereunder, and further conditioned that the grantee
shall restore at his own cost, to a condition satisfactory to the City, any
pavement, subway, tunnel, sewer, pipe, conduit, or other public utility that
may be injured by reason of the transportation of such article under such
permit. In addition, the applicant shall carry general liability insurance in
an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) and shall tender
to the City a certificate of insurance evidencing same. Police vehicles may be
required for escort under circumstances as required by rules and regulations of
the Police Department.
   H.   Violation of any rule, limitation or condition or provision of any
permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this Section shall render
the permit void and the violator shall be deemed guilty of exceeding any size,
weight or load limitations in excess of those authorized by the permit.
   I.   It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be operated or movement made
under a fraudulent permit and said permit shall be void. The Police Department
shall not issue permits to the person, convicted of such violation for a period
one year after the date of conviction. Penalties for violation of this Section
shall be in addition to any penalties imposed for violation of other sections
of this Chapter.
   J.   Whenever any vehicle is operated or movement made in violation of a
permit issued in accordance with this Section, the person to whom such permit
was granted, or the driver of such vehicle, is guilty of such violation and
either, but not both, persons may be prosecuted for such violation as stated in
this subsection. Any person, convicted of such violation shall be fined for the
first offense, not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) and, for the second offense by the same person, within a
period of one year, not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than
two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and, for the third offense by the same person,
within a period of one year after the date of the first offense, not less than
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) and the Police Department shall not issue permits to the person
convicted of a third offense during a period of one year after the date of
conviction for such third offense.
Penalties for violations of this Section shall be in addition to any penalties
imposed for violation of the sections of this Chapter. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-21: FEES FOR SPECIAL PERMITS:
The Police Department with respect to highways and streets under the City's
jurisdiction shall collect a fee from the applicant for the issuance of a
permit to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles or load as
authorized in Section
6-8-20 of this Chapter. The charge for each permit shall consist of:
   A.   A service charge for special handling of a permit when requested by an
applicant;
   B.   Fees for any dimension, axle weight or gross weight in excess of the
maximum size or weight specified in this Chapter; and
   C.   Additional fees for special investigation or special police escort when
required.
With respect to overweight fees, the charge shall be sufficient to compensate
in part for the cost of the extra wear and tear on the mileage of streets or
highways over which the load is to be moved. With respect to over- dimension
permits, the fee shall be sufficient to compensate in part for the special
privilege of transporting oversize vehicle or vehicle combination and loads and
to compensate in part for the economic loss of operators of vehicles in regular
operation due to inconvenience occasioned by the oversize movements.
Fees to be paid by the applicant are to be at the rates specified in this
Chapter. In determining the fees in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-306 and
5/15-307, all weights shall be to the next highest one thousand (1,000) pounds
and all distances shall be determined from the Illinois Official Highway Map or
official City maps.
For repeated moves of like objects which cannot be dismantled or disassembled
and which are monolithically structured for permanent use in the transported
form, the fees specified in Sections
6-8-24,
6-8-25 and
6-8-26 of this Chapter for other than the first move shall be reduced by four
dollars ($4.00) provided the objects are to be moved from the same origin to
the same destination, the number of trips will not be less than five (5), the
trips will be completed within thirty (30) days, and all applications are
submitted at one time. Round trip permits shall be the same as a single trip
permit except the fee shall be computed based upon the total distance traveled,
and shall be for the same vehicle, vehicle combination or like load traveling
both directions over the same route, provided a description including make and
model of the equipment being transported is furnished to the Police Department.
Limited continuous operation permits are to be valid for a period of ninety
(90) days, and shall be for the same vehicle, vehicle combination or like load.
(Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-22: TRANSMISSION FEES:
When special transmission of permits is requested by an applicant, a service
charge in an amount sufficient to defray the costs shall be charged. (Ord. O-
01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-23: FEES FOR HOUSE TRAILER COMBINATION:
Fees for special permits to move a house trailer or modular home section in
combination with a towing vehicle shall be paid by the applicant to the City at
the rates set forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-304 as may be
amended from time to time. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-24: FEES FOR LEGAL WEIGHT BUT OVERDIMENSION VEHICLES, COMBINATIONS AND
LOADS, OTHER THAN HOUSE TRAILER COMBINATIONS:
Fees for special permits to move overdimension vehicles, combinations, and
load, other than house trailer combinations, shall be paid by the applicant to
the City at the rates set forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-305 as
may be amended from time to time.
Permits issued under this Section shall be for a vehicle, or vehicle
combination and load not exceeding legal weights; and, in the case of the
limited continuous operation, shall be for the same vehicle, vehicle
combination or like load.
Escort requirements shall be as prescribed in the Police Department's Rules and
Regulations. Fees for the police vehicle escort, when required, shall be in
addition to the permit fees. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-25: FEES FOR OVERWEIGHT-AXLE LOADS:
Fees for special permits to move legal gross weight vehicles, combinations of
vehicles and loads with overweight-axle loads shall be paid by the applicant to
the Police Department as follows:
For each overweight single axle or tandem axle group, the flat fees herein
scheduled for increments of forty five (45) miles or fraction thereof including
issuance fee predicated upon an eighteen thousand (18,000) pound single axle
equivalency.
Single trip permits only shall be issued.
   18,000 POUND SINGLE AXLE EQUIVALENCY FEES
 
Axle Weight In Excess Of Legal Limit Single Axle   2 Axle Tandem 3 Axle Tandem
1 - 6,000 pounds                     $ 5.00        $ 5.00        $ 5.00
6,001 - 11,000 pounds                8.00          7.00          6.00
11,001 - 17,000 pounds               not permitted 8.00          7.00
17,001 - 22,000 pounds               not permitted not permitted 9.00
22,001 - 29,000 pounds               not permitted not permitted 11.00
 
(Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-26: FEES FOR OVERWEIGHT-GROSS LOADS:
Fees for special permits to move vehicles, combinations of vehicles and loads
with overweight-gross loads shall be paid at the flat rate fees established in
this Section for weights in excess of legal gross weights, by the applicant to
the Police Department. Single trip permits only shall be issued:
   A.   With respect to fees for overweight-gross loads listed in this Section,
and for overweight-axle loads listed in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-
306, one fee only shall be charged, whichever is the greater, but not for both.
   B.   In lieu of the fees stated in this Section and Section
6-8-24 of this Chapter, with respect to combinations of vehicles consisting of
a three (3) axle truck tractor with a tandem axle composed of two (2)
consecutive axles drawing a semitrailer, or other vehicle approved by the
Police Department, equipped with a tandem axle composed of three (3)
consecutive axles, weighing over seventy three thousand two hundred eighty
(73,280) pounds but not more than eighty eight thousand (88,000) pounds gross
weight, the fees shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate   $10.00
For such combinations weighing over eighty eight thousand (88,000) pounds but
not more than one hundred thousand (100,000) pounds gross weight, the fees
shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate   $15.00
For such combinations weighing over one hundred thousand (100,000) pounds but
not more than one hundred ten thousand (110,000) pounds gross weight, the fees
shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate   $20.00
For such combinations weighing over one hundred ten thousand (110,000) pounds
but not more than one hundred twenty thousand (120,000) pounds gross weight,
the fees shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate   $30.00
Payment of overweight fees for the above combinations also shall include fees
for overwidth dimensions of four feet (4') or less, overheight and overlength.
Any overwidth in excess of four feet (4') shall be charged an additional fee of
fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   C.   In lieu of the fees stated in this Section and Section
6-8-24 of this Chapter, with respect to combinations of vehicles consisting of
a three (3) axle truck tractor with a tandem axle composed of two (2)
consecutive axles drawing a semitrailer, or other vehicle approved by the
Department, equipped with a tandem axle composed of two (2) consecutive axles,
weighing over seventy three thousand two hundred eighty (73,280) pounds but not
more than eighty eight thousand (88,000) pounds gross weight, the fees shall be
at the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $20.00
For such combinations weighing over eighty eight thousand (88,000) pounds but
not more than one hundred thousand (100,000) pounds gross weight, the fees
shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $30.00
Payment of overweight fees for the above combinations also shall include fees
for overwidth dimension of four feet (4') or less, overheight and overlength.
Any overwidth in excess of four feet (4') shall be charged an additional
overwidth fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   D.   In lieu of the fees stated in this Section and in Section
6-8-25 of this Chapter, with respect to a three (3) or more axle mobile crane
or water well-drilling vehicle consisting of a single axle and a tandem axle or
two (2) tandem axle groups composed of two (2) consecutive axles each, with a
distance of extreme axles not less than eighteen feet (18'), weighing not more
than sixty thousand (60,000) pounds gross with no single axles weighing more
than twenty one thousand (21,000) pounds, or any tandem axle group to exceed
forty thousand (40,000) pounds, the fees shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $12.50
For such vehicles weighing over sixty thousand (60,000) pounds but not more
than sixty eight thousand (68,000) pounds with no single axle weighing more
than twenty one thousand (21,000) pounds and no tandem axle group exceeding
forty eight thousand (48,000) pounds, the fees shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $20.00
Payment of overweight fees for the above vehicle shall include overwidth
dimension of four feet (4') or less, overheight and overlength. Any overwidth
in excess of four feet (4') shall be charged an additional overwidth fee of
fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   E.   In lieu of the fees stated in this Section and in Section
6-8-25 of this Chapter, with respect to a four (4) or more axle mobile crane or
water well-drilling vehicle consisting of two (2) sets of tandem axles composed
of two (2) or more consecutive axles each with a distance between extreme axles
of not less than twenty three feet (23') weighing not more than seventy two
thousand (72,000) pounds with axle weights on one set of tandem axles not more
than thirty four thousand (34,000) pounds, and weight in the other set of
tandem axles not to exceed forty thousand (40,000) pounds, the fees shall be at
the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $15.00
For such vehicles weighing over seventy two thousand (72,000) pounds but not
more than seventy six thousand (76,000) pounds with axle weights on either set
of tandem axles not more than forty four thousand (44,000) pounds, the fees
shall be at the following rate:
Single trip rate -- $20.00
Payment of overweight fees for the above vehicle shall include overwidth
dimension of four feet (4') or less, overheight and overlength. Any overwidth
in excess of four feet (4') shall be charged an additional fee of fifteen
dollars ($15.00).
   F.   In lieu of fees stated in this Section and in Section
6-8-25 of this Chapter, with respect to a two (2) axle mobile crane or water
well-drilling vehicle consisting of two (2) single axles weighing not more than
forty eight thousand (48,000) pounds with no single axle weighing more than
twenty five thousand (25,000) pounds, the fees shall be at the following rates:
Single trip rate -- $15.00
For such vehicles weighing over forty eight thousand (48,000) pounds but not
more than fifty four thousand (54,000) pounds with no single axle weighing more
than twenty eight thousand (28,000) pounds, the fees shall be at the following
rates:
Single trip rate -- $20.00
Payment of overweight fees for the above vehicle shall include overwidth
dimension of four feet (4') or less, overheight and overlength. Any overwidth
in excess of four feet (4') shall be charged an additional overwidth fee of
fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   G.   Fees for special permits to move vehicles, combinations of vehicles,
and loads with overweight gross loads not included in the fee categories shall
be paid by the applicant to the Police Department at the rate of fifty dollars
($50.00) plus 3.5 cents per ton-mile in excess of legal weight. Single trip
permits only shall be issued for such movements.
With respect to fees for overweight gross loads not included in the schedules
specified in subsections A through E of this Section and for overweight axle
loads listed in Section
6-8-25 of this Chapter, one fee only shall be charged, whichever is the
greater, but not both. An additional fee in accordance with the schedule set
forth in Section
6-8-24 of this Chapter shall be charged for each overdimension. (Ord. O-01-98,
1-5-1998)
6-8-27: FEES FOR POLICE ESCORT:
When City police escorts are required by the Police Department for the safety
of the motoring public, the following fees shall be paid by the applicant to
the Police Department: forty dollars ($40.00) per hour per vehicle based upon
preestimated time of movement to be agreed upon between Police Department and
applicant. The minimum fee is eighty dollars ($80.00) per vehicle. (Ord. O-01-
98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-28: SUPPLEMENTAL PERMIT FEE:
The Police Department shall collect a fee of five dollars ($5.00) and other
applicable fees to cover the cost of processing an application for supplemental
special permit. This fee shall be charged for each supplemental special permit
issued. In addition, if the supplemental permit provides for an increase in
size or weight or both over that specified in the original special permit,
additional fees shall be charged as provided in Sections
6-8-22 through
6-8-27 of this Chapter as applicable, to correct for the increase. (Ord. O-01-
98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-29: PAYMENT OF FEES:
The Police Department shall prescribe the time and method of payment of all
appropriate fees authorized by Sections
6-8-21 through
6-8-28 of this Chapter.
The Police Department may, at its discretion, establish credit accounts with
billing to be made at intervals not exceeding one month.
Failure to pay invoices in full within a period of thirty (30) days after the
billing date shall be sufficient cause for the Police Department to withhold
issuance of any further permits or credit to the individual, company, or
subsidiary firm.
The Police Department is authorized to charge a service fee of three dollars
($3.00) for a check returned for any reason. All money received by the Police
Department under the provisions of this Section shall be deposited in the Road
Fund. No refund shall be made to applicant following issuance of a permit if
move is not completed. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-30: EXEMPTIONS TO REQUIREMENT OF FEES:
   A.   The requirements as to fees authorized by Sections
6-8-21 through
6-8-29 of this Chapter shall not apply to the owner of the vehicle or vehicle
combination if owned by the United States, this State, or any political
subdivision of this State, or any municipality therein.
   B.   The provisions of Sections
6-8-21 through
6-8-29 of this Chapter requiring fees for a permit shall not modify, alter or
in any manner affect either the provisions of Section
6-8-20 of this Chapter, or the policy of the Police Department adopted for the
administration of this Chapter. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-31: RESERVED:
(Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-32: LIABILITY IF STREET, HIGHWAY OR STRUCTURE DAMAGED:
   A.   Any person driving any vehicle, object or contrivance upon any street,
highway or highway structure is liable for all damage which the highway or
structure may sustain as a result of any illegal operation, driving or moving
of such vehicle, object, or contrivance exceeding the maximum dimension or
weighing in excess of the maximum weight specified in this Chapter but
authorized by a special permit issued as provided in this Chapter. The measure
of liability is the cost of repairing a facility partially damaged or the
depreciated replacement cost of a facility damaged beyond repair together with
all other expenses incurred by the authorities in control of the highway or
highway structure in providing a temporary detour, including a temporary
structure to serve the needs of traffic during the period of repair or
replacement of the damaged highway or highway structure.
   B.   Whenever such driver is not the owner of such vehicle, object, or
contrivance, but is so operating, driving, or moving the same with the express
or implied permission of such owner, then the owner and driver are jointly and
severally liable to the extent provided in subsection A of this Section.
   C.   Recovery may be had in a civil action brought by the City. (Ord. O-01-
98, 1-5-1998)
6-8-33: WEIGHT ON RESIDENTIAL STREETS:
   A.   On all residential streets the gross weight of any type motor vehicle
including the weight of the vehicle and its maximum loads shall not exceed ten
thousand (10,000) pounds, except when such vehicle is making a local delivery,
and then such vehicle shall proceed to its destination via a section street
line or highway which is closest to it. (Ord. O-01-98, 1-5-1998; amd. Ord. O-
36-98, 7-20-1998)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Supervision And Enforcement
7-1-2: Defects, Maintenance And Repairs
7-1-3: Use Of Public Ways
7-1-4: Excavations
7-1-5: Street Openings
7-1-6: Barricades And Warning Lights
7-1-7: Deposits On Streets And Sidewalks
7-1-8: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
7-1-1: SUPERVISION AND ENFORCEMENT:
All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways in the City shall
be under the supervision of the Superintendent of Public Works. He shall be
charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such
public places except traffic ordinances. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. 1992
Code; Ord. O-36-97, 8-18-1997, eff. 12-1-1997)
7-1-2: DEFECTS, MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS:
   A.   City Employees To Report Defects: Every City officer or employee
becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk or any
obstruction thereof, shall report the same to the Superintendent of Public
Works or other proper City officers as soon as possible.
   B.   Pavement Repairs: All public street, alley and sidewalk pavements shall
be kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the City or by the
abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the Superintendent of Public
Works. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-36-97, 8-18-1997, eff. 12-1-1997)
   C.   Restoration Of Public Ways And Parkways: Any person constructing,
laying or breaking any sidewalk shall, upon completion thereof, remove any and
all materials and debris from the public ways and parkways and shall restore
the same to the condition in which it was prior to the commencement of work.
   D.   Maintenance Of Sidewalks And Walkways: All sidewalks on areas open to
the public on private property shall be maintained in a safe condition. Any
sidewalk on private property open to the general public for use or business
purposes shall be maintained by the owner and occupant of the premises in a
safe condition. Any such sidewalk containing cracks, uneven areas, holes or
other dangerous conditions is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and the owner
and the occupant shall be responsible for correcting the nuisance. (Ord. O-23-
79, 11-20-1979)
7-1-3: USE OF PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Private Use: No person shall use any street, sidewalk, parkway or other
public place as space for the storage or display of goods or merchandise for
sale. No person shall place, install or maintain on any street, sidewalk,
parkway or other public place any sign or advertisement of any type other than
traffic-control signs installed by a unit of government. Any goods,
merchandise, sign or advertisement that is placed, installed or maintained in
violation of this Section is hereby declared a public nuisance and may be
removed at any time by the City at the expense of the person responsible for
the violation. (Ord. O-20-98, 4-20-1998)
   B.   Poles And Wires: No person shall erect any poles or wires or maintain
any poles or wires over any public street, alley or other public way without
first obtaining a permit therefor from the City Council.
   C.   Gas Pumps:
      1.   Permit Required: No person shall maintain or erect any gasoline pump
or tank in any public street, alley or sidewalk without having first obtained a
permit therefor from the City Council.
      2.   Bond Or Insurance Required: No gas pump permit shall be issued until
the applicant furnishes a bond or indemnity policy, with corporate surety, to
indemnify the City against loss or liability, in the sum of twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00), occasioned by such tank or pump. (Ord. O-23-79,
11-20-1979)
7-1-4: EXCAVATIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall make any excavation in or tunnel under
any public street, alley or sidewalk or other public place in the City without
having first obtained a permit therefor.
   B.   Application For Permit: An application for a street excavation permit
shall be made to the City Clerk in conformity with the general requirements of
this Code relating to applications for licenses and permits 1  and shall
specify the intended location and the purpose of the excavation.
   C.   Bond Or Insurance Required: No street excavation permit shall be issued
until the applicant furnishes a bond or indemnity policy, with corporate
surety, to indemnify the City against loss or liability, in the sum of twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00), occasioned by such excavation and a completion
or performance bond in the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00),
guaranteeing that such excavation will be properly refilled and the surface
will be properly restored.
   D.   Refilling And Restoration Required: Any person making any street
excavation shall refill the excavation properly and shall restore the surface
to its condition before the excavation was made, as soon as possible. (Ord. O-
23-79, 11-20-1979)
   E.   Supervision: All such excavations, refills and resurfacing shall be
made subject to the supervision and direction of the Superintendent of Public
Works or any other proper City officer. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-
36-97, 8-18-1997, eff. 12-1-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code.
7-1-5: STREET OPENINGS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct or maintain any opening or
stairway in any public street or sidewalk or alley without a permit from the
City Council. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
   B.   Safety Guards: All lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a
suitable strong cover or a railing to the approval of the Superintendent of
Public Works or other proper City officer. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord.
O-36-97, 8-18-1997, eff. 12-1-1997)
7-1-6: BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS:
   A.   Barricades And Lights Required:
      1.   Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or
other public place, or making an excavation in any such place, shall maintain
suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the
work; such barricades shall be protected by lights at nighttime.
      2.   Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent
injury. Any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any such
place shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open by
proper barricades and lights.
   B.   Disturbing Or Removal Of Barricades And Lights Prohibited:
      1.   No person shall disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights
lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation opening in
any public street, alley or sidewalk.
      2.   No person shall remove any barricade or lights or danger signal
erected in front of or about any defective sidewalk or street under repair, or
undergoing reconstruction within the City, or in any way interfere with, change
or destroy such barricade, light or other danger signal. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-
1979)
7-1-7: DEPOSITS ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Generally: No person shall deposit on any street or public sidewalk any
material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof or any refuse, waste
material, glass or other articles which may do injury to any person, animal or
property. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
   B.   Deposit Of Snow: No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited on
any public thoroughfare including, but not limited to, streets, alleys and
sidewalks, any snow accumulation which might in any way obstruct, hinder,
render unsafe or create a nuisance to the orderly and normal use of said public
thoroughfare.
Any person violating any provision of this subsection shall be fined not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day on which a
violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate and distinct
offense. (Ord. O-01-79, 1-23-1979; amd. 1992 Code)
   C.   Merchandise On Sidewalks: Merchandise or other articles may be
deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery; provided, that the usable width
of the sidewalk is not thereby reduced to less than four feet (4') and
provided, that no such article remains on such walk for more than one-half (1/
2) hour.
   D.   Casting Rinds Or Peels On Sidewalks: No person shall throw, cast, lay
or place on any sidewalk in the City the rind or peel of any orange, banana,
apple or other fruit.
   E.   Coal On Streets: Coal or other materials may be deposited in streets
preparatory to delivery or use; provided, that such deposit does not reduce the
usable width of the roadway at that point to less than eighteen feet (18');
provided further, that such material or coal, other than material to be used in
actual building construction, shall not be permitted to remain on such street
for more than three (3) hours.
Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same remains upon
any street after nighttime. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
7-1-8: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Injury To Pavements:
      1.   No person shall injure any sidewalk, street or alley pavement.
      2.   No person shall walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or
injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by
a warning sign or barricade or knowingly injure any soft or newly laid
pavement. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
   B.   Obstructions: No person shall cause, create or maintain any obstruction
of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may be
specifically authorized by ordinance or by the Director of Public Works when
necessary in an emergency or in connection with any lawful construction, repair
or removal work. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-36-97, 8-18-1997, eff.
12-1-1997)
   C.   Encroachments:
      1.   No person shall erect or maintain any building or structure which
encroaches upon any public street or property. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
      2.   No person shall install, place, maintain or construct any structure
that encroaches upon the State right of way for North Avenue within the limits
of the City. (Ord. O-36-89, 9-6-1989)
   D.   Drains: No person shall obstruct any drain in any public street or
alley.
   E.   Playing On Streets Or Sidewalks: No person shall play any games upon
any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place where such games cause
unnecessary noise or interfere with traffic or pedestrians. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-
20-1979)
ARTICLE A. STREET AND SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-1A-1: Construction Permit
7-1A-2: Bond and Insurance Requirements
7-1A-3: Sidewalk Construction
7-1A-3-1: Specifications for Concrete Sidewalks
7-1A-1: CONSTRUCTION PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct, lay or break any pavement
on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or repair the same
without first having secured a permit therefor.
   B.   Application for Permit: An application for a permit to construct or
repair streets or sidewalks shall be made to the Clerk in conformity with the
general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses and
permits 1  and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the
extent thereof and the person who shall do the actual construction work.
   C.   Permit Fee: The fee for all sidewalk permits shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Code.
   D.   Restrictions on Issuance: No permit for construction or repair of
streets or sidewalks shall be issued except on order of the City Council. (Ord.
0-23-79, 11-20-79)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 7 of this Code.
7-1A-2: BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Bond and Insurance: No person shall build, construct or lay down
a cement, concrete or stone sidewalk or driveway 1  upon any public way in the
City unless he shall file with the City Clerk a bond or certificate of
insurance indemnifying the City in the minimum amount of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) for any claim or liability of the City or for any damage to City
property during the construction of the sidewalk or during a period of one year
following the completion of the sidewalk. If a sidewalk is constructed by a
property owner doing his own labor without a contractor, he shall file with the
City Clerk a certificate of insurance indicating that a homeowner's liability
policy is in effect which will be sufficient to comply with this requirement.
   B.   Performance Bond; Cash Deposit; Real Estate Bond: In addition to the
permit bond, the owner or contractor shall furnish a performance bond or a cash
deposit in a sum equal to three dollars ($3.00) per running foot when the
sidewalk or driveway is upon the City's easement for the public's use. Such
deposit or performance bond shall be returned or discharged after the final
inspection (Phase 4) and approval of the sidewalk by the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services. Where a sidewalk is constructed by a property owner with
his own labor without the use of a contractor, a real estate bond pledging the
property in question will be adequate to comply with the requirements of this
subsection. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
 
Notes
1 2. See Article C of this Chapter.
7-1A-3: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Sidewalk Construction Required; General Provisions:
      1.   A concrete sidewalk shall be constructed on each side of each street
where eighty percent (80%) of the sidewalk on each side is already in and
constructed.
      2.   All sidewalk construction shall be under the direction and
supervision and to the satisfaction of the City Engineer, and all necessary
labor and work shall be performed in good and workmanlike manner.
      3.   For the purpose of constructing sidewalks, the grades and lines of
construction shall be determined by the City Engineer.
   B.   Notice to Property Owners of Sidewalk Construction: All owners of lots,
blocks, tracts or parcels of land touching the line of proposed sidewalks are
hereby required to construct the sidewalk in front of or touching upon their
respective lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of land, in accordance with the
specifications for the construction of sidewalks now on file with the City
Clerk, within sixty (60) days after the mailing of notice addressed to the
party who last paid the general taxes on the respective lots, blocks, tracts or
parcels of land. In default thereof, the City may furnish the materials and
construct these sidewalks or may enter into a contract for the furnishing of
the materials and the construction of these sidewalks, in accordance with the
provisions of this Article.
   C.   Construction Not to Vary with Street Grade: All sidewalks constructed
in compliance with the provisions of this Article shall not vary more than six
inches (6") above or below an already established street grade. Where there is
no established street grade, construction of sidewalks shall be in compliance
with a grade established by the City Engineer. Upon completion of a permanent
street and/or gutter program hereafter, sidewalks varying more than six inches
(6") above or below the established street grade, but constructed in accordance
with a grade established by the City Engineer prior to establishment of a
permanent grade, shall be replaced by the City at no cost or expense to
property owner whatsoever. The City Clerk shall refer written complaints of
such variations to the City Engineer. The Director of Public Works shall
replace sidewalks within sixty (60) days after receipt of certification from
the City Engineer of such variance.
   D.   Construction by Property Owner: Sidewalk improvements, if made by the
abutting property owners, shall be made by owners of each lot, block, tract or
parcel of land of seventy five feet (75') or less upon posting with the City of
either five hundred dollars ($500.00) in cash, returnable to the party posting
the same in one year, or security for performance bond; provided, that all
corner lots shall be included even though they exceed seventy five feet (75').
All owners of lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of land of seventy six feet (76')
or more shall comply with all ordinances as to the posting of performance bonds
in such cases, and provided, further, any person, in any event, shall file with
the City evidence of public liability insurance to cover such construction as
herein directed in such amounts and of such kinds as provided by ordinance.
   E.   Construction by City; Special Tax:
      1.   Sidewalk improvements, if not made by the abutting property owners,
shall be made by the City, and the whole cost thereof shall be paid by special
tax in accordance with chapter 24, article 63 of the Illinois Revised Statutes.
      2.   Special Tax List: If the owners of lots, blocks, tracts or parcels
of land fail or refuse to construct their portion of the sidewalk in accordance
with the provisions of this Article, the City Clerk shall prepare a special tax
list against these lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of land touching upon such
sidewalks and which were not constructed by the owners, ascertaining, by
computation, the amount of special taxes and the annual installments thereof to
be charged against each of these lots, blocks, tracts or parcels of land.
      3.   Annual Installments: The total amount of the special tax assessed
and each individual assessment shall be divided into five (5) annual
installments which shall bear interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per
annum in accordance with chapter 24, article 63 of the Illinois Revised
Statutes.
      4.   Vouchers: For the purpose of anticipating the collection of the
installments of the special tax herein provided for, the City shall issue
vouchers bearing not to exceed five percent (5%) interest annually, payable
solely out of a special tax provided for in this Article when the tax is
collected. Such vouchers shall be issued in accordance with and shall in all
respects conform to the provisions of chapter 24, article 63 of the Illinois
Revised Statutes.
   F.   Supervision of Construction: The City Engineer is hereby designated to
take charge of the construction of these sidewalks and to prepare a bill of the
costs of construction, together with a list of the lots, blocks, tracts or
parcels of land touching upon the line of sidewalks, the names of the parties
who last paid the general taxes on the respective lots, blocks, tracts or
parcels of land and levy the cost according to the number of feet of property
touching upon said sidewalks.
   G.   Inspections: All work and materials used shall be inspected by the City
and the finished sidewalk shall be subject to inspection and acceptance by the
City prior to authorizing payment to the contractor.
The Director of Health and Inspectional Services or any other duly authorized
inspector shall make the following inspections during the course of all
installation of sidewalks in the following phases, and no subsequent phase of
work to be performed shall be commenced before a previous phase of the
construction is inspected:
      1.   Phase 1: Inspection of the excavation.
      2.   Phase 2: Inspection of the stone quantities in accordance with this
City Code for sidewalks.
      3.   Phase 3: Inspection of concrete specifications of sidewalks in
accordance with this City Code.
      4.   Phase 4: Inspection to determine that all excess material is leveled
and graded and debris removed. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79; 1992 Code)
7-1A-3-1: SPECIFICATIONS FOR CONCRETE SIDEWALKS: 1
All labor, material, equipment and tools necessary for the construction of all
concrete sidewalks shall be furnished and placed in compliance with the
following specifications:
   A.   Dimensions: All walks constructed in front of and siding residentially
zoned property shall be five feet (5') in width and five inches (5") in
thickness. Walks constructed in front of and siding business or industrially
zoned property shall be six feet (6') in width and five inches (5") in
thickness. Location of walks shall be one foot (1') streetward from the right-
of-way line, unless otherwise authorized by the City.
   B.   Grade: The standard grade for sidewalk shall be at a slope not less
than one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot (1') of parkway width where curb is
existing. Where conditions require, this standard may be modified as directed
by the Director of Health and Inspectional Services. Where no curbs exist, the
grade shall be established by the City.
   C.   Weather Conditions: No sidewalk shall be installed when the temperature
is forty five degrees (45°) or lower or when the United States Weather Bureau
forecasts a temperature of less than forty degrees (40°) within seventy two
(72) hours after pouring concrete.
   D.   Materials for Concrete:
      1.   All materials to be incorporated in concrete placed under these
specifications shall comply with the following specifications:
         a.   Portland Cement: Portland Cement shall conform to Type 1 of the
standard specifications and tests for Portland cement (Serial Designation C150-
56) of the American Society for Testing Materials and subsequent revisions
thereto.
         b.   Fine Aggregate: Fine aggregate shall consist of sand having
clean, hard, durable, uncoated grains, free from deleterious substances and
shall range in size from fine to coarse within the limits indicated below,
percentage by weight. Sand shall be obtained from a source known to be in
current use on concrete construction:
Passing through No. 4 sieve not less than ninety five percent (95%).
Passing through No. 100 sieve about five percent (5%).
         c.   Coarse Aggregate: Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed
stone, gravel or other approved inert materials with similar characteristics,
or combination thereof, having clean, hard, durable, uncoated particles, free
from deleterious matter. It shall range in size from fine to coarse within the
following percentages, by weight. Coarse aggregate shall be obtained from a
source known to be in current use on concrete construction:
Passing one and one-half inch (11/2") sieve not less than ninety five percent
(95%).
Passing No. 4 sieve not more than five percent (5%).
         d.   Mixing Water: Mixing water shall be clean and shall be free from
oil, acid and injurious amounts of vegetable matter, alkalies or other salts.
      2.   All concrete shall be volume proportioned on the basis of one part
Portland cement, two (2) parts of fine aggregate and three and one-half (31/2)
parts of coarse aggregate with only enough water added to make a workable mix;
except, that all concrete shall contain not less than six (6) sacks of cement
per cubic yard. All concrete shall contain four percent (4%) to six percent
(6%) of entrained air. Slump shall not exceed four inches (4"). All concrete
used shall be subject to satisfactory inspection by the Director of Health and
Inspectional Services.
   E.   Cylinder or Cores: The Director of Health and Inspectional Services may
order standard concrete cylinder or cores made of concrete deemed questionable
by him. Such cylinder or cores shall be obtained and tested by a reputable
testing laboratory approved by the City. Concrete shall have a strength of
three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch at twenty five (25)
days when tested by standard methods.
   F.   Subgrade:
      1.   During excavation, all unsuitable material such as black dirt,
broken concrete, spoil or any other material deemed unsatisfactory by the
Director of Health and Inspectional Services shall be removed from the sidewalk
area and a satisfactory subgrade established. Fill under sidewalks shall
consist of tamped or rolled sand, gravel or crushed stone, satisfactory to the
Director of Health and Inspectional Services.
      2.   The subgrade shall be tamped or rolled until thoroughly compacted,
shall be constructed true to line, grade and cross-section for the bottom of
the sidewalk or sidewalk apron and shall be prepared sufficiently wide to
accommodate the forms.
   G.   Embankments: Embankments prepared for walk construction shall be not
less than six inches (6") wider on each side than the width of the walk to be
installed.
   H.   Forms:
      1.   Side forms shall be lumber with a nominal thickness of two inches
(2") or of steel of equal rigidity. They shall be held securely in place by
stakes or braces, with the top edges true to line and grade. The forms for
street sidewalks shall be so set that the slab will have a fall of one inch
(1") vertical to four feet (4') horizontal from the edge nearest the property
line toward the edge farthest from the property line.
      2.   Forms for the sidewalk aprons shall be so set that the slab will
have a uniform fall between the sidewalk proper and the curb grade. Forms shall
be of a depth equivalent to or greater than the thickness of the walk;
   I.   Laying Concrete: The subgrade or subbase shall be adequately moistened
just before the concrete is placed. The concrete shall be placed in successive
bate for the entire width of the slab, tamped until all voids are removed and
free mortar appears on the surface thoroughly spaded along the edges, struck
off to the true grade and finished to a true and even surface with suitable
trowels and floats. The surface shall be divided by grooves constructed at
right angles to the center line of the sidewalk. These grooves shall extend to
one-fourth (1/4) the depth of the sidewalk, shall be not less than one-eighth
inch (1/8") or more than one-fourth inch (1/4") in width and shall have the
edge rounded one-fourth inch (1/4"). No slab shall be longer than six feet (6')
or less than four feet (4') unless otherwise approved by the Director of Health
and Inspectional Services. The side edges of the walk shall also be edged with
an edging tool, having a one-fourth inch (1/4") radius. The finished sidewalk
shall be finally dragged across its width with a brush or the surface otherwise
roughened by approved methods to give a nonskid finish.
   J.   Expansion Joints:
      1.   Expansion joints, one-half inch (1/2") thick, shall be provided
between the sidewalk and all structures, such as light standards, traffic light
standards, traffic poles, etc., which extend through the sidewalk.
      2.   Expansion joints, one inch (1") thick, shall be placed wherever
sidewalks abut against concrete driveways, concrete pavements, concrete curb
and/or concrete walks.
   K.   Curing:
      1.   The concrete shall be cured by protecting it against loss of
moisture, rapid temperature change and from rain, flowing water and mechanical
injury for a period of not less than three (3) days from the beginning of the
curing operation. Moist curing, waterproof paper, white polyethylene sheeting,
liquid membrane compound or a combination thereof may be used for curing.
Immediately after finishing operations have been completed, the entire surface
of the newly laid concrete shall be covered by the curing medium which is
applicable to local conditions and approved by the City Engineer. The edge of
concrete slabs exposed by the removal of forms shall be protected immediately
to provide these surfaces with continuous curing treatment equal to the method
selected for curing the slab surface and to prevent injury to pavement edges;
      2.   The use of a covering material which contains or becomes
contaminated with sugar in any form, tannic acid or any other substances
considered detrimental to Portland cement will not be permitted. The initial
curing medium shall be effective and shall be applied so as to prevent
checking, crackling and the appearance of dry spots in the surface of the
concrete. The contractor shall have the equipment needed for adequate curing at
hand and ready to install before actual concrete placement begins. In all cases
in which the curing medium requires the use of water, the curing shall have
prior right to all water supply. Failure to provide sufficient cover material
of the type selected, failure to maintain saturation for the entire curing
period in the moist-curing methods, lack of water to adequately care for both
curing and other requirements or other failures to comply with curing
requirements shall be cause for immediate suspension of concreting operations.
      3.   Moist curing shall be accomplished by covering of burlap, cotton
mats or other approved fabric mat, used singly or in combination. Curing mats
shall be thoroughly wet when applied and kept continuously wet and in intimate
contact with the pavement surface for the duration of the moist-curing period.
Other fabric mats shall conform in design and shall provide a curing medium at
least equal to cotton mats. Cotton mats, other fabric mats and burlap strips
shall be furnished in the widths or lengths, after shrinkage, required to cover
the entire width and edges of the pavement lane. Mats or burlap shall be lapped
at joints between adjacent sheets to prevent drying of this location. Moist-
curing, when used as initial curing, shall be continued for not less than
twenty four (24) hours.
      4.   The surface of the concrete shall be wetted with a fine spray of
water and then covered with the waterproof paper. The paper shall be in pieces
large enough to cover the entire width and edges of the slab and shall be
lapped not less than twelve inches (12"). Paper shall be adequately weighted to
prevent displacement or billowing due to wind. Paper folded down over the side
of the pavement edges shall be secured by continuous bank of earth. Tears or
holes appearing in the paper during the curing period shall be immediately
repaired. Waterproof paper for curing concrete shall conform to the current
ASTM or AASHO Specification for Waterproof Paper for Curing Concrete (C-171 and
M-139, respectively).
      5.   White polyethylene sheeting shall consist of a single sheet having a
thickness of not less than four (4) mills (0.004"). Moisture retention shall
conform to the requirements of ASTM Specifications - Designation C156; except,
that air-entraining Portland cement shall be used in the mortar. The material
shall be tested for tensile strength and elongation as prescribed in the
current ASTM Specifications Designation D-882-Method A.
      6.   Membrane curing compounds shall be the white pigmented type or
approved equal and conform to the requirements for the current AASHO Standard
Specifications for Liquid Membrane-Forming Compounds for Curing Concrete
(designation: M-148). The curing compound must be applied to cover the surface
completely and uniformly at a rate which will achieve the performance
requirements specified in AASHO Specifications M-148. This method of curing
shall be applied immediately behind the final finishing operation or after the
initial curing when a combination of methods are used. Failure to provide
complete and uniform coverage at the required rate will be cause for
discontinuance of this method of curing and the substitution of one of the
other approved methods. The compound shall be kept agitated to prevent the
pigment from settling. Special care shall be taken to apply the curing compound
to the pavement edges immediately after the forms have been removed.
   L.   Barricades and Lights: Sidewalks shall be properly barricaded and
lighted after finishing.
   M.   Space Adjacent to Sidewalks: After removal of forms, the space
alongside the sidewalk shall be filled with topsoil and leveled to prevent a
finished appearance.
   N.   Longitudinal and Transverse Joints: Longitudinal and transverse joints
shall be constructed as shown on the plans. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  11-4A-1C of this Code.
ARTICLE B. SIDEWALK SPACE
SECTION:
7-1B-1: Sidewalk Space Permit
7-1B-2: Construction of Vaults; Inspection
7-1B-3: Safety Guards
7-1B-4: Maintenance and Repair of Sidewalks Over Vaults
7-1B-5: Use Restrictions
7-1B-1: SIDEWALK SPACE PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall use any vault, space, room or
structure under any street or sidewalk in the City without having first
obtained a permit therefor.
   B.   Application for Permit: An application for a permit to use or maintain
a vault, space, room or structure under any street or sidewalk in the City
shall be made in writing to the City Clerk and shall state thereon,
specifically, the size of the space to be used or maintained and the purpose
for which it is to be used. Each application shall contain an agreement by the
applicant to abide by the regulations contained in this Article.
   C.   Permit Fee: The annual fee for a permit under this Article shall be in
an amount as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Code.
   D.   Bond: Each applicant for a permit hereunder shall file with the
application a surety company bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), with surety to be approved by the City Council, conditioned to
save the City harmless from any liability resulting from or caused by such
vault, room or structure. Whenever, in the opinion of the City Council, the
sureties on such bond become insolvent or unlawful, different sureties may be
required by order of the City Council. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
   E.   Issuance of Permit: Permits required by this Article shall be issued by
the City Clerk. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79; 1992 Code)
   F.   Transfer of Permit: No permit issued under this Article shall be
transferred except in accordance with the provisions of this Article.
Whenever any premises abutting on any vault, room, space or structure for which
a permit has been issued shall be conveyed or whenever the interest or lease or
right of occupancy of the person holding the permit shall be transferred or
conveyed, the grantee or transferee must make the application for a transfer of
the permit to him and must furnish a bond as is required in subsection D of
this Section. A fee as provided in Section
3-1A-1 of this Code shall be required for such transfer, and upon the payment
of the fee and the full compliance with the contents hereof, a new permit shall
be issued.
   G.   Revocation of Permits: Any permit issued under the provisions of this
Article may be revoked by order of the City Council for any violation hereof.
(Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
7-1B-2: CONSTRUCTION OF VAULTS; INSPECTION:
Vaults, rooms, spaces or structures shall be firmly constructed so as to
support the sidewalk or street over them, with the maximum load which the
sidewalk or street will carry, with a margin of safety of fifty percent (50%)
over its maximum load or weight.
The Director of Public Works shall inspect all rooms, spaces, vaults or
structures to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this Section. (Ord.
0-23-79, 11-20-79)
7-1B-3: SAFETY GUARDS:
All openings through the sidewalk or street into any vault, space, room or
structure shall be kept covered and graded. If the opening is a manhole or trap
door, an adequate, strong metal cover must be provided and must be equipped
with a rough surface so that there will be no danger of any pedestrian slipping
on it. If a stairway is provided, the stairway must be properly guarded with a
railing at least three feet (3') high to protect pedestrians from injury. (Ord.
0-23-79, 11-20-79)
7-1B-4: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF SIDEWALKS OVER VAULT:
The surface of the sidewalk over any vault, space, room or structure shall be
kept free from snow and ice and free from all dirt and obstruction of any kind
by the person holding the permit. Such person must keep the sidewalk over such
vault, space, room or structure in good repair. (Ord. 0-23-79, 11-20-79)
7-1B-5: USE RESTRICTIONS:
No vault, space, room or structure shall be used for the storing of explosives
or flammable liquids nor shall a cesspool be located therein. (Ord. 0-23-79,
11-20-79)
ARTICLE C. DRIVEWAYS
SECTION:
7-1C-1: Driveway Construction Permit
7-1C-2: Maintenance And Repair
7-1C-3: Definitions
7-1C-4: Construction Requirements
7-1C-1: DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION PERMIT 1 :
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct, replace or repair any
driveway in or across any public walk, curb or parkway without first having
obtained a permit therefor from the City Council.
   B.   Application For Permit: An application for a driveway permit shall be
in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to
applications for licenses and permits 2  and shall state the size, location and
material to be used in such driveway and shall include plans and specifications
therefor. No person shall depart from such plans and specifications or vary
from them without permission of the City Council.
   C.   Permit Fee: The fee for a driveway permit shall be as provided in
Section
3-1A-1 of this Code. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section 7-1A-2 of this Chapter for bond and insurance requirements.
2 2. See Title 3, Chapter 1 of this Code.
7-1C-2: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR:
Every person maintaining a driveway shall keep the same free from snow or ice
or any obstruction and shall keep the same in good repair where it crosses any
public sidewalk. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
7-1C-3: DEFINITIONS:
CURB CUT: The location of the transition of a driveway to a public street.
DRIVEWAY: The paved area located beyond the curb of a public street on a lot
which is designed for access to a garage and/or the parking of motor vehicles.
LOT: A parcel of land legally described as a distinct portion or piece of land
of record. (Ord. O-22-99, 12-6-1999)
7-1C-4: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
In addition to all other requirements imposed by this Code, all driveways
constructed on any lot in a residential district shall comply with the
following:
   A.   No driveway shall exceed twenty four feet (24') in width except that
the width of a driveway may exceed twenty four feet (24') at the point that the
driveway connects to a garage and from the connection to the garage for a
distance not to exceed thirty feet (30') toward the front lot line.
   B.   No driveway shall have more than one curb cut. Circular driveways are
prohibited.
   C.   No lot shall have more than one driveway.
   D.   The total paved area (including driveway, sidewalks, patios, and
parking pad) of a lot shall not exceed twenty five percent (25%) of the total
area of a lot.
   E.   Abutting paved or gravel sidewalks or patios considered as part of
driveway for purposes of determining overall width, size and area of driveway.
   F.   A paved parking pad not to exceed twelve feet by twenty four feet (12'
x 24') may be constructed adjacent to a garage on a lot provided that it
complies with all other requirements of this Section.
   G.   All driveways must be paved with a hard durable surface such as
concrete, asphalt, brick pavers or permeable brick pavers. No gravel, sand or
dirt driveways shall be allowed.
   H.   No driveway located in a front yard of any lot shall extend more than
twelve feet (12') across the front elevation of the residence located on such
lot except when the driveway connects to an attached garage. (Ord. O-22-99, 12-
6-1999; amd. Ord. O-13-2023, 8-14-2023)
CHAPTER 2
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Approval Of Improvements Required
7-2-2: Permit Or Authorization Required; Plans And Specifications
7-2-3: Engineering Fees
7-2-4: Contract Price Placed In Escrow
7-2-5: Benefits To Other Property Owners
7-2-6: Exemptions From Provisions
7-2-1: APPROVAL OF IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED:
No work involving the construction of any public improvement constructed under
the provisions of this chapter shall be engaged in without the permission of
the Superintendent of Public Works and without notifying the inspector assigned
to the particular improvement. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-36-97, 8-
18-1997, eff. 12-1-1997)
7-2-2: PERMIT OR AUTHORIZATION REQUIRED; PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Any person owning or being interested in any real estate located within the
City and desiring to construct any improvement of or in any street, avenue,
alley or other publicly owned property adjacent to or in the neighborhood of
his privately owned property and for the benefit of such property shall first
obtain a permit or authorization from the City Council for the preparation of
plans and specifications for such improvement by the City Engineer. All plans
and specifications for such proposed improvement must be approved by the City
Council before the letting or execution of any contract for the construction of
such proposed work, the award of such contract must be approved by the City
Council and a copy of such contract, together with copies of any exhibits
attached thereto and of the plans and specifications so approved by the City
Council, must be filed with the City Clerk. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
7-2-3: ENGINEERING FEES:
After authorization for plan and specification preparation is granted by the
City Council, the person owning or being interested in the development of such
real estate shall deposit with the Finance Director for engineering services
for the preparation of such plans and specifications, a sum of money based
either upon an agreement for such service between such owner and such engineer
or based upon the following schedule:
8% of the first $15,000.00 of construction cost, plus
51/2% of the next $15,000.00 of construction cost, plus
41/2% of the next $45,000.00 of construction cost, plus
31/2% of all construction cost in excess of $75,000.00.
(Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd. Ord. O-24-2018, 11-19-2018)
7-2-4: CONTRACT PRICE PLACED IN ESCROW:
   A.   The total amount of the contract price for the construction of such
proposed improvement shall be deposited in escrow with the Finance Director
before any work shall be commenced under such contract. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-
1979; amd. Ord. O-24-2018, 11-19-2018)
There shall also, at the same time, be deposited by such owner a sufficient
amount of money to pay the engineering charges of the City Engineer for
services to be rendered in connection with the construction of the proposed
improvement, the amount to be based either upon an agreement for such service
between such owner and such engineer or based upon the following schedule:
      1.   For the services of a qualified full-time resident engineer or
inspector, five hundred twenty five dollars ($525.00) to six hundred dollars
($600.00) per month based upon an estimate of the time required for such
inspection prepared by the City Engineer and submitted to the owner and the
City Council.
      2.   On contracts which require the services of a resident engineer or
inspector, two percent (2%) of the first fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00)
worth of construction cost and one and one-half percent (11/2%) of all
construction costs above fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00).
   B.   On contracts which do not require the services of a resident engineer
or inspector, three and one-half percent (31/2%) of the first ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00) worth of construction cost and two and one-half percent
(21/2%) of all construction costs above ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
(Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
   C.   Monies so deposited as provided in this section shall be paid by the
Finance Director to the parties entitled thereto on monthly estimates issued by
the City Engineer and only upon the order of the City Council up to ninety
percent (90%) of such estimates furnished. Upon the issuance of a final
estimate so marked, accompanied by letter from the City Engineer stating that
such work has been completed in accordance with plans and specifications and
the acceptance of the completed improvement by the City Council, the final
balance due the contractor or contractors shall be payable. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-
20-1979; amd. Ord. O-24-2018, 11-19-2018)
7-2-5: BENEFITS TO OTHER PROPERTY OWNERS:
Where the improvement so constructed shall be of benefit to property other than
the property of the person constructing or having such improvement constructed
for the benefit of his property and if the owners of or parties interested in
such additional property so benefited shall not have contributed their
proportionate share of the cost of such improvement, the City shall, by
ordinance, provide that no owner or person interested in such other property so
benefited shall be permitted to connect to such improvement or to receive the
benefit thereof unless and until the owner or owners of such property shall
have contributed a proportionate share of the cost of the construction of such
improvement and deposited the same with Finance Director to be paid to the
owner or owners who have originally paid the cost of such improvement, less two
percent (2%) for the collection and handling of such additional funds to be
deducted from such additional deposits made. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979; amd.
Ord. O-24-2018, 11-19-2018)
The provision of this section shall not apply to any street paving
improvements. (Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
7-2-6: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
Improvements consisting of the construction of sidewalks costing less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00), unless it is a part of the general street
improvement, and the construction of driveway aprons and sewer and water
service connections shall be exempted from the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. O-23-79, 11-20-1979)
CHAPTER 3
TREES AND SHRUBS 1
SECTION:
7-3-1: Intent; Tree Defined
7-3-2: Authority; Permission to Plant
7-3-3: Approved Trees
7-3-4: Prohibited Trees
7-3-5: Reforestation
7-3-6: Spacing of Trees
7-3-7: Planting Requirements
7-3-8: Spraying and Pruning; Tree Removal
7-3-9: Construction Procedures Around Trees on City Property
7-3-10: Hedges and Shrubs
7-3-11: Penalties

  11-4-7B of this Code.
7-3-1: INTENT; TREE DEFINED:
Trees, as defined, regulated and protected herein, are declared to be a
natural, public resource, and it is the intent of the City Council to protect
them as herein set out in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of the
present and future citizens of the City. For the purpose of this Chapter, a
tree is defined to be a woody plant that attains a height of at least twenty
feet (20') at maturity in a given locality and usually (but not always) has but
a single, self-supporting stem or trunk. (Ord. 0-28-90, 6-4-90)
7-3-2: AUTHORITY; PERMISSION TO PLANT:
The Director of Public Works or his authorized representative is hereby
empowered to superintend, regulate the planting, preservation, protection and
maintenance of trees on all City- owned properties, parkways, rights of way,
easements and utilities easements. No persons hall plant any tree, shrub or any
other woody plant on any City parkway until the Director of Public Works or his
authorized representative has given written permission for such planting. In
the absence of the needed permission, the Director of Public Works or his
authorized representative may require removal of any unapproved tree, either by
the resident or by the City Public Works Department. (Ord. 0-28-90, 6-4-90)
7-3-3: APPROVED TREES:
Trees to be planted in City parkways shall be selected from the following list
of authorized tree species and/or other species as approved by the Director of
Public Works.
